all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 Heard learned counsel for the petitioners and learned counsel appearing for the State assisted by the learned counsel for the informant. 
 Defects, as pointed out by the office, are ignored. The petitioners apprehend their arrest in connection with Pakur(T) P.S. Case No. 193 of 2019, registered for the offence punishable undersections 341,323,504,379,34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 It has been alleged that the accused persons come to the house of the informant and started abusing him. The petitioner no. 1 had assaulted the informant on his head with an iron rod and the other accused persons had assaulted him with lathi. 
 It has been stated by the learned counsel for the informant that the case has been found to be true undersection 307of IPC. It has further been submitted that the petitioner no. 1 has three criminal antecedents. 
 It appears that the specific allegation of assault upon the informant with the iron rod has been attributed to the petitioner no. 1 who also has criminal antecedent. In such view of the matter, I am not inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner no.1, which is, accordingly rejected. 
 However, so far as the petitioner nos. 2 & 3 are concerned, the allegations are general and omnibus in nature. 
 On consideration of the aforesaid facts, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner nos. 2 & 3. Accordingly, the petitioner nos. 2 & 3, above named, are directed to surrender in the court below within a period of four weeks from today and pray for regular bail, and in that event, they will be enlarged on bail, on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Ten Thousand only) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned C.J.M., Pakur, in connection with Pakur(T) P.S. Case No. 193 of 2019, subject to the conditions as laid down undersection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application, accordingly, stands disposed. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J.) MM

case title: Jayanto Banerjee vs State Of Jharkhand

Coram: Hon'ble Mr. Justice Ananda Sen Through:-Video Conferencing ...... 
 which has been held through video conferencing today at 11.00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 Defects stand ignored for the present. 
 Heard the parties. 
 The petitioners, in this application, have challenged the order 27.08.2019, by which cognizance of the offence punishable underSection 384,387,323,406,504,506/34of the Indian Penal Code, has been taken and, thereafter, the petitioners were proceeded against. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners submits that the cognizance order is absolutely bad and is a non-speaking order and does not reflect as to what are the materials to issue summons against these petitioners. He submits that the requirement ofSection 204Cr.P.C. has not been dealt with in the impugned order. 
 After going through the record, I find that the order is absolutely cryptic and non-speaking and is not in conformity with the judgment passed by this Court in the case of "Amresh Kumar Dhiraj & Ors.- versus- State of Jharkhand & Anr, reported in 2020 (1) JLJR 199". What are the materials against the petitioners to proceed, has also not been mentioned. Thus, the impugned order dated 27.08.2019 is, hereby, set aside. The matter is remitted to the Court below to pass a fresh order in accordance with the provisions of law. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition stands allowed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J) Mukund/-cp.3

case title: Sakina Bibi vs State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 201 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
Coram: Hon'ble Mr. Justice Ananda Sen Through:-Video Conferencing ...... 
 which has been held through video conferencing today at 11.00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 Defects stand ignored for the present. 
 Heard the parties. 
 The petitioners, in this application, have challenged the order dated 04.09.2019, by which charge underSection 302,201/34of the Indian Penal Code, has been framed against them. 
 The petitioners did not file any discharge application. Counsel for the petitioners submits that due to the village politics the petitioners have been made accused in this case. Another ground, which has been submitted, is that only on suspicion the FIR has been lodged that too after six months. On the aforesaid grounds, they challenged the charge. 
 The grounds that have been urged are not at all tenable and cannot be a ground to set aside the charges which has been framed. All these grounds, which the petitioners have taken, need to be substantiated by evidence. 
 Since, there are materials to frame charge against the petitioners, the court proceeded and framed charge underSection 302,201/34IPC against them and the same has been explained, which is apparent from the form of the charge. Thus, I find no merit in this application. Accordingly, the same is hereby dismissed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J) Mukund/-cp.3

case title: Parmeshwar Baidya vs State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
which has been held through video conferencing today at 11.00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 Defects stand ignored for the present. 
 Petitioner, in this application, has prayed to quash the FIR, registered for committing an offence punishable underSections 366Aof the Indian Penal Code. 
 Counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner has got nothing to do in the entire occurrence. He submits that the victim is a major and is married with one Ambika Pandey. He submits that only on the basis of suspicion the father of the victim has lodged this FIR against this petitioner. He submits that since no offence is made out, the instant FIR is liable to be quashed. 
 I have heard counsel for the parties and have gone through the FIR. After going through the FIR, I find that the informant has alleged that his daughter was kidnapped and this petitioner has played an active role in the said occurrence. The averments, made in the FIR, definitely make out an offence. Further, I find that the FIR is of the year 2007, which is sought to be challenged in this application, filed in the year 2018. Further, learned APP has informed this Court that charge sheet in this case was filed way back in the year 2008 itself. 
 Considering the aforesaid fact as well as the fact that prima facie an offence is made out, I am not inclined to entertain this application. Thus, this application stands dismissed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J) Mukund/-cp.3

case title: Raj Kumar Jha vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 406 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 420 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
Other defect(s) as pointed out by the office, if any, is ignored for the present. 
 By way of filing this petition, the petitioner has challenged the order taking cognizance dated 17.3.2009 in connection with Complaint Case No. 269 of 2008 for the offence underSections 420and406IPC, pending in the court of learned SDJM, Rajmahal. 
 The petitioner has challenged the order taking cognizance dated 17.3.2009 in the year 2019 by way of filing this petition, though he was all along aware of this case, which is apparent from the record as well as order impugned. 
 Counsel for the petitioner submits that other co-accused are not appearing in trial and thus the trial has not proceeded, so this application has been moved to quash the order taking cognizance. 
 Considering the fact that the petitioner has challenged the order dated 17.3.2019 after ten years, I am not inclined to interfere with the order taking cognizance dated 17.3.2009. However, the trial court is directed to split up the trial of this petitioner from the other accused persons, as they are not appearing in trial with a direction that the grounds taken by the petitioner in this petition, will be considered by the trial court concerned at appropriate stage. 
 With the aforesaid observation and direction, this petition stands disposed of.

case title: Ashok Kumar Sahu @ Ashok Kumar Sah vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
Cr. Appeal (D.B.) No. 42 of 2016 Ashok Kumar Sahu @ Ashok Kumar Sah, son of Rajendra Prasad Sahu, resident of Qr. No. T2 23/222 UCIL Jadugora colony, P.O. Jadugora, P.S. Jadugora, District- East Singhbhum, Jharkhand. ... ... Appellant Versus The State of Jharkhand ... ... Respondent 
 -------- 
 CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE SHREE CHANDRASHEKHAR : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RATNAKER BHENGRA 
 ------ 
 For the Appellant : Mr. Pramod Kumar, Advocate For the State : Mrs. Priya Shreshtha, Spl. P.P. 
 ------ 
 11/03.09.2020: Hearing of this criminal appeal has been convened and conducted through video conferencing. 
 The appellant has challenged the judgment of conviction undersection 304-B/34of the Indian Penal Code and the order of sentence to R.I. for 10 years, both dated 10th June, 2013, passed by the District & Additional Sessions Judge, Ghatsila in S.T. Case No. 352 of 2011. 
 The appellant has remained in custody all along and on completing custody of seven years, six months and fifteen days, he was released, on completing the sentence of ten years with remission of two years five months and fifteen days. 
 Mrs. Priya Shreshtha, the learned Spl. PP refers to a letter dated 13th July, 2020 issued by the Superintendent, Central Jail, Gaghidih, Jamshedpur in which the period of custody with remission earned by the appellant has been reflected. 
 Mr. Pramod Kumar, the learned counsel for the appellant, on instruction, submits that in view of release of the appellant after serving the sentence, with remission, the appellant is not inclined to press this appeal on merits. 
 Accordingly, Cr. Appeal (DB) No. 42 of 2016 is dismissed as not pressed. 
 (Shree Chandrashekhar, J.) (Ratnaker Bhengra, J.) S.B./Nibha

case title: Purna Chandra Murmu vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 406 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 Heard learned counsel for the petitioner and learned counsel appearing for the State assisted by learned counsel for the O.P. No. 2. 
 Defects, as pointed out by the office, are ignored. The petitioner apprehends his arrest in connection with Complaint Case No. 2177 of 2019, registered for the offence punishable undersections 498A,406,34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 The marriage of the complainant was solemnized with the petitioner on 18.06.2017. It has been alleged that a demand was made for a bullet motor cycle and since the same was not fulfilled she was assaulted and ultimately ousted from her matrimonial house. Allegation has also been leveled about the petitioner solemnizing a second marriage. 
 It has been submitted by the learned counsel for the petitioner that under the Santahl customs polygamy is permissible and, therefore, on such score, the petitioner cannot be proceeded against in the case u/s 498A I.P.C. 
 Learned counsel for the O.P. No. 2 has stated about the specific demand of bullet motorcycle made from the side of petitioner and the subsequent ouster of the complainant from her matrimonial house. 
 On consideration of the aforesaid facts it appears that the petitioner had solemnized a second marriage and there is also allegations regarding the demand and consequent torture upon the complainant on non- fulfillment of the said demand. 
 Regard being had to the aforesaid facts, I am not inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. 
 This application, accordingly, stands rejected. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J.) MM

case title: Sukdeo Singh @ Sukhdeo Singh vs State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 326 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 324 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANANDA SEN. 
 THROUGH : VIDEO CONFERENCING 
 ------ 
 FOR THE PETITIONER(S) : Mr. A.K. Choudhary, Advocate FOR THE STATE : Ms. Vandana Bharti, APP 
 ------ 
 05/03.09.2020 Heard learned counsel for the parties through video conferencing. They have no complain with respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 In this application, petitioners have prayed to quash the order date 31.7.2019. 
 Counsel for the petitioners submits that on the facts of this case no offence under Section 324 and 326 is made out. He submits that Hocky stick weapon was used, thus it cannot be said that the said weapon is a stiffer weapon by which murder can be committed. 
 Be that as it may, since cognizance has been taken and the reference of paragraph no.13 has been given in the impugned order from which court found that by Hocky stick and Rod, the injuries were inflicted, I am not inclined to entertain this application in which order taking cognizance has been challenged. 
 Accordingly, the instant application stands dismissed. 
 However at the time of framing of charge the court below should pass a reasoned order and will conclude as to whether there are ingredients to frame charge underSection 324and326IPC or not. 
 (ANANDA SEN , J) anjali/ C.P 3

case title: Ejaj Ansari vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): (AMITAV K. GUPTA, J.), (Rupees Ten Thousand), (SC/ ST Case No.05 of 2019)
issues: ['Section 376 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMITAV K. GUPTA 
 --------- 
 For the Appellant : Mr. Onkar Nath Tiwary, Advocate Mr. Altamash Khan, Advocate For the State : Mr. Abhay Kr. Tiwari, A.P.P. 
 --------- 
 1. This appeal has been preferred against the order dated 14.01.2020, passed in Misc. Cr. Application No.209 of 2019 (SC/ ST - 05 of 2019) by the court of learned Additional Sessions Judge - 1st, Lohardaga, whereby prayer for bail of the appellant has been rejected. 
 2. The appellant is an accused in connection with SC/ST Case No.05 of 2019, arising out of Kisko Police Station Case No.24 of 2019, registered underSection 376of I.P.C and Section 3(2) (Va) of the Scheduled Caste &Scheduled Tribe (Prevention of Atrocities) Act. 
 3. Having heard learned counsel for the appellant, learned A.P.P and on perusal of the status report, it appears that charge was framed on 19.11.2019 and till date no witnesses have been examined. As per the allegation in the F.I.R, the prosecutrix is aged 24 years and she has stated that for the past two-three years, on threats of killing her and her son, the appellant had established physical relationship with her. On 12.07.2019 he again established physical relationship and when she protested she was assaulted by the appellant. 
 Considering the delay in lodging of the F.I.R., I am inclined to enlarge the appellant on bail, on his furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Additional Sessions Judge - 1st, Lohardaga, in connection with Misc. Cr. Application No.209 of 2019 (SC/ ST Case No.05 of 2019), arising out of Kisko Police Station Case No.24 of 2019. 
 4. In the result, the appeal is, hereby, allowed. 
 (AMITAV K. GUPTA, J.) Chandan/-

case title: Md Munsarif vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through- Video Conferencing 
 ------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Shravan Kumar, Advocate For the State : Mr. A.P. Topno, A.P.P. 
 ------- 
 02/03.09.2020 Heard Mr. Shravan Kumar, learned counsel for the petitioner and Mr. A.P. Topno, learned A.P.P. for the State. 
 Defects as pointed out by the office are ignored. The petitioner has prayed for grant of anticipatory bail, as he is apprehending his arrest in connection with Chatra Sadar P.S. Case No. 325/2016, corresponding to POCSO Case No. 46 of 2016. 
 It has been alleged that the petitioner had tried to drag the informant inside the house. The informant is aged about 11 years. The petitioner is a married person having four children. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has stated that on account of a case having been instituted against the father of the informant in which he was convicted and by way of retaliation the present case has been instituted. 
 It appears that in the 164Cr.P.C. statement of the victim she has supported the occurrence. Moreover the institution of the present case appears to be after expiry of a considerable length of time from the case which was instituted against the father of the informant. 
 In such view of the matter, therefore, I am not inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. This application accordingly stands rejected. 
 (R. Mukhopadhyay, J.) Alok/-

case title: Habil Barla vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through- Video Conferencing 
 ------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Arun Kumar, Advocate For the State : Mr. Prabir Kr. Chatterjee, Spl. P.P. 
 ------- 
 02/03.09.2020 Heard Mr. Arun Kumar, learned counsel for the petitioner and Mr. Prabir Kr. Chatterjee, learned A.P.P. for the State. 
 Defect no. 9(i) as pointed out by the office is ignored. The petitioner has prayed for grant of anticipatory bail, as he is apprehending his arrest in connection with Torpa P.S. Case No. 39/2019. 
 A raid was conducted by the Police and flesh of bovine animals were recovered. 
 The petitioner has been implicated on account of he being the owner of a seized motorcycle found near the place of occurrence which however has been denied by the petitioner. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner does not have any criminal antecedent. 
 Several co-accused persons appear to have been granted anticipatory bail by this Court in A.B.A. No. 8854 of 2019 and A.B.A. No. 9030 of 2019. 
 Regard being had to the aforesaid facts, the petitioner, named above, is directed to surrender before the learned court below within a period of four weeks and on such surrender, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Khunti in connection with Torpa P.S. Case No. 39/2019, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (R. Mukhopadhyay, J.) Alok/-

case title: Amit Giri vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through Video Conferencing 
 --- 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. Anurag Kashyap, Advocate For the State : Mr. Ravi Prakash, Spl.P.P. 
 --- 
 Order No. 02 Dated 03rd September, 2020 Heard the learned counsel for the respective sides. The defects, as pointed out by the office, are ignored. The petitioners apprehend their arrest in connection with Musabani P.S. Case No. 08 of 2020. 
 It has been alleged that the petitioner and other accused persons had assaulted the informant and his family members. The father of the informant had suffered sharp cut injuries which can be attributed to Olanga Giri who had assaulted with an axe. So far as the other accused persons are concerned, the allegations are general and omnibus in nature, save and except the petitioner No. 3, who is said to have assaulted the informant with a danda which caused injuries near his ear. 
 On consideration of the aforesaid facts, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioners. The petitioners accordingly are directed to surrender before the learned court below within four weeks from today and on such surrender, they shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Ten Thousand) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Additional Chief Judicial Magistrate, Ghatshila in connection with Musabani P.S. Case No. 08 of 2020, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY,J.) MK

case title: Abhishek Jaiswal vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
Abhishek Jaiswal ... ... Petitioner Versus The State of Jharkhand ... ... Opposite Party 
 ------- 
 CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through- Video Conferencing 
 ------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. J.N. Upadhyay, Advocate For the State : Mr. Tarun Kumar, A.P.P. 
 ------- 
 02/03.09.2020 Heard Mr. J.N. Upadhyay, learned counsel for the petitioner and Mr. Tarun Kumar, learned A.P.P. for the State. 
 Defect no. 9(i) as pointed out by the office is ignored. The petitioner has prayed for grant of anticipatory bail, as he is apprehending his arrest in connection with Kharswan P.S. Case No. 19/2020. 
 It has been alleged that batteries were stolen from the Airtel Mobile Tower. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner does not have any criminal antecedent. He has further submitted that one battery is said to have been recovered from the scrap shop of the brother of the petitioner which does not match with the battery which had been stolen. 
 It appears that the scrap shop from which a battery was recovered belongs to the brother of the petitioner. 
 On consideration of the aforesaid facts, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. The petitioner accordingly is directed to surrender before the learned court below within a period of four weeks and on such surrender, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned A.C.J.M. at Seraikella in connection with Kharswan P.S. Case No. 19/2020, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (R. Mukhopadhyay, J.) Alok/-

case title: Baldeo Ganjhu vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
Coram: THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. K.S. Nanda, Advocate For the State : Miss. Nehalika Bhagat, A.P.P. 
 -------- 
 02/3-9-2020 Heard the parties. 
 Defects, as pointed out by the office, are ignored. The petitioner apprehends his arrest in connection with Charhi P.S. Case No. 19 of 2020. 
 It has been alleged that the informant was threatened by the petitioner with respect to a land and when the informant was going to Hazaribagh, he was accosted by the petitioner and others and he was forced to sign on cheques. The informant was also threatened and when some persons had arrived, the accused persons had fled away. 
 It appears that the petitioner has filed a complaint case against the informant for dishonor of cheque which has been registered as complaint case no. 250 of 2019. After the legal notice for dishonor of the cheque was received by the informant, he has filed the present complaint case. The petitioner appears to have given a plausible explanation regarding his false implication at the hands of the complainant. 
 Regard being had to the aforesaid facts, the petitioner, named above, is directed to surrender in the court below within a period of four weeks from today and pray for regular bail, and in that event, he will be enlarged on bail, on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- ( Ten thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Sub Divisional Judicial Magistrate, Hazaribagh in connection with Charhi P.S. Case No. 19 of 2020, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J) Rakesh/-

case title: Kundan Saha vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
Coram: THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Raja Ravi Shekhar Singh, Advocate For the State : Mr. Vishwanath Roy, A.P.P. 
 -------- 
 02/3-9-2020 Heard the parties. 
 Defects, as pointed out by the office, are ignored. The petitioner apprehends his arrest in connection with Radhanagar P.S. Case No. 42 of 2020, G.R. No. 117 of 2020. 
 It has been alleged that one Md. Shamim Ansari who was involved in illegally selling lottery tickets was apprehended. The said Md. Shamim Ansari had disclosed that the lottery tickets were given by the petitioner who later collected the money earned. 
 The petitioner seems to have been implicated on the disclosure made by Md. Shamim Ansari and there is no other evidence which would indicate the complicity of the petitioner. 
 Regard being had to the above, the petitioner, named above, is accordingly directed to surrender in the court below within a period of four weeks from today and pray for regular bail, and in that event, he will be enlarged on bail, on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- ( Ten thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st Rajmahal in connection with Radhanagar P.S. Case No. 42 of 2020, G.R. No. 117 of 2020, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J) Rakesh/-

case title: Irshad Ahamd @ Raju vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): ( H. C. Mishra, J.), (Rajesh Kumar, J.)
issues: ['Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE H. C. MISHRA : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RAJESH KUMAR 
 -------- 
 For the Appellant : Mr. Gautam Kumar, Advocate. For the respondent-State : Mr. P.K. Appu, A.P.P. 
 -------- 
 The matter was taken up through Video Conferencing. Learned counsels for the parties had no objection with it and submitted that the audio and video qualities are good. 
 -------- 
 I.A. No. 2081 of 2020. 
 08/ 03.09.2020 Heard learned counsel for the appellant and learned counsel for the State, on the interlocutory application, filed on behalf of the sole appellant for granting bail, during the pendency of this appeal. 
 The appellant has been convicted and sentenced for the offence underSection 302of the Indian Penal Code. 
 The appellant had married the deceased, and had brought her to his house, in spite of the fact that he was already married, and in the same night the deceased was found dead. The cause of death was found to be asphyxia due to smothering. 
 In the facts of the case, we are not inclined to release the appellant Irshad Ahamd @ Raju, on bail. Accordingly, his prayer for bail is rejected. 
 The aforesaid interlocutory application stands dismissed. 
 ( H. C. Mishra, J.) (Rajesh Kumar, J.) Amitesh/-

case title: Manik Saw vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through Video Conferencing 
 --- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Jageshwar Mahto, Advocate For the State : Md. Prabir Chatterjee, Spl.P.P. 
 --- 
 Order No. 02 Dated 3rd September, 2020 Heard the learned counsel for the respective sides. Defect no.9 (i), as pointed out by the office, is ignored. The petitioner apprehends his arrest in connection with Gola Case No.04 of 2020. 
 It has been alleged that a raid was conducted by the police and several accused persons were apprehended who were transporting illegal coal on motorcycles. 
 The apprehended accused persons had disclosed about the petitioner being the purchaser of the theft coal. There does not appear to be any other incriminating material, save and except the disclosure made by the apprehended accused persons, regarding the complicity of the petitioner in committing the offence. 
 On consideration of the aforesaid facts, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. The petitioner is directed to surrender before the learned court below within four weeks from today and on such surrender, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- (Ten Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st Class, Ramgarh in connection with Gola Case No.04 of 2020, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY,J.) Raja/-

 registered underSections 406,420,467,468,471and120Bof the Indian Penal Code in connection with Mosabani P.S. Case No.13 of 2014.

In para - 92, 97, 101 and 102, the statement of the higher officials who conducted the enquiry has been recorded and they have stated about the complicity of the petitioner who had sanctioned 8 loans amounting to Rs.1.51 crore, in favour of family members of accused Deepak Bhattacharya.

case title: Manohar Kumar Sah vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 482 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
Manohar Kumar Sah 
 2. Deb Narayan Sah @ Dev Narayan Sah ... Petitioners Versus The State of Jharkhand ... Opposite Party Coram: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY For the Petitioner : Mr. S.K. Thakur , Adv. 
 Mr. S. K. Thakur, learned counsel for the petitioners personally undertakes to remove the defects pointed out by the Stamp Reporter within two weeks after the lockdown is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking given by learned counsel for the petitioners, the defects pointed out by the Stamp Reporter are ignored for the present. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition has been filed undersection 482Cr.P.C by the petitioners with a prayer for modification of the order dated 11.02.2020, passed in ABA No. 504 of 2020. 
 It is submitted by the learned counsel for the petitioners that vide order dated 11.02.2020, passed in ABA No. 504 of 2020, the petitioners were directed to surrender before the court below within four weeks on depositing ad interim victim compensation of Rs. 20,000/- jointly in favor of the informant but as they could not arrange money and hence, could not surrender within the stipulated time but in the meanwhile, the petitioners have arranged money and prepared the demand draft of the said amount, the photocopy of which is kept at page 9 (Annexure 2) of the brief, which has become invalid. Learned counsel for the petitioners also undertakes to get the said demand draft revalidated and therefore, it is submitted that time to surrender before the court below in terms of the order dated 11.02.2020, passed in ABA No. 504 of 2020 be extended for eight weeks from the date of this order. 
 Considering the facts of the case and the submission of the learned counsel for the petitioner, the prayer for extension of time for the petitioners to surrender in the court below in terms of the order dated 11.02.2020, passed in ABA No. 504 of 2020 is allowed. Hence, the petitioners are directed to surrender before the court below "within eight weeks from the date of this order in terms of the dated 11.02.2020, passed in ABA No. 504 of 2020". 
 The order dated 11.02.2020, passed in ABA No. 504 of 2020 is modified to the aforesaid extent only. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition is disposed of accordingly. 
 (ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY, J.) Smita/-

case title: Md. Hesam Quadri @ Md. Hesam Kadri vs The State Of Jharkhand & Anr
issues: ['Section 482 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
1. Md. Hesam Quadri @ Md. Hesam Kadri 
 2. Md. Akhatar Ansari @ Akhtar Ansari ... Petitioners Versus The State of Jharkhand & Anr. ... Opposite Parties 
 ------ 
 CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY 
 ------ 
 Heard the parties through video conferencing. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition has been filed undersection 482Cr.P.C by the petitioners with a prayer for modification of the order dated 28.03.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6907 of 2018. 
 It is submitted by the learned counsel for the petitioners that in the petition of the anticipatory bail application, due to inadvertence, in paragraph no.1 and in the prayer portion the name of the pending court has been wrongly mentioned as "Court of learned Additional Chief Judicial Magistrate, Bermo at Tenughat" instead of being mentioned as "Court of learned Additional Chief Judicial Magistrate, Bokaro" and accordingly the same has also been reflected in first paragraph and also in operative portion of the said order dated 28.03.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6907 of 2018 and hence the petitioners could not surrender before the court below within the stipulated time in terms of the order dated 28.03.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6907 of 2018. It is therefore submitted that the order dated 28.03.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6907 of 2018 be modified accordingly and the time for the petitioners to surrender before the court below in terms of the order dated 28.03.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6907 of 2018 be extended by six weeks from the date of this order. 
 Considering the aforesaid submission of the learned counsel for the petitioners and the facts of the case, the order dated 28.03.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6907 of 2018 is modified to the extent that "the name of the pending court in the first paragraph and in the operative portion of the order dated 28.03.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6907 of 2018 be read as Court of learned Additional Chief Judicial Magistrate, Bokaro instead of being read as Court of learned Additional Chief Judicial Magistrate, Bermo at Tenughat and the time for the petitioners to surrender before the court below in terms of the order dated 28.03.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6907 of 2018, is extended by six weeks from the date of this order". 
 The order dated 28.03.2019; passed in A.B.A. No. 6907 of 2018 is modified to the aforesaid extent only. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition is disposed of accordingly. 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Sonu-Gunjan/

case title: Anoj Kumar Yadav @ Rakesh Yadav vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMITAV K. GUPTA HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RAJESH KUMAR 
 --------- 
 1. Learned senior counsel for the petitioner does not want to press I.A. No.3349 of 2020, accordingly the same is, hereby, dismissed as not pressed. 
 I.A. No.3380 of 2020 
 1. This interlocutory application has been filed underSection 389(1)of the Code of Criminal Procedure, on behalf of the appellant, for suspending the sentence and admitting him to bail, during the pendency of the present appeal. 
 2. Learned senior counsel for the appellant has submitted that earlier the prayer for bail of the petitioner/ appellant was rejected on the ground that the victim had identified the appellant as one of the abductors. 
 It is argued that P.W.-6, i.e., the Investigating Officer, in his cross-examination, has admitted that the appellant was arrested on 20.09.2014 and the Test Identification Parade was held on 03.12.2014. There is no plausible explanation for the delay in conducting the T.I.P. Moreover, the Investigating Officer has admitted that the brother of the informant has not named the abductor rather the name was disclosed by the members of the Teachers Association. 
 It is submitted that the petitioner is in jail custody from 20.09.2014 till date. 
 3. Learned A.P.P., has opposed and submitted that the prayer for bail of the petitioner was earlier rejected by a speaking order dated 19.11.2020 and no fresh ground is made out for renewal of the prayer for bail. 
 4. Heard. Perused the statement of P.W.-6, i.e., the Investigating Officer. Considering that the T.I.P was conducted after three months of the arrest and the petitioner has remained in custody for nearly six years, we are inclined to suspend the sentence and enlarge the appellant on bail, during the pendency of the appeal, on his furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned District & Additional Sessions Judge 
 - I, Latehar, in connection with S.T. No.10 of 2015 (arising out of Balumath P.S. Case No.110 of 2014), subject to the condition that the appellant shall deposit Rs.10,000/- (Ten thousand), part of the fine amount, in the court below. 
 5. The appellant shall remain present before the Court when the appeal is taken up for hearing, failing which his bail shall be cancelled. 
 6. In the result, I.A. No.3380 of 2020 stands allowed. 
 (Amitav K. Gupta, J.) (Rajesh Kumar, J.) Chandan/-

case title: Ishwar Gope @ Chottan Gope vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 201 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMITAV K. GUPTA HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RAJESH KUMAR 
 --------- 
 For the Appellant :Mr. J.S. Tripathi, Advocate For the State :Ms. Anuradha Sahay, A.P.P 
 --------- 
 06/Dated:04.09.2020 I.A. No.835 of 2020 
 1. This interlocutory application has been filed under Section 389 (1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure for suspension of the sentence and grant of ad-interim bail, to the appellant no.4, namely, Ritu Devi @ Ritu Kumari, during the pendency of the appeal. 
 2. The appellant no.4stands convicted for the offences under Sections 302, 201 read withSection 34of Indian Penal Code and sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for life underSection 302IPC and for four years underSection 201IPC. 
 3. Having heard the learned counsel for the appellant and learned A.P.P and on perusal of the materials on record, it appears that PW-5 the son of the deceased has stated about the involvement of the appellant No.4 alongwith co-accused Pintu Yakav @ Pintu Gope in committing the murder of the deceased whereas PW-13 - the I.O in para-12 of his cross-examination has stated that PW-5 had not stated that the appellant alongwith co- accused Pintu Yadav had throttled his mother (the deceased). As per the post-mortem report and finding of the Doctor, (PW-9) the injuries caused by pressing of fingers was found on the neck of the deceased. No other injuries were found on the body of the deceased. PW-13 has stated that PW-5 was produced before him by the grand parents and he did not have any idea as where PW-5 was for 3 days since the date of occurrence. 
 In the attending facts and circumstances, we are inclined to suspend the sentence and enlarge appellant no.4 on bail, during the pendency of the appeal, on her furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand) with two sureties of like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Additional Sessions-2-Judge-I, Bermo at Tenughat, in connection with S.T. No.207 of 2016 subject to the condition that she shall deposit Rs 5,000/- as part of the fine amount in the court below. 
 5. The appellant no.4, shall remain present before the Court as and when the appeal is taken up for hearing failing which her bail shall be cancelled. 
 6. I.A. No.835 of 2020 stands allowed. 
 (AMITAV K. GUPTA, J.) (RAJESH KUMAR, J.) Tarun, Rohit/-

case title: Santosh Kumar Yadav vs The State Of Jharkhand & Anr
issues: ['Section 482 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY 
 ------ 
 Heard the parties through video conferencing. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition has been filed undersection 482Cr.P.C by the petitioner with a prayer for modification of the order dated 11.11.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 5148 of 2019 by which the petitioner was given the privilege of anticipatory bail on satisfying the learned court below that the petitioner has taken the opposite party no.2 to his house and is keeping and maintaining her with full dignity and honour as his lawful wife. 
 It is next submitted that the petitioner wants and tried to bring the opposite party no.2 but the opposite party no.2 is not ready and willing to resume conjugal life with the petitioner. 
 Learned counsel for the opposite party no.2 submits that the petitioner never went to the house of the father of the opposite party no.2 and has made a false petition before learned trial court that he went much before the schedule date of 15.12.2019 and because of this conduct, the opposite party no.2 does not have any confidence upon the petitioner to resume conjugal life. 
 Considering the aforesaid facts, the order dated 11.11.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 5148 of 2019 is modified to as follows:- 
 "In the event of petitioner's arrest or his surrendering within a period of two months from the date of this order, he shall be released on bail on depositing a demand draft of Rs. 30,000/- as ad interim victim compensation in favour of opposite party no.2-Sima Kumari Yadav @ Sima Kumari Devi and on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned S.D.J.M., Jamtara, in connection with P.C.R. Case No.792 of 2017 with the condition that the petitioner will cooperate with the investigation of the case and appear before the Investigating Officer as and when noticed by him and will furnish his mobile number and a copy of his Aadhar Card in the court below with the undertaking that he will not change his mobile number during the pendency of the case. 
 In case, the petitioner deposits the ad interim victim compensation amount, the court below is directed to issue notice to the opposite party no.2-Sima Kumari Yadav @ Sima Kumari Devi and hand over the said demand draft to her, after proper identification. 
 In case, the said amount is received by the opposite party no.2, the same shall be adjusted with respect to the maintenance in any present or future proceeding between the parties or final settlement between the parties, if and when the same takes place." 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Sonu-Gunjan/

case title: Babloo Verma @ Babloo Prasad Verma vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 482 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
1. Babloo Verma @ Babloo Prasad Verma 
 2. Subodh Kumar @ Raja Verma 
 3. Balmiki Verma @ Balmiki Prasad ... Petitioners Versus The State of Jharkhand ... Opposite Party 
 ------ 
 CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY 
 ------ 
 Heard the parties through video conferencing. This criminal miscellaneous petition has been filed undersection 482Cr.P.C by the petitioners with a prayer for modification of the order dated 07.02.2020, passed in A.B.A. No. 548 of 2020. 
 It is submitted by the learned counsel for the petitioners that the petitioners were directed to surrender before the court below within four weeks in terms of the order dated 07.02.2020, passed in A.B.A. No. 548 of 2020 but due to paucity of money and also because of the COVID -19 Pandemic, the petitioners could not surrender within the stipulated time. It is next submitted that the petitioners have collected money and have jointly prepared a demand draft of Rs.10,000/- in terms of the order dated 07.02.2020, passed in A.B.A. No. 548 of 2020, hence, it is submitted that time to surrender before the court below in terms of the order dated 07.02.2020, passed in A.B.A. No. 548 of 2020 be extended for six weeks from the date of this order. 
 It is further submitted by the learned counsel for the petitioners that the petitioners were first granted anticipatory bail vide order dated 07.02.2020, the operative portion of which reads as under:- 
 "Considering the submissions of learned counsels and the facts and circumstances stated above, I am inclined to grant privileges of anticipatory bail to the petitioners. Accordingly, the petitioners are directed to surrender in the Court of learned Additional Chief Judicial Magistrate, Dhanbad within four weeks from today and in the event of their arrest or surrendering, the petitioners will be enlarged on bail on jointly depositing a demand draft of Rs.10,000/- as ad interim victim compensation without prejudice to their defence in this case drawn in favour of the informant of this case and on furnishing bail bail bond of Rs.25,000/- (Twenty five thousand) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of Additional Chief Judicial Magistrate, Dhanbad in connection with Jharia P.S. Case No. 243 of 2019 with the condition that they will cooperate with the investigation of the case and appear before the investigating officer as and when noticed by him and furnish their mobile number and photocopy of the Aadhar Card with an undertaking that they will not change their mobile number during the pendency of the case and they will not disturb or annoy the informant in any manner during the pendency of the case and subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure" 
 The said order was modified vide order dated 04.03.2020 but in the said order dated 04.03.2020, in the cause title, the name of the three petitioners were not specifically mentioned instead in the cause title, it has been mentioned 'Babloo Verma @ Babloo Prasad Verma & Others.' It is made clear that the order dated 04.03.2020 was modified in respect of the three petitioners whose names are appearing in the cause title of this criminal miscellaneous petition. 
 Considering the aforesaid submission of the learned counsel for the petitioners, the prayer for extension of time for the petitioners to surrender in the court below in terms of the order dated 07.02.2020, passed in A.B.A. No. 548 of 2020 is allowed. Hence, the petitioners are directed to surrender before the court below "within six weeks from the date of this order in terms of the order dated 07.02.2020, passed in A.B.A. No. 548 of 2020". 
 The order dated 07.02.2020, passed in A.B.A. No. 548 of 2020 is modified to the aforesaid extent only. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition is disposed of accordingly. 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Sonu-Gunjan/

case title: Gunnu Karmkar @ Gunu Karmakar vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RAJESH SHANKAR 
 ------ 
 08/04.09.2020 The present criminal appeal is taken up today through Video conferencing. 
 I.A. No.3569 of 2020 The present interlocutory application has been filed on behalf of the appellant underSection 389(1)of the Cr.P.C. for suspension of sentence awarded to the appellant by the learned Trial Court during the pendency of the present appeal. 
 Learned counsel for the appellant submits that similar application of the petitioner was earlier rejected by this Court vide order dated 7th March, 2019 passed in I.A. No.1731 of 2019. The appellant has renewed his prayer for suspension of sentence awarded to him by the learned Trial Court, primarily on the ground that he has already served the half of the sentence of seven years. It is also submitted that learned Trial Court has erroneously convicted the appellant without considering the materials available on record in true perspective. It is a case in which the appellant had allegedly given a single blow with a wooden log on the head of the injured (Mangal Singh). 
 Mr. Ravi Prakash, learned Spl. P.P. though opposes the appellant's application filed underSection 389(1)of the Cr.P.C. on merit, yet he accepts the fact that the appellant has already undergone about three years and six months i.e., half of the sentence awarded to him by the learned Trial Court. 
 Having heard learned counsel for the parties, on perusal of the Lower Court Records and keeping in view that the appellant has already undergone half of the sentence awarded to him by the-2-learned Trial Court, I am inclined to suspend the sentence awarded to him by the learned Additional Sessions Judge-V, Jamshedpur in connection with S.T. No.352 of 2017. 
 Accordingly, the appellant above named, is directed to be released on bail, during the pendency of the present appeal, on furnishing bail bond of Rs.20,000/-(Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of the court of learned Additional Sessions Judge-V, Jamshedpur in connection with S.T. No.352 of 2017. 
 The present interlocutory application stands disposed of. 
 (Rajesh Shankar, J.) Rohit

case title: Mohammad Perwez @ Md. Pravej vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 204 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 190 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
1. Mohammad Perwez @ Md. Pravej 
 2. Shazia Parween @ Rano Praveen 
 3. Md. Sabir 
 4. Yasmeen Bano @ Sony Praveen @ Sony Praveeen 
 5. Nikhat Parween @ Nikhat Praveen @ Nikhat Perween 
 6. Shabana Bano @ Shabnam Praveen .... Petitioner(s). 
 2. The lawyers have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through video conferencing today at 11:00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect of the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 3. Heard the counsel for the parties. 
 4. The petitioner is aggrieved by the order dated 16.3.2019 by which, the learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st Class, Ranchi, has taken cognizance for the offence under Section(s) 143, 341, 323, 448, 504of the Indian Penal Codein connection with Lower Bazar P.S. Case No. 317/2014 (G.R No. 7164/2014). 
 5. Learned counsel for the petitioners submits that the order impugned is cryptic and it does not suggest application of mind. He submit that what are the materials for taking cognizance, has not been reflected in the order impugned and the court below in most mechanical way without application of mind has passed the order impugned. 
 6. Learned A.P.P opposes the prayer of the petitioner but after going through the order impugned, he cannot justify the order impugned. 
 7. After going through the record and the order impugned, I find that the court below has taken cognizance for the offence under Section(s) 143, 341, 323, 448, 504of the Indian Penal Codeagainst the petitioners. What are the materials against the petitioner has not been mentioned in the order impugned. In most mechanical way, the order taking cognizance has been passed. This Court in the case of Amresh Kumar Dhiraj and Ors. Vs. State of Jharkhand and Another, reported in 2020 (1) JLJR 199 (Jhr.) has passed the detailed order discussing the provisions ofSections 190and204Cr.P.C. The impugned order is not in consonance with the aforesaid order. 
 8. In view of the aforesaid facts, I find that order dated 16.3.2019 is not in consonance with the provisions as laid down underSections 190and204Cr.P.C. Thus, order impugned is, hereby, quashed and set aside. 
 9. Accordingly, this petition stands disposed of. 
 10. The learned court below is directed to pass order afresh in accordance with the provisions of law.

case title: Babulal Kumar @ Sonu Kumar @ Babu ... vs The State Of Jharkhand

all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMITAV K. GUPTA HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RAJESH KUMAR 
 --------- 
 For the Appellant :Mr. A.K. Kashyap, Sr. Advocate For the State :Mr. Saket Kumar, A.P.P 
 --------- 
 06/Dated:04.09.2020 
 1. Office to delete the name of Mr. Arun Kr. Pandey and mention the name of Mr. Saket Kumar, as the counsel for the State in the cause list. 
 I.A. No.3774 of 2020 
 1. This interlocutory application has been filed under Section 389 (1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure for suspension of the sentence and grant of ad-interim bail, to the appellant, during the pendency of the appeal. 
 2. The appellant has been convicted for the offence underSection 377of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to undergo R.I for life as well as underSection 4of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offence Act (for short POCSO Act) and to pay a fine of Rs.10,000/-. 
 3. Having heard the learned senior counsel for the appellant and learned A.P.P and on perusal of the materials on record, it appears that PW-5, the Doctor who examined the victim girl did not find any injury in the vagina and the hymen was intact but found small lacerated wound in anal verge skin deep measuring of ¼ cm X ¼ cm. PW-5, the victim has stated that the appellant had opened her pant and assaulted her on the back with something. She has stated that she alongwith her parents are residing as tenant in the house of the appellant. 
 Considering that the appellant is in judicial custody for more than five years, we are inclined to suspend the sentence and enlarge the appellant on bail, during the pendency of the appeal, on his furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand) with two sureties of-2-like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Special Judge (POCSO Act), Palamau at Daltonganj, in connection with POCSO Case No.4 of 2015 on the condition that he shall deposit Rs.10,000/- as part of the fine amount in the court below.

case title: Annu Gupta @ Anuj Kumar Gupta vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RAJESH SHANKAR 
 ------ 
 The petitioner is an accused in a case registered for the offence punishable underSection 302/34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner's prayer for bail was earlier rejected by this Court vide order dated 31st July, 2019 passed in B.A. No. 6485 of 2019. By way of present bail application, the petitioner has renewed his prayer for regular bail, primarily on the ground that co-accused Amar Singh against whom there is an allegation of stabbing the deceased (Vicky Nath), has already been granted regular bail by a co- ordinate Bench of this Court vide order dated 21st August, 2020 passed in B.A. No.5248 of 2020. It is further submitted that most of the prosecution witnesses who have been examined so far in the trial have not supported the case of the prosecution and the informant has been declared hostile by the prosecution. Considering the said fact, the petitioner who is in judicial custody since 18th April, 2019 may be given the privilege of regular bail. 
 The learned A.P.P. opposes the petitioner's prayer for bail. Considering the facts and circumstances of the case and keeping in view that one of the main accused Amar Singh has already been granted bail in the present case, I am inclined to grant regular bail to the petitioner. Accordingly, the petitioner above named, is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs.20,000/-(Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of the court of Additional Sessions Judge-III, Hazaribag in connection with S.T. No.330 of 2019 arising out of Korrah P.S. Case No.61 of 2019 subject to the condition that the petitioner shall co-operate in the trial and shall be present as and when required by the learned trial court, failing which the trial court is at liberty to pass appropriate order against the petitioner in accordance with law. 
 (Rajesh Shankar, J.) Rohit

case title: Saukat Ali vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J.), (Ten Thousand only), (G.R. Case No. 3533 of 2016), (2)
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 414 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 Heard learned counsel for the petitioner and learned counsel appearing for the State. 
 Defect no. 9(i), as pointed out by the office, is ignored. The petitioner apprehends his arrest in connection with Bishnugarh P.S. Case No. 180 of 2016 (G.R. Case No. 3533 of 2016), registered for the offences punishable undersections 414&34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 It has been alleged that four motor cycles illegally loaded with coals were seized. The petitioner has been implicated as an accused on account of the fact that he is the registered owner of a seized motorcycle bearing registration JH09D5427. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the motorcycle, in question, had already been sold to one Phulendra Kumar on 14.08.2012 for which a sale letter has been referred. Learned counsel further submits that in a similar circumstance one of the co-accused namely Sharda Devi has been granted anticipatory bail by this Court in A.B.A. No. 8576 of 2019. It has also been submitted that the petitioner does not have any criminal antecedent. 
 Learned A.P.P. has opposed the prayer for anticipatory bail of the petitioner. 
 Prima facie, from the sale letter it appears that the petitioner has already sold the motorcycle to one Phulendra Kumar. However, nothing has been brought on record to indicate that the ownership has also been transferred in favour of Phulendra Kumar. If what has been stated by the learned counsel for the petitioner is true in such circumstances the investigating officer should also investigate the role of Phulendra Kumar if actually he appears to be the owner of the vehicle pursuant to the sale of the same in his favour by the petitioner. 
 Be that as it may, on consideration of the fact that the similarly situated co-accused has been granted anticipatory bail by this Court, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. Accordingly, the petitioner, above named, is directed to surrender in the court below within a period of four weeks from today and pray for regular bail, and in that event, he will be enlarged on bail, on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Ten Thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st Class, Hazaribagh, in connection with Bishnugarh P.S. Case No. 180 of 2016 (G.R. Case No. 3533 of 2016), subject to the conditions as laid down undersection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J.) MM

case title: Maheswar Pahariya @ Maheshwar ... vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): (Shree Chandrashekhar, J.), (Rupess Ten Thousand), (S.T Case No. 213 of 2017)
issues: ['Section 366 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
(Through V.C.) CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE SHREE CHANDRASHEKHAR For the Petitioner : Mr. Swami Nath Prasad Rai, Advocate For the State : Mrs. Ruby Pandey, APP 
 ------------------ 
 Order No. 03/ Dated: 04th September, 2020 Mr. Swami Nath Prasad Rai, the learned counsel appears for the petitioner and states that charges were framed against the accused vide order dated 03.04.2018 however till now no witness has been examined by the prosecution. 
 This is second attempt by the petitioner in connection to Mirzachouki P.S. Case No.34 of 2016 corresponding to G.R. Case No. 321 of 2016. 
 Mrs. Ruby Pandey, the learned APP opposing the prayer for bail submits that sufficient evidence has been collected against the accused and now since charge has been framed against him, the presumption of innocence of accused has been substantially diluted. The learned APP further submits that period of custody normally is not a ground to enlarge an accused on bail particularly in serious offences likesection 366(A) of the Indian Penal Code. 
 The allegation against the petitioner is that he has taken the victim girl to Sonipat and sold her to another person who forced her to work as maid servant. The offence undersection 366(A) of the Indian Penal Code is punishable with imprisonment which may extend to ten years and with fine. The expression "may extend to" reflects the legislative intendment that maximum punishment shall2be awarded only in exceptional cases and not as a matter of routine. The learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the trial in Sessions Trial No.213 of 2017 has not progressed at all and till now no witness has been examined by the prosecution. It is really a very serious matter that in about 2½ years since charges were framed in the Sessions Trial vide order dated 03.04.2018, the prosecution has failed to examine a single witness. The petitioner is in custody since 07.03.2017 and the memo of evidence furnished to learned APP does not disclose any reason why in S.T Case No. 213 of 2017 any witness has not been examined by the prosecution. 
 Having regard to the aforesaid facts and circumstances, the petitioner above-named is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupess Ten Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of the learned Additional Sessions Judge-1st, Sahibganj in connection to Mirzachouki P.S. Case No. 34 of 2016 (S.T Case No. 213 of 2017). 
 B.A. No.11716 of 2019 is allowed. 
 (Shree Chandrashekhar, J.) RKM/-

case title: Sanjeev Kumar vs The State Of Jharkhand & Another
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through Video Conferencing 
 --- 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. D. K. Prasad, Advocate For the State : Mr. Shailesh Kr. Sinha, A.P.P. For the O.P. No. 2 : Mr. Md. Zaid Ahmed, Advocate 
 --- 
 Order No. 02 Dated 04th September, 2020 Heard the learned counsel for the respective sides. So far as the defects No. 5(e) and 9(iii) are concerned, if the same are existing, learned counsel for the petitioners is directed to remove the same once the situation normalizes. As regards the rest defects, as pointed out by the office, are concerned, the same are ignored. 
 The petitioners apprehend their arrest in connection with Sakchi P.S. Case No. 181 of 2019. 
 A development agreement was entered into between the petitioners and the informant. The petitioners were to handover two units in the second floor along with car parking apart from Rs. 16 Lakhs. It has further been alleged that the petitioners did not abide by the terms and conditions of the agreement. 
 Mr. Md. Zaid Ahmed, learned counsel for the opposite party No. 2 submits that the petitioners had not adhered to the conditions as instead of Rs. 16 Lakhs, Rs. 8 Lakhs had been paid to the informant. It has further been stated that so far as handing over of two units in the second floor is concerned, that was also not adhered to. 
 It appears that the agreement which was entered into between the petitioners and the opposite party No. 2 had an arbitration clause, which however was never invoked by the opposite party No. 2. It further appears that the case has been instituted after almost 9 years. The case of the petitioners as stated by Mr. D. K. Prasad, learned counsel for the petitioners is that further payment was stopped since on measurement, the area of land was found to be less than what had been recorded in the agreement. 
 The entire gamut of allegation therefore points to a civil dispute and in such circumstances, therefore, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioners. The petitioners accordingly are directed to surrender before the learned court below within four weeks from today and on such surrender, they shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Ten Thousand) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate at Jamshedpur in connection with Sakchi P.S. Case No. 181 of 2019, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY,J.) MK

case title: Ajay Singh @ Ajay Kumar Singh vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 204 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
1. Ajay Singh @ Ajay Kumar Singh 
 2. Sanjay Singh @ Sanjay Kumar Singh 
 3. Dhananjay Singh .... Petitioner(s). 
 The lawyers have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through video conferencing today at 11:00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect of the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 Heard the counsel for the parties. 
 The petitioners in this petition, have challenged the order dated 13.8.2018, by which, cognizance of the offence punishable under Section(s) 323, 341, 504, 506 and 34of the Indian Penal Code, has been taken by the learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st Class, Palamau, in connection with Nawdiha Bazar P.S. Case No. 28/2018 (G.R. No. 1501 of 2018) and thereafter the petitioners have been summoned. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners submits that the order impugned is cryptic and is a non speaking order and does not reflect any subjective satisfaction as to what are the material to take cognizance against he petitioners. He submits that the requirement ofSection 204Cr.P.C has not been dealt with in the impugned order. 
 Learned A.P.P opposes the prayer of the petitioner but after going through the order impugned, he cannot justify the order impugned. 
 After going through the record and the order impugned, I find that the order is absolutely cryptic and non-speaking and is not in conformity with the judgment passed by this Court in the case of Amresh Kumar Dhiraj and Ors. Vs. State of Jharkhand and Another, reported in 2020 (1) JLJR 199 (Jhr.). What are the materials against the petitioners to proceed, has also not been mentioned. Thus, the impugned order dated 13.8.2018 is, hereby, set aside. The matter is remitted to he court below to pass a fresh order in accordance with law. 
 Accordingly, this petition stands allowed.

case title: Jamuna Prasad @ Yamuna Prasad vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
Jamuna Prasad @ Yamuna Prasad ... ... Petitioner Versus The State of Jharkhand ... ... Opposite Party 
 ------- 
 CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through- Video Conferencing 
 ------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. S.S. Choudhary, Advocate For the State : Mr. V.K. Vasishtha, A.P.P. For the Informant. : Mr. Sanjay Kr. Pandey, No. 2, Advocate 
 ------- 
 02/04.09.2020 Heard Mr. S.S. Choudhary, learned counsel for the petitioner and Mr. V.K. Vasishtha, learned A.P.P. for the State assisted by Mr. Sanjay Kr. Pandey, No. 2, learned counsel appearing for the informant. 
 Defects as pointed out by the office are ignored. The petitioner has prayed for grant of anticipatory bail, as he is apprehending his arrest in connection with Ichak P.S. Case No. 203/2019. 
 It has been alleged that the informant and the petitioner had agreed to the sale and purchase of a land for which Rs. 3,92,500/- was paid by the informant. It has further been alleged that the petitioner did not get the land registered in the name of the informant nor the money which was taken returned back. 
 It appears that the petitioner has also filed a complaint case against the complainant for illegally procuring the agreement dated 11.12.2008 in order to grab the land of the petitioner. 
 It has been stated by Mr. S.S. Choudhary, learned counsel for the petitioner that the informant is an accused in a case of theft of government records in Ichak P.S. Case No. 212/2019. 
 Mr. Sanjay Kr. Pandey, No. 2, learned counsel for the informant has stated that neither the land was registered in favour of the informant nor the amount of Rs. 3,92,500/- returned back to the informant. He has further submitted-2-that a spate of cases have been filed by the petitioner against the informant. In such circumstances learned counsel submits that the present application is liable to be rejected. 
 The entire gamut of allegations as is revealed from above would indicate a civil dispute as it is with respect to the specific performance of a contract. 
 On consideration of the aforesaid facts, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. The petitioner accordingly is directed to surrender before the learned court below within a period of four weeks and on such surrender, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned S.D.J.M. at Hazaribag in connection with Ichak P.S. Case No. 203/2019, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (R. Mukhopadhyay, J.) Alok/-

case title: Mamta Singh vs Ramayan Singh Bisen
all_text:
Manish Kumar, learned counsel for the opposite party-husband are present through Video Conferencing. 
 Petitioner seeks transfer of Original Suit No. 13 of 2019 instituted before learned Principal Judge, Family Court, Daltonganj by the husband/opposite party herein for dissolution of marriage on grounds of cruelty and desertion under Section 13(1)(i-a)(i-b) ofHindu Marriage Act, 1955 to the Court of learned Principal Judge, Family Court, Dhanbad. Parties have solemnized marriage on 18th June 2011 as per Hindu Rites and Customs and they were blessed with a baby girl on 20 th August, 2012. Thereafter a case was instituted for restitution of conjugal rights which was decided ex parte. Petitioner has complained that because of approach of husband she has been residing at her parental house at Dhanbad with her minor daughter aged about 7 years. She is unable to attend and contest the divorce suit at Daltonganj with no sources of income. Daltonganj is separated by distance of more than 300 kilometres which is very onerous for her to cover alone with a minor child and stay overnight there before undertaking the return journey. Therefore, she has prayed for transfer of the case to Dhanbad. 
 Learned counsel for the opposite party has opposed the prayer. However, during course of arguments on the previous date i.e., 28th August, 2020, learned counsel for the opposite party proposed that the suit may be transferred to Bokaro instead of Dhanbad where both parties can appear in a tension free and independent environment. 
 Today, on instructions, learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner has no objection if the suit is transferred to the Family Court, Bokaro. 
 I have considered the submission of learned counsel for the parties, in the light of the facts and circumstances pleaded and the consensus between the parties on transfer of the Original Suit No. 13 of 2019. to the Family Court at Bokaro. It is true that petitioner may have had serious inconvenience in attending the suit at Daltonganj which is separated by a considerable distance and petitioner having no independent sources of income to maintain herself and her minor daughter. 
 In those circumstances and in view of consensus between the parties, it is deemed appropriate that the Original Suit No. 13 of 2019 be transferred from the Court of learned Principal Judge, Family Court, Daltonganj to the Court of learned Principal Judge, Family Court, Bokaro. 
 Let the records of Original Suit No. 13 of 2019 be transmitted to learned Family Court, Bokaro without any delay. 
 The instant petition stands disposed of. 
 Interim order dated 25.11.2019 stands vacated. 
 (Aparesh Kumar Singh, J) jk/

case title: Birsa Lohra vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 397 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 392 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MRS. JUSTICE ANUBHA RAWAT CHOUDHARY 
 --- 
 For the Petitioner : Mrs. Ritu Kumar, Advocate For the Opp. Party : Mr. Sardhu Mahto, A.P.P. 
 Through Video Conferencing 3/04.09.2020 
 1. Heard Mrs. Ritu Kumar, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the petitioner. 
 2. Heard Mr. Sardhu Mahto, learned A.P.P. appearing on behalf of the opposite party-State. 
 3. Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner is in custody since 16.11.2018 in connection with Dasam Fall P.S. Case No. 22 of 2018, corresponding to S.T. No. 182 of 2019, for the alleged offence registered underSections 392/397of the Indian Penal Code, now said to be pending in the court of learned A.J.C. XVI, Ranchi. 
 4. Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that bail application of the petitioner was earlier rejected by this court vide order dated 22.07.2019 in B.A. No. 5754 of 2019 with observation that the petitioner may renew his prayer for bail after six months. She further submits that considering the Covid-19 situation, there is no progress in the trial. Learned counsel submits that considering the fact and circumstances of this case, the petitioner may be enlarged on bail. 
 5. Learned counsel appearing on behalf of the opposite party opposes the prayer for bail and submits that the bail application was rejected on merits considering the seriousness of allegation coupled with the confessional statement leading2to recovery. 
 6. After hearing the learned counsel for the parties and considering the facts and circumstances of this case and the observation made by this court vide order dated 22.07.2019 and also the fact that there is no much progress in the trial under the Covid-19 situation, this court is inclined to enlarge the petitioner on bail on his furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rs. Twenty five thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned A.J.C. XVI, Ranchi in connection with Dasam Fall P.S. Case No. 22 of 2018, corresponding to S.T. No. 182 of 2019 on the following conditions: 
 (i) One of the bailor would be the father of the petitioner. 
 (ii) The petitioner will give his mobile number before the learned court below which he will not change during the pendency of the case before the learned court below without prior permission of the court. 
 (iii) The petitioner shall fully co-operate with the proceedings before the learned court below. 
 7. The instant bail application is allowed with the aforesaid conditions. 
 8. Let this order be communicated to the court concerned through FAX/e-mail. 
 (Anubha Rawat Choudhary, J.) Binit/

case title: Md. Shamim Khan @ Guddu vs State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
Md. Shamim Khan @ Guddu ... ... Petitioner Versus 
 1. State of Jharkhand 
 2. Sarwari Khatoon ... ... Opposite Parties 
 ------- 
 CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through- Video Conferencing 
 ------- 
 For the O.P. No. 2. : Ms. Amrita Sinha, Advocate 
 ------- 
 06/04.09.2020 Heard Mr. Sahil, learned counsel for the petitioner and Ms. Mahua Palit, learned A.P.P. for the State as well as Ms. Amrita Sinha, learned counsel appearing for the opposite party no. 2. 
 The petitioner has prayed for grant of anticipatory bail, as he is apprehending his arrest in connection with Complaint Case No. 497/2019. 
 The marriage of the complainant was solemnized with the petitioner on 07.10.2017. It has been alleged that there was a demand of Rs. 1,00,000/- and a motorcycle and on non- fulfillment of which she was subjected to torture. On account of the torture meted out to the complainant she was taken away by her parents where she had given birth to a child. 
 It has been stated by the learned counsel for the petitioner that the complainant had preferred an application u/s 125Cr.P.C. in which pursuant to the order of the learned Family Court the petitioner is diligently paying an amount of Rs. 3,500/- per month to the complainant. It has further been stated that the main allegation appears to have been levelled against the mother-in-law of the complainant namely Mobina Khatoon. 
 Ms. Amrita Sinha, learned counsel appearing for the opposite party no. 2 submits that a mediation is going on and it is on the verge of being concluded. She has further stated that a positive outcome is expected in the mediation which is going on. 
 On a perusal of the complaint petition the allegation appears to be general and omnibus in nature so far as the-2-petitioner is concerned who happens to be the husband of the complainant. The primary allegations are centered around the mother-in-law Mobina Khatoon. The petitioner also appears to have shown his bonafide in regularly making payment of maintenance in terms of the direction of the learned Family Court to the complainant. Moreover, as stated by Ms. Amrita Sinha, learned counsel for the opposite party no. 2, there is a possibility of a positive outcome in the mediation which is going on. 
 On consideration of the aforesaid facts, therefore, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. The petitioner accordingly is directed to surrender before the learned court below within a period of four weeks and on such surrender, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Sub-Divisional Judicial Magistrate, Koderma in connection with Complaint Case No. 497/2019, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 It is further made clear that the petitioner shall cooperate in the mediation process which as stated above is on the verge of being concluded. 
 Ms. Amrita Sinha, learned counsel who is appearing in the present case on behalf of the opposite party no. 2 through JHALSA has submitted the Vakalatnama through e-mail to this Court. 
 Let the same be kept on the record. 
 Ms. Sinha, is further directed that once she receives the original Vakalatnama she shall file the same in the drop box kept for such purpose. 
 (R. Mukhopadhyay, J.) Alok/-

CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY

 Order No.03 Dated- 04.09.2020 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Mr. Atma Ram Chaudhary, learned counsel for the petitioner personally undertake to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking of the learned counsel for the petitioner, the defects pointed out by the stamp reporter are ignored for the present. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition has been filed undersection 482Cr.P.C by the petitioner with a prayer for modification of the order dated 05.11.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6950 of 2019. 
 It is submitted by the learned counsel for the petitioner that the petitioner was directed to surrender before the court below within eight weeks but due to paucity of money, he could not surrender within the stipulated time. It is next submitted that the petitioner has collected money and has prepared a demand draft of Rs.2500/- each drawn in favour of victims in terms of the order dated 05.11.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6950 of 2019 hence, it is submitted that time to surrender before the court below in terms of the order dated 05.11.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6950 of 2019 be extended for six weeks from the date of this order. 
 Considering the aforesaid submission of the learned counsel for the petitioner, the prayer for extension of time for the petitioner to surrender in the court below in terms of the order dated 05.11.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6950 of 2019 is allowed. Hence, the petitioner is directed to surrender before the court below "within six weeks from the date of this order in terms of the order dated 05.11.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6950 of 2019". 
 The order dated 05.11.2019, passed in A.B.A. No. 6950 of 2019 is modified to the aforesaid extent only. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition is disposed of accordingly. 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Sonu-Gunjan/
