 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Chainpur P.S. Case No. 278/2019, for the offence registered underSections 379,385,34I.P.C. andSections 33/34of Forest Act. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that earlier for the same occurrence, a complaint case was filed by the Forest Officer vide Complaint Case No.2508/2019 in which this petitioner has been granted bail vide order dated 16.03.2020 passed in B.A. No.1122/2020 but for the same occurrence, another F.I.R. has been lodged, which is the present F.I.R. as Chaipur P.S. Case No. 278/2019 registered underSections 379,385,34I.P.C. andSections 33/44of Indian Forest Act against four named accused persons with-2-regard to illegal cutting of 156 Khair tree. It is alleged that a false document of agreement has been shown to justify the act, though petitioner has been granted bail for the same occurrence, but again, he is in custody since 12.05.2020, as such, he may be enlarged on bail, as he is a labourer earning daily wages for his livelihood. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. Prabir Kr. Chatterjee, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that since the complaint case was not filed before this Court and in the present petition, it is very difficult to ascertain that both cases relate to the same occurrence or not. 
 Learned counsel for the State has placed reliance upon the seizure list, which is at page no.14 of the petition, which shows dated 31.10.2019. 
 Learned counsel for the State has further submitted that learned court below has also considered this aspect while passing the impugned order stating therein at the second last para of impugned order that petitioner was granted bail in another case, so the submission of the learned counsel for the petitioner is not well founded, as such, both the cases have not amalgamated together, otherwise the court below have amalgamated both the cases together. 
 Considering the rival submission of the parties, learned counsel for the petitioner is directed to bring on record the Complaint Case No.2508/2019 and the order granting bail. 
 In the meantime, State counsel is also directed to file detail counter affidavit and the S.O.P. issued in this regard by the Department. 
 State counsel may take assistance from Principal Secretary Forest and Environment, Government of Jharkhand as well as D.F.O., Palamu in this regard. The counter affidavit must be filed with a period of four weeks. 
 Put up this case after four weeks. 
 Let a copy of order be communicated to the Principal Secretary, Forest and Environment, Government of Jhakhand as well as D.F.O., Palamu. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Garhwa P.S. Case No.755 of 2013, for the offence registered underSections 341,323,386and392IPC. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that instant case has been lodged against two named accused persons namely Raj Khan and Imran Ansari and two unknown persons. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has not named in the FIR nor he has any knowledge about the pendency of the case, as such, he could not surrender earlier and he has been remanded in this case on 02.03.2020. Charge has already been framed in the year, 2020. Offences are triable by a Magistrate, as such, petitioner may be enlarged on bail. Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that co-accused-2-Imran Ansari has already been granted bail by co-ordinate Bench of this Court vide order dated 08.08.2014 in B.A. No.5781 of 2014. Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that petitioner has absconded since 2013 to 2020 and he has as many as 25 criminal antecedents i.e. five cases of murder, six cases of attempt to murder, four cases of rangdari and three cases of preparation of dacoity, as such, petitioner may not be enlarged on bail. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties, learned State counsel is directed to file counter-affidavit within four weeks regarding nature of all 25 cases and stage of trial.

 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

 The appellant has been convicted and sentenced for the offence underSection 306of the Indian Penal Code on the allegation that due to the atrocities committed by him, his wife had committed suicide alongwith two children.

Accordingly, the appellant, named above, is directed to be released on bail, during the pendency of this appeal, on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- (ten thousand), with two sureties of the like amount each, to the satisfaction of the learned Additional Sessions Judge, XII, Hazaribag, in connection with S.T. No. 282 of 2017. 
 The Trial Court below however, before issuing the release order shall satisfy itself that the appellant has remained in custody for more than three years, and if this submission is found to be incorrect, the release order shall not be issued and the matter shall be reported to this Court. 
 The aforesaid interlocutory application stands allowed with the direction as above. 
 (H.C. Mishra, J.) (Rajesh Kumar, J.) D.S./

case title: Vijay Singh @ Vijay Kumar Singh vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 420 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANANDA SEN THROUGH VIDEO CONFERENCING 
 ---- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. P.K. Mukhopadhyay, Advocate For the State: A.P.P. 
 For the O.P. No.2 : None 
 ---- 
 5/ 08.09.2020 The lawyers have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through Video Conferencing today at 11.00 a.m. They have no complain in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 2. The defects stand ignored for the present. 
 3. With the consent of the parties, the matter is taken up for hearing on merits. 
 4. Petitioner has challenged the order dated 29.05.2019 passed by the Judicial Magistrate 1st Class, Dhanbad in C.P. Case No.617 of 2018, whereby cognizance has been taken for the offence underSection 420of the Indian Penal Code and thereafter petitioner has been summoned. 
 5. Counsel for the petitioner submits that since the agreement itself is void, petitioner cannot be proceeded underSection 420of the Indian Penal Code. He submits that the petitioner is a retired police official and he has been falsely implicated in this case. 
 6. I have heard the counsel for the petitioner and the counsel for the State and have gone through the records. 
 7. From the First Information Report, I find that there is an allegation that the petitioner has entered into an agreement with the informant and has taken money to provide job to the informant in a Public Sector Undertaking, i.e., Heavy Engineering Corporation (HEC), Ranchi. On such false insurance of the petitioner, money was given. Thereafter the accused persons did not provide any job. This entire transaction ie. alluring the informant and taking payment of Rs.1,02,800/- on the pretext of providing job in Public Sector is itself an offence. So far as contention of the petitioner that the agreement of providing job itself is void, for which no criminal case can be instituted, cannot-: 2 :-be a ground to quash the criminal proceeding. It is a settled principle of law that a void contract is not enforceable, but there is no prohibition in initiating criminal proceeding against the person, who has allured unemployed person and cheated them on the pretext of providing job. 8 Thus, I find no merit in this criminal miscellaneous petition. This criminal miscellaneous petition is, accordingly, dismissed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J.) Kumar/Cp-03

case title: Manoj Kumar @ Manoj Kumar Das vs The State Of Jharkhand

all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conference) 
 ----- 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that though there are defect nos.9(i) to 9(iv) in the bail application as pointed out by the stamp reporter but he has filed an undertaking that he shall remove the defects within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard as it is a regular bail in which petitioner is in custody since 01.06.2020. Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the bail application on merit but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defects within 30 days after the physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defects. Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Mukesh Kumar and learned counsel for the State, Mr. Saket Kumar. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Topchanchi P.S. Case No.19 of 2018, for the offence registered underSections 409/420/467/468/471/34IPC. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that it is alleged in the FIR that till October, 2017, a sum of Rs.6,71,960/- has been collected from the consumers but the same has not been deposited in the account of Jharkhand Electricity Board (Jharkhand Urja Vikash Limited). Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that petitioner is low salary paid man. The co-accused namely, Bunty Kumar Sinha and Raj Narayan Prasad (Retired Assistant Electrical Engineer) have been granted bail by co-ordinate Bench of this Court on payment of Rs.2,00,000/- but since this petitioner is low paid salary man and was not involved in such offence, as such, he could not deposit the said amount and he is in custody since 01.06.2020, as such, he may be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has-2-submitted that this petitioner being the switch operator has never disconnected the electrical supply of the consumers whose bills have not been deposited, as such, he is also in league with the other accused persons. 
 Learned counsel for the State has further submitted that in the part of the FIR, the signature of the petitioner has been mentioned as M.K., which shows that he has collected money but has not deposited in the account of the Electricity Board, as such, petitioner may not be enlarged on regular bail. 
 Heard, learned counsel for the parties and perused the materials brought on record and looking into the facts stated before this Court, this Court deems it proper to add Principal Secretary, Energy-cum-Chief Managing Director, (Jharkhand Urja Vikash Limited) for his response with regard to the steps taken for collection of defalcated money from the erring officer, the involvement of the petitioner and standard operation procedure to stop such type of crimes by the employee of the Jharkhand Electricity Board. In the meantime, petitioner (Manoj Kumar @ Manoj Kumar Das), is directed to be released on Provisional Bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Dhanbad in connection with Topchanchi P.S. Case No.19 of 2018, on the following conditions:- 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be deponent/parivikar of the present case namely, Raju Das, S/o C. Das, R/o Bandh Gora Site, P.O. & P.S.- Chas, District- Bokaro (Jharkhand), who has furnished photocopy of his UID Card bearing No.3732 1309 3746 before this Court in the bail application. 
 Office is directed to send photo copy of the UID Card bearing No. 3732 1309 3746 of deponent along with this order to the court below so as to verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Another bailor shall be close relative of the petitioner i.e. father/mother/son/sister/brother. 
 (iii) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioner only after his medical check- up. 
 (iv) The Civil Surgeon, Dhanbad is directed to medically examine the petitioner at the time of his release and if require, petitioner shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, he shall be released forthwith, if not wanted in any other case. 
 (v) Petitioner shall also comply with all the guidelines issued by the-3-Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as the country is passing through Pandemic of Covid-19. 
 Put up this case on 06.11.2020, if the physical court starts. Office is directed to implead Principal Secretary, Energy-cum-Chief Managing Director, (Jharkhand Urja Vikash Limited) as Opposite Party No.2. In the meantime, O.P. No.2 shall file the standard procedure before this Court. 
 The State counsel shall also file counter-affidavit. Office is directed to send a copy of this order through FAX to the Principal Secretary, Energy-cum-Chief Managing Director, (Jharkhand Urja Vikash Limited) Jharkhand, Ranchi. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

issues: ['Section 82 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 83 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANANDA SEN THROUGH VIDEO CONFERENCING 
 ---- 
 which has been held through Video Conferencing today at 11.00 a.m. They have no complain in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 2. This case was listed/supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board of the Registrar General for passing an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the Office. 
 3. Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their Clerks in the Court, this Court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 4. The defects stand ignored for the present. 
 5. With the consent of the parties, the matter is taken up for hearing on merits. 
 6. Petitioners have challenged the order dated 11.12.2018 passed by the Sessions Judge-cum-Special Judge, Chatra in Bashistha Nagar Police Station Case No.09 of 2018, by which processes underSection 82of the Code of Criminal Procedure have been issued. They also challenge the order dated 29.03.2019, by which attachment order in terms ofSection 83of the Code of Criminal Procedure has been issued. 
 7. While going through the impugned orders, I find that just because anticipatory bail application of 7 other co-accused persons got dismissed, the Court below had reasons to believe that these petitioners had also got knowledge about this case and they have absconded. This ground mentioned by the Court below is not tenable. The order is absolutely cryptic. There is nothing on record to suggest that police ever went to arrest these petitioners or ever notices were served upon them. Subjective satisfaction, which is-: 2 :-mandatory in terms ofSection 82of the Code of Criminal Procedure is not reflected in the order issuing processes underSection 82of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Thus, the order dated 11.12.2018 passed in Bashistha Nagar Police Station Case No.09 of 2018, by which processes underSection 82of the Code of Criminal Procedure have been issued is hereby set aside. 
 8. So far as the attachment order in terms ofSection 83of the Code of Criminal procedure is concerned, I find that the same is also not in accordance with law. More so, when the order issuing processes underSection 82of the Code of Criminal Procedure has been set aside, the order dated 29.03.2019 issuing attachment order in terms ofSection 83of the Code of Criminal Procedure being a consequential order is also, hereby, set aside. 
 9. The matter is remanded to the Court below to pass fresh orders in accordance with law. 
 10. This criminal miscellaneous petition, accordingly, stands allowed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J.) Kumar/Cp-03

case title: Arjun Prasad vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 376 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMITAV K. GUPTA 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner :Mr. Anurag Kashyap, Advocate For the State :Mr. Vibuti Sahay, APP 
 --------- 
 04/Dated: 08.09.2020 
 1. Office to delete the name of Ram Prakash Singh and mention the name of Mr. Vibuti Sahay, as learned counsel for the State in the cause list. 
 2. This revision is directed against the order dated 09.06.2020, passed in Cr. Appeal (Juvenile) No.19 of 2020, whereby the learned Additional Sessions Judge-I-Cum- Children Court, Garhwa, has rejected the prayer for bail of the petitioner-juvenile, in connection with Ramkanda P.S. Case No.105 of 2019. 
 2. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that perusal of FIR reveals that the victim girl is aged 16 years and the petitioner is aged about 17 years. It is submitted that no doubt offence underSection 376IPC is heinous but it appears from the recital in the FIR that the petitioner and the victim were having love affairs. It is argued that at the time of occurrence the petitioner was residing at Daltonganj alongwith his elder brother and pursuing his studies. It is alleged in the FIR that, on life threats given by the petitioner, the victim took a bus and travelled from Garhwa to Daltonganj where the petitioner met her at the Bus stand and took her to his room. He put vermilion on her forehead and established physical relationship which continued for over a month. It is submitted that since the petitioner refused to marry the victim, therefore the instant case was lodged with the intention to pressurize the petitioner to marry her. 
 3. Learned APP has opposed and submitted in the impugned order it is mentioned that the petitioner requires psychological treatment. It is contended that it is mentioned in the impugned order that there is lack of proper care by the parents and keeping him in observation home is essential for betterment of the mental condition of-2-the petitioner. 
 On query by the Court as to how the victim had reached Daltonganj learned APP could not provide any satisfactory answer. 
 4. Heard. It is evident from the FIR that the petitioner and the victim knew each other. The victim had travelled from Garhwa to Daltonganj to meet the petitioner. Physical relationship between the petitioner and the victim continued for more than a month and the FIR was lodged after an inordinate delay. In the attending facts and circumstances, the petitioner is directed to be released on bail on his furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/-(Rupees Ten thousand only) with two sureties of like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Principal Magistrate, Juvenile Justice Board, Garhwa, in connection with Ramkanda P.S. Case No.105 of 2019 on the condition that one of the bailor shall be the parent or guardian of the petitioner, who shall execute a bond and an undertaking (i) to ensure proper supervision and good behaviour of the petitioner, (ii) he/she shall ensure to take proper care that the petitioner does not come in contact with any anti-social element, and (iii) shall produce the petitioner before the Probation Officer as and when directed by the Board. The Probation Officer shall submit the supervision report to the Board for needful. 
 In case of any adverse remark the Board is at liberty to pass necessary order in accordance with the provisions of the J.J. Act, 2015. The petitioner shall be present before the Board till the conclusion of the enquiry. 
 5. With the aforesaid direction, the revision is, hereby, allowed. 
 (AMITAV K. GUPTA, J.) Tarun/-

case title: Beena Devi @ Beena Tiwari vs State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 204 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 387 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 385 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
which has been held through video conferencing today at 11.00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 This case was listed/ supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board of the Registrar General for passing an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the office. 
 Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their Clerks in the Court, this court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 The defects stand ignored for the present. 
 With the consent of the parties, the matter is taken up for hearing on merits. 
 Heard the parties. 
 The petitioner is challenging the order dated 03.11.2018, passed in G.R. No. 3555 of 2017, by which the petitioner has been summoned after taking cognizance of the offence punishable underSections 385,387/34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners submits that the cognizance order is absolutely bad and is a non-speaking order and does not reflect any subjective satisfaction as to what are the materials to take cognizance against these petitioners. He submits that the requirement ofSection 204Cr.P.C. has not been dealt with in the impugned order. 
 After going through the record, I find that the order is absolutely cryptic and non-speaking and is not in conformity with the judgment passed by this Court in the case of "Amresh Kumar Dhiraj & Ors.- versus- State of Jharkhand & Anr, reported in 2020 (1) JLJR 199". What are the materials against the petitioner to proceed, has also not been mentioned. Thus, the impugned order dated 03.11.2018, passed by the C.J.M. Hazaribagh, in G.R. No. 3555 of 2017, is, hereby, set aside. The matter is remitted to the Court below to pass a fresh order in accordance with the provisions of law. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition stands allowed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J) Mukund/-cp.3

case title: Dinesh Kumar Jaiswal vs The State Of Jharkhand Through The ...
all_text:
The present writ petition is taken up today through Video conferencing. 
 At the request of the learned counsel for the petitioner, the defects as pointed out by the office are ignored. 
 The present writ petition has been filed for issuance of direction upon the respondents to consider the objection raised by the petitioner against the amount of compensation fixed for the land appertaining to Plot No. 3105/3 under Khata No. 44, Touzi No. 28, Village-Kulgo, measuring an area of 0.0700 acre consisting a residential house which is being acquired for widening of NH-2 under the provisions ofNational Highways Act, 1956. 
 2. The learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner received notice dated 12.12.2019 underSection 3-G(4)of the National Highways Act, 1956 [wrongly mentioned in the notice asSection 37(2)of the Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act, 2013] calling upon him to submit relevant documents for receiving the compensation awarded for acquisition of the land pertaining to Plot No. 3105/3 under Khata No. 44, measuring an area of 0.0700 acre relating to award no. 37. The grievance of the petitioner is that though in the earlier notice dated 13.02.2017 (Annexure-2 to the writ2petition), it has been mentioned that a house is situated over the said land i.e., Plot No. 3105/3, but the compensation has been fixed on rate applicable for agricultural land. Aggrieved by non-payment of the compensation at residential rate, the petitioner along with other villagers made representation before the respondent no. 4 - the Project Director, National Highway Authority of India, Kandra, Govindpur, Dhanbad, however, no action was taken by the respondent no. 4 on the said representation. 
 3. The learned counsel appearing on behalf of the respondent-State of Jharkhand and the respondent-NHAI submit that if the petitioner is aggrieved with the quantum of compensation, he may file a suitable application before the competent authority under theNational Highways Act, 1956 i.e., the respondent no. 3 - the District Land Acquisition Officer-cum-Competent Authority, Giridih so that the said competent authority may take appropriate action in terms withSection 3-G(5)of the National Highways Act, 1956. 
 4. Having heard the learned counsel for the parties and keeping in view the nature of prayer made in the present writ petition, without entering into the merit of the claim of the petitioner, he is given liberty to prefer an application before the respondent no. 3 raising objection on the point of quantum of compensation. On receipt of the said application, the respondent no. 3 shall take appropriate steps to refer the matter to the arbitrator in terms with the provisions ofSection 3-G(5)of the Act, 1956 within a period of four weeks from the date of receipt of the application. 
 5. The writ petition is accordingly disposed of with aforesaid liberty and direction. 
 (Rajesh Shankar, J.) Manish

case title: Chhatu Mandal @ Chhathu Mandal vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 326 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 324 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMITAV K. GUPTA 
 --------- 
 1. The petitioner stands convicted for the offence underSection 323,324and326of the Indian Penal Code by the learned Sub Divisional Judicial Magistrate, Deoghar, in connection with G.R. No.478 of 2011 (T.R. No.312 of 2019) which has been affirmed by learned Additional Sessions Judge-II, Deoghar, in Criminal Appeal No.53 of 2019. 
 2. Learned senior counsel has submitted that perusal of FIR will reveal that the dispute had arisen between the parties due to installation of a hand-pump on the land which was claimed jointly by the parties. It is alleged that the informant with an axe causing injuries on her hand. 
 It is submitted that both the parties are agnates and during the pendency of the revision, on intervention of friends and well wishers both the parties agreed to resolve the dispute for which panchayati was held. In the panchayati the parties have arrived at amicable settlement. 
 3. Mr. S.K. Deo, learned counsel on behalf of O.P. No.2 has not controverted the submission and consented that both the parties are agnates and they have amicably settled the dispute and filed the joint compromise petitioner being I.A. No.1004 of 2020. . 
 4. Heard. Considering that both the parties have amicably settled the dispute in the panchayati, as per Annexure-1, and O.P. No.2 does not want to proceed further with prosecution of the case and considering the-2-ingredients to constitute the offence underSection 326of the Indian Penal Code, is not made out as per the injury report. In the attending facts and circumstances, in the interest of justice the compromise is accepted, accordingly the revision is, hereby, allowed and the judgment dated 27.11.2019, passed by learned Additional Sessions Judge-II, Deoghar, in Criminal Appeal No.53 of 2019 is, hereby, set aside in view of the compromise. 
 5. In the result the petitioner is exempted from surrendering in the court below in terms of Rule 159 of the High Court of Jharkhand Rules 2001, accordingly I.A. No.1004 of 2020 & I.A. No. 1812 of 2020 stand allowed. 
 (AMITAV K. GUPTA, J.) Tarun/-

case title: Ajit Tirkey vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 387 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 401 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMITAV K. GUPTA 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. K. S. Nanda, Advocate For the State : Mrs. Vandana Bharti, A.P.P 
 --------- 
 1. This interlocutory application has been filed underSection 401of the Code of Criminal Procedure for suspension of the sentence and grant of ad-interim bail, to the petitioners, during the pendency of the revision. 
 2. The petitioners have been convicted for the offence underSection 387read withSection 34of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to undergo R.I. of 4 years and to pay a fine of Rs.10,000/- in default thereof, to further undergo S.I. for 6 months vide judgment dated 24.04.2019, passed by the court of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Simdega in G.R. Case No.534 of 2015/ T.R. No.23 of 2019, which has been affirmed by the Principal Sessions Judge, Simdega in Criminal Appeal Nos.25 of 2019 & 37 of 2019. 
 3. Having heard learned counsel for the petitioners and learned A.P.P, and on perusal of materials on record, it appears that the petitioners name has transpired on the confessional statement of co-accused Karishma Kumari @ Reshma Kumari, who had demanded ransom from the informant on the point of pistol. Co-accused had confessed about involvement of the petitioners in the crime and arms and motorcycle were recovered from the possession of the petitioners, and a separate case was lodged against the petitioners under theArms Act. The petitioners have been granted bail by a co-ordinate Bench of this Court vide order-2-dated 18.12.2019 in Cr. Appeal (S.J.) No.943 of 2019, preferred against the judgment of conviction under theArms Act. 
 Considering, the fact, that the petitioners have remained in custody for nearly two years, i.e., half of the sentence inflicted by the court below, accordingly I am inclined to suspend the sentence and enlarge the petitioners on bail, during the pendency of the revision, on their furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Simdega in G.R. Case No.534 of 2015, corresponding to T.R. No.23 of 2019, subject to the condition that the petitioners shall deposit the fine amount of Rs.10,000/- (Ten thousand) in the court below. 
 4. I.A. No.3239 of 2020 stands allowed. 
 Cr. Revision No.1560 of 2019 
 1. This revision shall be heard. 
 2. Admit. 
 3. The lower court record has already been received. 
 4. Office to list this revision under the appropriate heading in seriatim, as per age. 
 (AMITAV K. GUPTA, J.) Chandan

case title: Gulzar Ansari vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 164 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 366 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 506 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mrs. Vani Kumari, Advocate. 
 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mrs. Vani Kumari. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that defect nos. 9 (i) to (iv), as per Stamp Reporting dated 26.08.2020, have not been removed, which he undertakes to remove within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard, as it is a regular bail application of the petitioner, who is in custody since 29.02.2020. 
 Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the instant bail application on merits, but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defect(s) within 30 days after physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defect(s). 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Narkopi P.S. Case No. 06/2020 (POCSO Case No. 55/2020) for the offence registered underSections 366,366A,34,506I.P.C. but after investigation, the police has only charge-sheeted the petitioner underSections 366/376(2)I.P.C. and Sections 4(2) & 6(1) of POCSO Act. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner, Mrs. Vani Kumari has submitted that the victim is aged about 15 years, but her statement has been recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C. and from perusal of Annexure-2 particularly, paragraph-3, it is apparent that victim has affair with this petitioner for last three years, which was not acceptable to the guardian of the victim, as such, they fled away-2-from the house on 25.02.2020, thereafter the victim along with petitioner surrendered before the court below. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has alleged that the victim, in her statement recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C., has not alleged a single word against the petitioner with regard to any offence, as such, petitioner, who is in custody since 29.02.2020, may be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. Tarun Kumar, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that police has already submitted charge-sheet, as such, petitioner may not be enlarged on bail. 
 Considering the rival submissions of learned counsel for the parties and also considering the statement of the victim recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C., the petitioner is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each in connection with Narkopi P.S. Case No. 06/2020 (POCSO Case No. 55/2020) to the satisfaction of learned Additional Judicial Commissioner-IV- cum-Special Judge, POCSO, Ranchi on the following conditions: 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be the deponent / parivikar of the present case namely, Bhola Sahu, son of Shri Sukhlal Sahu, resident of Piska More, Ratu, P.O. - Ratu, P.S. - Ratu, District - Ranchi, Jharkhand, who has furnished photocopy of his UID Card bearing number 6623 2107 9799 before this Court in the bail application. 
 Office is directed to send the photocopy of UID Card bearing no. 6623 2107 9799 of deponent alongwith this order to the court below so as to verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Another bailor shall be close relative of the petitioner i.e. father / mother / son / wife / brother. 
 (iii) Petitioner shall appear before the learned trial court, after physical court starts, on each and every date till conclusion of the trial, failing which the trial court shall cancel the bail bonds of the petitioner. 
 (iv) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioner only after his medical check-up. 
 (v) The Civil Surgeon, Ranchi is directed to medically examine the petitioner at the time of his release and if he is infected with corona virus, he shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, he shall be released forthwith, if not wanted in any other case. 
 (vi) The petitioner shall follow all the guidelines issued by the Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as presently Country is passing through pandemic of Covid-19. 
 Accordingly, the instant bail application is allowed. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Ranjeet Kumar vs The State Of Jharkhand

all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conference) 
 ----- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Kamdeo Pandey, Advocate For the State : Mr. S.K. Tiwari, Spl.P.P. for Cyber Crime 
 ----- 
 02/Dated: 08/09/2020: 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that though there are defect nos.4, 5(e) and 9(i) to 9(iv) in the bail application as pointed out by the stamp reporter but he has filed an undertaking that he shall remove the defects within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard, as it is a regular bail application of the petitioner and petitioner is in custody since 21.11.2019. 
 Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the bail application on merits but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defects within 30 days after the physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defects. Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Kamdeo Pandey and learned counsel for the State, Mr. S.K. Tiwari. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Giridih Cyber P.S. Case No.31 of 2019 dated 14.10.2019, for the offence registered underSections 419,420,467,468,471and120BIPC and read withSection 66(D)I.T. Act. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner is innocent and has falsely been implicated in this case. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that petitioner is in custody since 21.11.2019. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that petitioner has no criminal antecedent regarding cyber offence rather some cases have been lodged against him by his agnates, as such, he may be enlarged on bail. Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has-2-submitted that co-accused, Ankush Raj @ Aditya Raj has also preferred A.B.A. No.2741 of 2020, as such, it would be proper if all the bail applications are heard together. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties, learned State counsel is directed to file a detail counter-affidavit within four weeks with regard to material collected regarding transfer of money and material recovered from the petitioner as well as criminal antecedent of the petitioner. Officer is directed to place this case after four weeks along with all the analogous bail applications arising out of Giridih Cyber P.S. Case No.31 of 2019. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Harihar Mahto @ Harihar Ram vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 27 in Arms Act', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 307 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 326 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Abhishek Kr. Dubey, Advocate. For the State : Mr. Shiv Shankar Kumar, A.P.P. 
 --------- 
 02/Dated: 08/09/2020 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Abhishek Kumar Dubey. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that defect nos. 9 (i) to (iii), as per Stamp Reporting dated 26.08.2020, have not been removed, which he undertakes to remove within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard, as it is a regular bail application of the petitioner who is in custody since 18.03.2020. 
 Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the instant bail application on merits, but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defect(s) within 30 days after physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defect(s). 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Khunti P.S. Case No. 85/2019, for the offence registered underSections 326,307/34I.P.C. andSection 27Arms Act, subsequently,Section 302I.P.C. has been added. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that F.I.R. has been lodged against five unknown persons on the basis of suspicion and on the criminal antecedent of the petitioner. This petitioner has been remanded in this case from another case on 18.03.2020, though in another case he is in custody since 30.10.2019, as such, petitioner may be enlarged on bail, as even though the informant has alleged that he can identify the accused after seeing, but Test-2-Identification Parade has not been conducted by the Investigating Officer. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. Shiv Shankar Kumar, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that F.I.R. has been lodged against unknown persons, as such, it is necessary to call for the case diary and postmortem report. 
 Learned counsel for the State has further submitted that this petitioner has also criminal antecedent, as such, his criminal antecedent may be called for. 
 Considering the rival submission of the parties, State Counsel is directed to file detail counter affidavit within a period of four weeks regarding material collected during investigation with regard to involvement of the petitioner, post-mortem report as well as criminal antecedent report of the petitioner. 
 Office is directed to place this case after four weeks with analogous case including B.A. No. 4857/2020 arising out of Khunti P.S. Case No. 85/2019. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Rajesh Jha vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conference) 
 ----- 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that though there is defect no.9(i) in the bail application as pointed out by the stamp reporter but he has filed an undertaking that he shall remove the defect within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard, as it is a regular bail application of the petitioner and petitioner is in custody since 16.05.2020. Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the bail application on merit but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defect within 30 days after the physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defect. Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. S.P. Roy and learned counsel for the State, Mr. P.K. Verma. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Dumka (M) P.S. Case No.62 of 2020, for the offence registered under Sections 25 (1-B)a/26/35 of theArms Act. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that police has recovered three live cartridges, one tester and one knife from co-accused, Gulshan Srivastava @ Jhunnu and on the basis of confessional statement co-accused namely, Rajesh Jha (petitioner), Sudip Singh @ Babu Singh and Abhinav Ojha @ Sonu, have been made accused in this case though there is no recovery from the possession of the petitioner. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that though there are three cases against the petitioner and petitioner is in custody since 16.05.2020, as such, he may be allowed on bail on some strict conditions. Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that petitioner has several criminal antecedents, as such, petitioner may not be enlarged on regular bail. 
 After hearing, learned counsel for the parties and perusing the materials brought on record and looking into the merits of the case, as such, petitioner (Rajesh Jha), is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Dumka in connection with Dumka (M) P.S. Case No.62 of 2020 on the following conditions:- 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be deponent/parivikar of the present case namely, Chanchal Jha, S/o Upendra Prasad Jha, R/o Village- Maharo, P.O.- Maharo & P.S.- Jama, District- Dumka, who has furnished photocopy of his UID Card bearing No.6692 5774 0732 before this Court in the bail application. 
 Office is directed to send photo copy of the UID Card bearing No. 6692 5774 0732 of deponent along with this order to the court below so as to verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Another bailor shall be close relative of the petitioner i.e. father/mother/son/wife/brother. 
 (iii) Petitioner shall appear before the learned trial court on each and every date till conclusion of the trial, failing which the learned trial court shall cancel the bail bonds of the petitioner. 
 (iv) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioner only after his medical check- up. 
 (v) The Civil Surgeon, Dumka is directed to medically examine the petitioner at the time of his release and if require, petitioner shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, he shall be released forthwith, if not wanted in any other case. 
 (vi) Petitioner shall also comply with all the guidelines issued by the Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as the country is passing through Pandemic of Covid-19. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Ashok Singh vs State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 471 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 468 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 406 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
which has been held through video conferencing today at 11.00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 This case was listed/ supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board of the Registrar General for passing an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the office. 
 Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their Clerks in the Court, this court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 The defects stand ignored for the present. 
 With the consent of the parties, the matter is taken up for hearing on merits. 
 Heard the parties. 
 The petitioner, in this application, has challenged the order 23.08.2019, by which cognizance of the offence punishable underSection 468,471of the Indian Penal Code, has been taken and, thereafter, the petitioner has been summoned. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the though charge sheet was submitted underSection 406IPC, but the court had taken cognizance for the offence underSection 468,471IPC, without assigning any reason as to why he is differing with the charge sheet. He further submits that even the order taking cognizance is absolutely bad as the same is cryptic and does not reflect any ground. He further submits that the order is non-speaking, which cannot be allowed to sustained. 
 After going through the record, I find that the order is absolutely cryptic and non-speaking and is not in conformity with the judgment passed by this Court in the case of "Amresh Kumar Dhiraj & Ors.- versus- State of Jharkhand & Anr, reported in 2020 (1) JLJR 199". What are the materials against the petitioner to proceed, has also not been mentioned. Thus, the impugned order dated 23.08.2019, passed by the C.J.M., Ramgarh, in G.R. No. 843 of 2018, is, hereby, set aside. The matter is remitted to the Court below to pass a fresh order in accordance with the provisions of law. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition stands allowed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J) Mukund/-cp.3

case title: Kanahai Yadav vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 120 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 471 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 468 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 467 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 420 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Ashok Kumar Singh, Advocate. 
 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Ashok Kr. Singh. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that defect nos. 9 (i) to (vi), as per Stamp Reporting dated 26.08.2020, have not been removed, which he undertakes to remove within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard, as it is a regular bail application of the petitioner, who is in custody since 01.06.2020. 
 Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the instant bail application on merits, but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defect(s) within 30 days after the physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defect(s). 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner Kanahai Yadav along with Binod Kumar Singh, Headmaster of the School, have been made accused in connection with Hunterganj P.S. Case No. 96/2018 for the offence registered underSections 409,420,467,468,471,120(B)I.P.C. as this petitioner was Ex-President of Gram Shiksha Samitee of Upgraded Middle School, Nawadih Kobna. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that from financial year 2010 till 2014, sum of Rs. 10,92,400/- has been granted and withdrawn for construction of school building and toilet, but at the time of lodging the F.I.R., it is alleged that work of Rs. 6,13,357/- has been done and a sum of Rs. 4,79,043/- has been defalcated. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that Headmaster of the School namely, Binod Kumar Singh has already deposited the aforesaid amount and has been granted bail in terms of order dated 13.11.2019 passed in A.B.A. No. 7010/2019. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that since no money has been defalcated by the petitioner as such, he did not deposit any money, rather he is in custody since 01.06.2020, as such, he may be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mrs. Lily Sahay, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail, but has submitted that report submitted by District Education Officer-cum-District Programme Officer dated 03.06.2020 with regard to two financial years i.e. of 2010-11 and 2011-12 shows that work has been completed. 
 Considering the rival submission of the parties, since the work has already been completed and defalcated money has already been deposited by co-accused Binod Kumar Singh, the petitioner is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each in connection with Hunterganj P.S. Case No. 96/2018 to the satisfaction of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Chatra on the following conditions: 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be the deponent / parivikar of the present case namely, Sandip Kumar, son of Kanhai Yadav, resident of Village - Belgada Nawadih, P.O. - Kedli Kalan, P.S. - Hunterganj, District - Chatra, who has furnished his photocopy of UID Card bearing number 2256 0369 5463 before this Court in the bail application. 
 Office is directed to send the photocopy of UID Card bearing no. 2256 0369 5463 of deponent alongwith this order to the court below so as to verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Another bailor shall be close relative of the petitioner i.e. father / mother / son / wife / brother. 
 (iii) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioner only after his medical check-up. 
 (iv) The Civil Surgeon, Chatra is directed to medically examine the petitioner at the time of his release and if he is infected with corona virus, he shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, he shall be released forthwith, if not wanted in any other case. 
 (v) The petitioner shall follow all the guidelines issued by the Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as presently Country is passing through pandemic of Covid-19. 
 Accordingly, the instant bail application is allowed. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Ashutosh Kabra vs State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 506 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 504 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 341 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 313 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
Coram: Hon'ble Mr. Justice Ananda Sen Through:-Video Conferencing ...... 
 which has been held through video conferencing today at 11.00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 This case was listed/ supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board of the Registrar General for passing an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the office. 
 Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their Clerks in the Court, this court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 The defects stand ignored for the present. 
 With the consent of the parties, the matter is taken up for hearing on merits. 
 Heard the parties. 
 The petitioner is challenging FIR being Adityapur P.S. Case No. 78 of 2019, registered for the offence punishable underSections 376,313,341,323,504,506IPC and also the order dated 14.11.2019, by which cognizance has been taken against the petitioner and he has been summoned. 
 Counsel for the petitioner submits that the informant of this case is habitual in filing this type of cases. By referring Annexure-4, he submits that similar type of allegation has been leveled against another person in another case. 
 I have gone through the FIR, which suggests that there was some relationship between this petitioner and the informant and on the false pretext of marriage physical relationship was established. Thereafter, there is allegation of abortion of pregnancy. Further, there is allegation that the informant was assaulted and driven out. 
 Aforesaid allegation definitely makes out an offence, which needs investigation. Further, from perusal of the FIR, cognizable offence is made out. Whether the allegation is true or false cannot be seen at this stage. Further, whether the informant had filed similar nature of cases against other persons can be appreciated by the court at the time of framing of charge and not at this stage where cognizance has to be taken. Cognizance is taken basing on the allegation leveled in the FIR and the materials which surfaced during investigation. 
 In this case, since there are materials to take cognizance of offence, the court has taken cognizance and summoned this petitioner. I find no illegality in the impugned order. Thus, this application stands dismissed. 
 However, liberty is given to the petitioner to raise all the points, which have been raised in this application at the time of framing charge, which would be considered by the court below without being prejudiced by this order. 
 (Ananda Sen, J) Mukund/-cp.3

 appellant. Respondent has not entered appearance till date despite service of notice and adjournment granted on 2nd March 2020.

case title: Raj Sharma @ Raj Kumar Sharma vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 164 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
Raj Sharma @ Raj Kumar Sharma ... ... Petitioner Versus The State of Jharkhand ... ... Opposite Party 
 --- 
 CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 --- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Pratiush Lala, Advocate For the Opposite Party : Mr. Tapas Roy, A.P.P. For the Informant : Mr. Suraj Singh, Advocate 
 --- 
 2/08.09.2020 Heard the parties. 
 Defect no. 9 (i) & (ii) as pointed out by the office are ignored. The petitioner is an accused in connection with Dhanbad Mahila P.S. Case No. 8 of 2020. 
 It has been alleged that the petitioner had established physical relationship with the informant on gun point. Suspecting illicit relationship between the informant and the petitioner, the husband of the informant consumed kerosene oil. 
 It appears that an undertaking was given by the petitioner in Mahila P. S. Case No. which has been brought on record and the same reveals that the relationship between the informant and her husband was not cordial. The dispute stems from the conversation made by the informant with another person of the locality as would appear from the undertaking and the same also hints at a relationship with the petitioner. In the statement underSection 164Cr.P.C. of the victim, it has been stated that the petitioner had twice established physical relationship with her. 
 Mr. Suraj Singh, learned counsel for the informant while going through the FIR has stated that physical relationship was forcibly established by the petitioner on the threat of committing the murder of her child and husband. 
 However, as stated above, the undertaking does reveal a hint of relationship between the petitioner and the informant and such fact circumstances does implore this court to grant bail to the petitioner. 
 Regard being had to the above, the petitioner above named is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Ten Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each, to the satisfaction of learned Judicial Magistrate 1st class, Dhanbad in connection with Dhanbad Mahila P.S. Case No. 8 of 2020. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J) R. Shekhar Cp 3

case title: Sandeep Kumar Pandit vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 376 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
which has been held through Video Conferencing today at 11.00 a.m. They have no complain in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 The defects stand ignored for the present. 
 Petitioner has challenged the first information report being Jasidih Police Station Case No.468 of 2019, which has been registered underSection 376of the Indian Penal Code. 
 Counsel for the petitioner, by referring to Annexure 3, submits that the petitioner was appearing in an examination at Dhanbad for the post of Constable. He submits that the examination was held on 01.09.2019 from 09.30 a.m. to 12.30 p.m. in the first sitting and from 03.00 p.m. to 04.00 p.m. in the second sitting. He submits that it is not expected from the petitioner to have committed this offence and the allegation is absolutely improbable. He submits that due to previous enmity between the parties, the instant case has been lodged. 
 I have gone through the first information. The allegations in the first information report suggests that at night on 01.09.2019, this petitioner has committed rape upon the petitioner. The allegation in the first information report, definitely, makes out a cognizable offence, which needs investigation. Whether the petitioner was present at the place of occurrence or not is a matter of investigation. His alibi cannot be looked at the stage of quashing of FIR. I want to only highlight that the time of examination on 01.09.2019 is from 09.30 a.m. till 04.00 p.m. whereas the time of occurrence is at night about 01.00 a.m. Since the entire allegation needs a proper investigation including-: 2 :-the defence of the petitioner, I am not inclined to quash the first information report as an offence is made out. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition, accordingly, stands dismissed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J.) Kumar/Cp-03

 I.A. No. 4144 of 2020 06/ 08.09.2020. Learned counsel for the appellants submits that he shall not be pressing this Interlocutory Application. 
 This Interlocutory Application is accordingly, dismissed as not pressed. I.A. No. 4145 of 2020 Heard learned counsel for the appellants and the learned counsel for the State on the Interlocutory Application filed by the appellants for granting bail during the pendency of this appeal. 
 The appellants have been convicted and sentenced for the offences underSections 302/34of the Indian Penal Code andSection 27of the Arms Act alongwith the other co-accused.

case title: Raj Kishore Mondal vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 197 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MRS. JUSTICE ANUBHA RAWAT CHOUDHARY 
 --- 
 For the Petitioner : Ms. Satakshi, Amicus For the Opp. Party : Mr. Santosh Shukla, A.P.P. 
 16/08.09.2020 
 1. Heard Ms. Satakshi, learned Amicus appearing on behalf of the petitioner. 
 2. Heard Mr. Santosh Shukla, learned A.P.P. appearing on behalf of the State. 
 3. Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the impugned judgments are perverse in view of the fact that sanction for prosecution has not been obtained underSection 197of the Cr. P.C. and in absence of sanction for prosecution, the impugned judgment of conviction and sentence against the petitioner cannot be sustained. She further submits that ultimately the amount was recovered by the department and the petitioner has paid defalcation amount of Rs. 1,08,000/- as reflecting from the impugned order of the learned lower appellate court. The learned counsel has relied upon the judgment passed by the Hon'ble Supreme Court reported in (2000) 8 SCC 500 as well as judgment reported in 1966 Crl. Law Journal 179(S.C.). She submits that these judgments are on the point of sanction for prosecution. 
 4. Learned counsel appearing on behalf of the opposite party submits that he does not have records of the present case and prays for adjournment. He further submits that he shall arrange the brief from the learned counsel for the petitioner. 
 5. Post this case on 09.09.2020 for argument of the opposite party-State. 
 (Anubha Rawat Choudhary, J.) Binit/

case title: Suku Sk vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 376 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Lakhan Chandra Roy, Advocate. For the State : Mr. Bishambhar Shastri, A.P.P. 
 --------- 
 02/Dated: 08/09/2020 Heard, learned counsel Mr. Lakhan Chandra Roy on the instruction of learned counsel for the petitioner Mr. Bejoy Kr. Pandey. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that defect nos. 9 (i) to (iv), as per Stamp Reporting dated 26.08.2020, have not been removed, which he undertakes to remove within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard, as it is a regular bail application of the petitioner who is in custody since 11.04.2020. 
 Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the instant bail application on merits, but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defect(s) within 30 days after physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defect(s). 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Pakur (Malpahari) P.S. Case No. 61/2020 (Spl. POCSO No. 12/2020) for the offence registered underSection 376I.P.C. read with Sections 4, 6 of POCSO Act. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner is in custody since 11.04.2020 and there is no medical report with regard to sexual assault upon the victim and there is delay in lodging the F.I.R. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. Bishambhar Shastri, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail and has-2-submitted that it is a sexual offence against a minor girl, as such, counter affidavit is required. 
 Considering the rival submission of the parties, State Counsel is directed to file detail counter affidavit within a period of four weeks. 
 Put up this case after four weeks. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/
