case title: Kirti Kumar Singh vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 409 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 407 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 420 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conference) 
 ----- 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that though there are defect nos.9(i) to 9(iii) in the bail application as pointed out by the stamp reporter but he has filed an undertaking that he shall remove the defects within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard as it is a regular bail application in which petitioner is in custody since 21.04.2020. 
 Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the bail application on merits but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defects within 30 days after the physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defects. Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Nilesh Kumar, learned counsel for the State, Mr. Rajesh Kumar as well as learned counsel for the informant, Mr. Rajesh Mahtha. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Bokaro Thermal P.S. Case No.01 of 2020, corresponding to G.R. Case No.13 of 2020, for the offence registered underSections 420,407,409/34IPC. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that as per the FIR this petitioner has taken 14 trucks of coal, worth of Rs.14,31,972/- and the transportation cost was Rs.5,11,672/-, which was not paid to the informant though an agreement has been executed between the informant and mediator, Ramchandra Mahto, who assured that if money is not given he shall pay the same. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that there is business dispute between the parties for which the case has been instituted-2-after a long delay without taking recourse by the informant to recover the said amount. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has thus submitted that petitioner who is in custody since 21.04.2020, may be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State assisted by the learned counsel for the informant have opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that petitioner has criminal antecedent of similar nature, as such, he is not entitled for regular bail as even after taken coal he has not paid amount and to that effect an agreement has been executed between the parties. 
 After hearing, learned counsel for the parties and perusing the materials brought on record and looking into the dispute between the parties, the cost of the coal, the freight charge, this Court is inclined to grant Bail to the petitioner. Accordingly, petitioner (Kirti Kumar Singh), is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned A.C.J.M., Bermo at Tenughat in connection with Bokaro Thermal P.S. Case No.01 of 2020, corresponding to G.R. Case No.13 of 2020 on the following conditions:- 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be deponent/parivikar of the present case namely, A.K. Singh, S/o P.N. Singh, R/o Village- Namkum, P.O.& P.S.- Namkum, District- Ranchi, who has furnished photocopy of his UID Card bearing No.7713 5333 1328 before this Court in the bail application. 
 Office is directed to send photo copy of the UID Card bearing No. 7713 5333 1328 of deponent along with this order to the court below so as to verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Another bailor shall be father/mother/son/sister/brother. 
 (iii) Learned trial court is directed to refer the matter before the Mediation Centre, Tenughat, Bokaro so as to have amicable settlement between the parties. 
 (iv) Petitioner shall appear before the learned trial court on each and every date till conclusion of the trial. 
 (v) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioner only after his medical check- up. 
 (vi) The Civil Surgeon, Ranchi is directed to medically examine the petitioner at the time of his release and if require, petitioner shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, he shall be released forthwith, if not-3-wanted in any other case. 
 (vii) Petitioner shall also comply with all the guidelines issued by the Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as the country is passing through Pandemic of Covid-19.

 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defects. Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Anil Kumar Ganjhu, and learned counsel for the State, Mr. Rajesh Kumar. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Maranghada P.S. Case No.06 of 2018, corresponding to G.R. Case No.294 of 2018 and S.T. No.63 of 2020 registered underSections 302/34IPC and underSection 27Arms Act. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner is not named in the FIR nor there is any eye witness to the occurrence rather on the basis of the confessional statement of the petitioner in another case ofArms Actand petitioner has been remanded in the present case. Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that petitioner has been implicated in this case showing as active member of MCC. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that petitioner is in custody since 26.09.2019, as such, he may be enlarged on regular bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has-2-submitted that since FIR has been lodged against unknown and petitioner has criminal antecedent, as such, State may be directed to file counter-affidavit. Considering the rival submissions of the parties, learned State counsel is directed to file a detail counter-affidavit within four weeks with regard to criminal antecedent of the petitioner and with regard to the material collected against the petitioner. 
 List this case after four weeks. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Anil Hansda @ Kole vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 164 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 366 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conference) 
 ----- 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that though there is defect no.5(e) in the bail application as pointed out by the stamp reporter but he has filed an undertaking that he shall remove the defect within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard as it is a regular bail application in which petitioner is in custody since 04.07.2020. Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the bail application on merits but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defect within 30 days after the physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defect. Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Sudhansu Kr. Deo, learned counsel for the State, Mr. Vijoy Kr. Sinha. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Budhai P.S. Case No.39 of 2020, corresponding to POCSO Case No.34 of 2020, for the offence registered underSections 366(A),323,34IPC & Sections 4/6 of POCSO Act. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that as the informant's daughter left the house of the informant and solemnized marriage with this petitioner, which was not acceptable to the informant because of similar gotra in the Hansda community, as such, an FIR has been lodged when the daughter of the informant refused to go with the informant and shown her inclination to live with the petitioner. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that marriage was solemnized and thereafter FIR has been lodged. The victim was examined underSection 164Cr.P.C. where she has given reply to the question no.3 that she made friendship with the petitioner in mela and she has earlier disclosed-2-this fact to the parents that she is interested in solemnization of marriage with the petitioner, which was not acceptable to the parents of the victim, as such, the FIR has been lodged but in the statement recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C., victim has not whispered a single word against the petitioner. Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that no offence under Section 4/6 of the POCSO Act is made out as there is no such allegation made by the victim in her statement recorded under Section 164 Cr.P.C. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that petitioner undertakes to solemnize marriage with the victim after she attains majority and till then petitioner will not solemnize marriage with any other girl, if the victim is ready after attaining the majority and the petitioner is duty bound to solemnize marriage with her. 
 Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that admittedly the victim is a minor girl and as per the informant she is 12 years and 6 months, as per the learned Magistrate she is 13 years and as per the victim, she is 14 and ½ years, as such, a minor girl has been taken by the petitioner and solemnized marriage, as such, he is not entitled for regular bail. 
 After hearing, learned counsel for the parties and perusing the materials brought on record and looking into the fact and material, it appears that in the statement recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C., victim has not alleged anything against the petitioner rather she called the petitioner and thereafter went to the temple and solemnized marriage with the petitioner, as such, this Court is inclined to grant Bail to the petitioner, as such, petitioner (Anil Hansda @ Kole), is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Additional Sessions Judge- IIIrd, Deoghar in connection with Budhai Case No.39 of 2020, corresponding to POCSO Case No.34 of 2020 on the following conditions:- 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be deponent/parivikar of the present case namely, Ranjan Tudu, S/o Adhanu Tudu, R/o Village- Koldi, Karogram, P.O.& P.S.- Budhai, District- Deoghar, who has furnished photocopy of his UID Card bearing No.4705 2775 3139 before this Court in the bail application. Office is directed to send photo copy of the UID Card bearing No. 4705 2775 3139 of deponent along with this order to the court below so as to-3-verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Another bailor shall be father/mother/son/sister/brother. 
 (iii) Petitioner will file an undertaking before the court below that after attaining the majority by the victim, petitioner will accept her as his wife if victim has no objection. Petitioner will not solemnize any marriage with any other girl till victim attains majority and refused to marry with this petitioner. 
 (iv) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioner only after his medical check- up. 
 (v) The Civil Surgeon, Deoghar is directed to medically examine the petitioner at the time of his release and if require, petitioner shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, he shall be released forthwith, if not wanted in any other case. 
 (vi) Petitioner shall also comply with all the guidelines issued by the Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as the country is passing through Pandemic of Covid-19. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Aman Mishra @ Aman vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 27 in Arms Act', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Anurag Kashyap, Advocate. 
 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Anurag Kashyap. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Sakchi P.S. Case No. 235/2017, corresponding to G.R. No. 3537/2017 (S.T. No. 142/2019) for the offence registered underSections 302/34I.P.C. andSection 27of Arms Act. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that earlier the prayer for bail of this petitioner was rejected as not pressed vide order dated 12.03.2019 passed in B.A. No. 8796/2018. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner is not named in the F.I.R., as such, petitioner may be enlarged on bail, as he is in custody since 26.12.2017 and charge has been framed on 10.01.2020. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that co-accused Md. Arif @ Md. Arif Ali has been granted bail vide order dated 06.09.2018 passed in B.A. No. 7354/2018. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that another co-accused Goutam Singh @ Goutam Kumar Singh and Niraj Dubey have also been enlarged on bail vide order dated 05.09.2018 passed in B.A. No. 5057/2018 and B.A. No. 3963/2018 respectively by Coordinate Bench of this Court. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that Santosh Kumar Pandey and Santosh Kumar Singh have been enlarged on bail vide order dated 14.08.2018 passed in B.A. No.-2-3764/2018 and B.A. No. 3748/2018 respectively by Coordinate Bench of this Court. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted further that Alamgir Alam @ Alamgir Khan has been enlarged on bail by this Court vide order dated 17.05.2019 passed in B.A. No. 3708/2019, as such, petitioner may also be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mrs. Sweta Singh, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail. 
 Considering the rival submission of the parties and looking into the fact that other co-accused persons have been granted bail by Coordinate Bench of this Court and even by this Court and he is in custody since 26.12.2017 and charge has been framed on 10.01.2020, the petitioner is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each in connection with Sakchi P.S. Case No. 235/2017, corresponding to G.R. No. 3537/2017 (S.T. No. 142/2019) to the satisfaction of learned Additional Sessions Judge- VI, Jamshedpur on the following conditions: 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be the deponent / pairvikar of the present case namely, Vishwabhar Mishra, son of Basisth Mishra, resident of House No. 154/2/2, Road No. 5 Bagbera Colony, P.O. - Tatanagar, P.S. - Bagbera, District - East Singhbhum, who has furnished photocopy of his UID Card bearing number 2001 4152 2714 before this Court in the bail application. 
 Office is directed to send the photocopy of UID Card bearing no. 2001 4152 2714 of deponent alongwith this order to the court below so as to verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Another bailor shall be close relative of the petitioner i.e. father / mother / son / wife / brother. 
 (iii) Petitioner shall appear before the trial court on each and every date till conclusion of the trial. 
 (iv) Petitioner should not influence the witnesses and if such complaint is filed, the prosecution is at liberty to file an application for cancellation bail. 
 (v) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioner only after his medical check-up. 
 (vi) The Civil Surgeon, Jamshedpur is directed to medically examine the petitioner at the time of his release and if he is infected with corona virus, he shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, he shall be released forthwith, if not wanted in any other case. 
 (vii) The petitioner shall follow all the guidelines issued by the Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as presently Country is passing through pandemic of Covid-19. 
 Accordingly, the instant bail application is allowed. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Morish Tirkey @ Muysu vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Sunil Kumar Ganjhu, Advocate. 
 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Sunil Kumar Ganjhu. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Khunti P.S. Case No. 78/2020 for the offence registered under Sections 25(1-b)a, 26, 35 ofArms Actas one country made pistol with two live cartridges and Samsung Mobile Phone with SIM No. 7033321131 have been recovered from the possession of the petitioner. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that other co- accused person namely, Soma Swansi has been enlarged on bail by the Coordinate Bench of this Court vide order dated 02.09.2020 passed in B.A. No. 5383/2020 and co-accused Govinda Nayak has been enlarged on bail by Coordinate Bench of this Court vide order dated 26.08.2020 passed in B.A. No. 5381/2020, as such, this petitioner, who is in custody since 15.05.2020, may also be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. Ashok Kumar, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that the petitioner along with Markush Bhengra @ Shuter, Albinush Soy and Parmeshwar Mahto have been made accused as police found these four persons moving with fire arms during the lock down period due to pandemic of Covid-19. 
 Learned counsel for the State has further submitted that other two accused persons have been granted bail by Coordinate Bench of this Court, who were not apprehended, rather it is alleged that both-2-have fled away, as such, the case of the petitioner is different from the case of the other co-accused persons, who have been granted bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State has further submitted that as per the memo of the evidence sent to him by the Officer-in-Charge, Khuti Police Station, this petitioner has three criminal antecedents of similar nature apart from this case, as such, he may not be enlarged on bail. 
 Considering the rival submission of the parties, looking into facts and circumstances of the case that the case of other co-accused persons is different from the case of the petitioner as those persons had been absconded, whereas this petitioner was apprehended with the other accused persons, since this petitioner was moving along with fire arm during the lock down period, this Court is not inclined to grant bail to the petitioner. 
 Accordingly, the instant bail application is hereby rejected. Petitioner has criminal antecedents, as such, he is directed to renew his prayer for bail after one year of his custody from 15.05.2020. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Kamdeo Hazra vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 447 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 316 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 341 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conference) 
 ----- 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that though there are defect nos.5(e) and 9(i) to 9(xi) in the bail application as pointed out by the stamp reporter but he has filed an undertaking that he shall remove the defects within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard as it is a regular bail in which petitioner is in custody since 04.01.2020. Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the bail application on merit but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defects within 30 days after the physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defects. Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Prashant Kumar Rai, learned counsel for the State, Mrs. Priya Shrestha. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Jamua Case No.15 of 2000, corresponding to G.R. No.146 of 2000, S.T. No.389 of 2001 for the offence registered underSections 341,323,316and447IPC. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has been granted earlier regular bail vide order dated 28.06.2006 passed in B.A. No.4106 of 2006 in connection with Jamua Case No.15 of 2000, corresponding to G.R. No.146 of 2000, S.T. No.389 of 2001 for the offence registered underSections 341,323,316and447IPC, but he filed a representation in the year, 2009, which was rejected and his bail bonds were cancelled. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner is an illiterate person and he was not knowing that it amounts to misuse of the privilege of bail. Under the aforesaid circumstances, since the petitioner is in custody since 04.01.2020 and undertakes before this Court that he shall remain physically present on each and every date till conclusion of the trial, as such, he-2-may be enlarged on regular bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that it has been found that 46% of the criminal trial is pending because of non-appearance of the accused. Present case is the glaring example of such delay in trial, as such, petitioner is not entitle for regular bail though he remained in custody for approximately nine months. 
 After hearing, learned counsel for the parties and perusing the materials brought on record and looking upon the merit of the case, which is misuse of the privilege of bail, this Court is inclined to grant Bail to the petitioner. Accordingly, petitioner (Kamdeo Hazra), is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Additional Sessions Judge-III, at- Giridih in connection with Jamua Case No.15 of 2000, corresponding to G.R. No.146 of 2000, S.T. No.389 of 2001 on the following conditions:-

case title: Mukesh Kumar vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.), (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand), (2)
issues: ['Section 414 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
1. Mukesh Kumar 
 2. Dinesh Kumar Gope ... Petitioners Versus The State of Jharkhand ... Opposite Party 
 ------ 
 CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY 
 ------ 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. Rahul Kumar, Advocate For the State : Mr. P.K. Chatterjee, Addl. P.P. 
 ------ 
 Order No.02 Dated- 14.09.2020 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Learned counsel for the petitioners personally undertake to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking of the learned counsel for the petitioners, the defects pointed out by the stamp reporter are ignored for the present. 
 Apprehending their arrest, the petitioners have moved this Court for grant of privilege of anticipatory bail in connection with Karra P.S. Case No.45 of 2020 registered undersections 414of the Indian Penal Code, Section 54 of J.M.M.C. Rules, 2004 and under Section 3/7 of Jharkhand Mineral (Prevention of Illegal Mining Transportation and Storage) Rule, 2017. 
 The Learned counsel for the petitioners submits that the allegation against the petitioners is that the petitioners are the owners of the tractors which were seized by police for transporting illegal excavated sand. It is further submitted that the allegation against the petitioners are all false and they have no knowledge about their vehicle being involved in any illegal activity. It is then submitted that the petitioners are ready and willing to furnish sufficient security including cash security and undertake to cooperate with the investigation of the case. Hence, it is submitted that the petitioners be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. Learned Addl. P.P. opposes the prayer for grant of anticipatory bail. 
 Considering the submissions of the counsels and the fact as discussed above, I am of the opinion that it is a fit case where the above named petitioners be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. Hence, in the event of their arrest or surrender within a period of four weeks from the date of this order, they shall be released on bail on petitioner no.1 depositing cash security of Rs.10,000/- and petitioner no.2 depositing cash security of Rs.5000/- and both of them furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned J.M., Khunti, in connection with Karra P.S. Case No.45 of 2020 with the condition that the petitioners will cooperate with the investigation of the case and appear before the Investigating Officer as and when noticed by him and will furnish their mobile numbers and a copy of their Aadhar Cards in the court below with the undertaking that they will not change their mobile numbers during the pendency of the case subject to the conditions laid down under section 438 (2) Cr. P.C. 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Gunjan-

case title: Ajay Kumar vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
1. Ajay Kumar. 
 2. Ravindra Kumar. 
 3. Dabloo @ Virendra Kumar @ Birendra @ Dabloo Kumar. 
 ......Petitioners Versus 
 1. The State of Jharkhand. 
 2. Ram Jatan Ganjhu .....Opposite Parties 
 -------- 
 Coram: THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 Defect No. 9 (i), as pointed out by the office, is ignored. The petitioners apprehend their arrest in connection with Mckluskiganj P.S. Case No. 33 of 2019. 
 It has been alleged that the miscreants had committed theft of contract and caterinary wire of 180 meters length and worth Rs.5,00,000/-. It has further been alleged that the accused persons had come to the work site and abused the staffs and threatened that such thefts will be repeated in future. 
 The petitioners appear to be agitating for job and compensation in CCL in view of the acquisition of land. The grievance of the petitioners is that without making payment of compensation and giving service, contract was awarded by the CCL to a private company for construction of a railway siding. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners has submitted that the matter has been compromised between the parties. 
 In view of the background facts as stated by the learned counsel for the petitioners, their false implication also cannot be ruled out. On consideration of the aforesaid scenario, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioners. 
 Accordingly, the petitioners, named above, are directed to surrender in the court below within a period of four weeks from today and pray for regular bail, and in that event, they will be enlarged on bail, on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- ( Ten thousand only) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Sub Divisional Judicial Magistrate, Ranchi in connection with Mckluskiganj P.S. Case No. 33 of 2019, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J) Rakesh/-

case title: Munsif Ansari vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 420 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
1. Munsif Ansari. 
 2. Mohan Sao. 
 3. Sudhir Nath Mishra. ......Petitioners Versus 
 1. The State of Jharkhand. 
 Coram: THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 So far as the defect nos.3, 4, 9(iv), as pointed out by the office are concerned, learned counsel for the petitioners undertakes to remove the same once the situation normalizes. As regards the rest defects are concerned, same are ignored. 
 The petitioners apprehend their arrest in connection with Protest cum Complaint Case No. 264 of 2019. 
 It has been alleged that one Md Idrish in connivance with other accused persons had fraudulently got executed a sale deed by the complainant for 13 ½ decimals of land. On being confronted, Md Idrish executed an Ekrarnama that after mutation he will execute another sale deed and resale the 13 ½ decimals of land to the complainant. 
 It appears that initially with respect to the allegations, as levelled, Bishnugarh P.S. Case No. 28 of 2018 was lodged, in which after investigation final form was submitted and on a protest petition having been filed by the complainant, cognizance has been taken undersection 420of the Indian Penal Code and the petitioners have been summoned to face the trial. 
 Petitioner Nos. 1 and 3 appear to be the witnesses of the sale deed while petitioner no. 2 is the deed writer of the sale deed. The main allegations even as per the complaint petition seem to revolve around Md. Idrish who was the person mainly responsible for execution of the sale deed by the complainant and the subsequent promise though the said Md. Idrish has resiled in spite of making such promise. 
 On consideration of the aforesaid facts, the petitioners, named above, are directed to surrender in the court below within a period of four weeks from today and pray for regular bail, and in that event, they will be enlarged on bail, on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- ( Ten thousand only) each with two-2-sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st class, Hazaribagh in connection with Protest cum Complaint Case No. 264 of 2019, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J) Rakesh/-

case title: Meghan Ram vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
1. Meghan Ram. 
 2. Guddu Das @ Om Prakash Das. 
 3. Putal Das @ Deepak Das. ......Petitioners Versus The State of Jharkhand. .....Opposite Party 
 -------- 
 Coram: THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. Kamdeo Pandey, Advocate For the State : Mr. Shailesh Kumar Sinha, A.P.P. 
 -------- 
 02/14-9-2020 Heard the parties. 
 So far as the defects, as pointed out by the office are concerned, learned counsel for the petitioners undertakes to remove the same once the situation normalizes. 
 The petitioners apprehend their arrest in connection with Giridih (M) P.S. Case No. 90 of 2020. 
 When the informant had gone to collect woods, she was accosted by the petitioners who tried to outrage her modesty and had also abused and assaulted her. The incident is said to have occurred on 29.03.2020 but the FIR was instituted after a delay of almost ten days without there being any reasonable explanation submitted by the informant regarding such delay. 
 From the FIR, it appears that the primary act alleged against the petitioners is abuse and assault and the allegation about outraging of modesty appears to be by way of an afterthought. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners has submitted that the matter has been compromised between both the sides. 
 Irrespective of the compromise, which has been effected between the petitioners and the informant party on consideration of the aforesaid facts regarding non explanation of the delay in registration of the F.I.R. and the nature of allegations levelled against the petitioners, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioners. 
 Accordingly, the petitioners, named above, are directed to surrender in the court below within a period of four weeks from today and pray for regular bail, and in that event, they will be enlarged on bail, on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- ( Ten thousand only) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Sub Divisional Judicial Magistrate, Giridih in connection with Giridih (M) P.S. Case No. 90 of 2020, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J) Rakesh/-

case title: Dasrath Prasad vs The State Of Jharkhand Through Its ...
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RAJESH SHANKAR For the Petitioner :- Mr. Ravi Prakash Mishra, Advocate For the State :- Mr. Ashok Kumar Singh, A.C. to S.C. (L&C)-III For the NHAI :- Ms. Khusboo Kataruka, Advocate Order No. 03 Dated: 14.09.2020 The present case is taken up through video conferencing. 
 2. At the request of the learned counsel for the petitioner, the defects, as pointed out by the office, are ignored. 
 3. The present writ petition has been filed for issuance of direction upon the respondents to consider the objection raised by the petitioner against the amount of compensation fixed for acquisition of land appertaining to plot no. 4726/2, Khata no. 393, Thana No. 139 (Bagodar), Mouza- Atkadih measuring total area of 04 decimals out of which 0.0073 acre has been acquired for the purpose of widening (six laning) of National Highway No.-02 between Aurangabad to Barwadda Section. 
 4. Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that earlier, an award was prepared in connection with the land in question on 15.04.2015 showing the land of the petitioner consisting of house/shop and the compensation amount to the extent of Rs.19,97,155.67/- was assessed. However, subsequently vide notice dated 05.07.2019, the petitioner was offered compensation of Rs.14,47,820.68/- for acquisition of 0.0073 acre of land. It is also submitted that the respondent authorities are bound to assess compensation in view of the letter dated 08.08.2016 issued by the Department of Revenue, Registration and Land Reforms, Government of Jharkhand, under2which it has been stipulated that even after demolition of the part of the house, if the rest part is no longer suitable for residential purpose, the compensation of entire constructed area has to be determined and the said raiyat is entitled for payment of compensation accordingly. 
 5. Learned counsel for the State as well as the respondent-NHAI jointly submit that the petitioner appears to be dissatisfied with the quantum of compensation fixed by the competent authority under theNational Highways Authority Act, 1956 (in short "the Act, 1956"), hence the petitioner has the recourse of raising an objection against the quantum of compensation fixed by the competent authority before the arbitrator appointed by the government. 
 6. Having heard the learned counsel for the parties and keeping in view the nature of the prayer made in the writ petition, without entering into the merit of the claim of the petitioner, he is given liberty to prefer an application/objection before the respondent no. 3 raising objection on the point of quantum of compensation. On receipt of the said application, the respondent no. 3 shall take appropriate steps to refer the matter to the arbitrator in terms with the provisions ofSection 3-G(5)of the Act, 1956 within a period of two weeks from the date of receipt of the said application/objection. Further, the arbitrator shall take an appropriate decision in accordance with law preferably within a period of four months thereafter. 
 7. The writ petition is accordingly disposed of with aforesaid liberty and direction. 
 (Rajesh Shankar, J.) Ritesh/

case title: Sukhvendra Singh @ Sulvendra ... vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 164 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 376 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 365 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 370 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Lalit Yadav, Advocate. 
 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Lalit Yadav. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that defect nos. 9 (i) to (vi), as per Stamp Reporting dated 27.08.2020, have not been removed, which he undertakes to remove within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard, as it is a regular bail application of the petitioner, who is in custody since 17.03.2020. 
 Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the instant bail application on merits, but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defect(s) within 30 days after physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defect(s). 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Madhupur P.S. Case No. 37/2020 for the offence registered underSections 370,365,34I.P.C. and subsequentlySection 376I.P.C. has been added vide order dated 16.03.2020. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner is not named in the F.I.R. It is alleged in the First Information Report that daughter of the informant was missing on 04.01.2020 and on 28.02.2020, an F.I.R. has been lodged that petitioner has purchased the daughter of the informant. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that police after investigation has not submitted charge-sheet underSection 376I.P.C., rather on the basis of the statement of victim recorded under-2-Section 164Cr.P.C., no case is made out against the petitioner as victim is twice married, but her conjugal life was not happy, as such, she fled away and solemnized marriage with this petitioner, as such, petitioner, who is in custody since 17.03.2020, may be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mrs. Ruby Pandey, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that case diary, statement of the victim recorded underSection 164Cr. P.C. are necessary for proper adjudication of the bail application, as such, four weeks time may be granted to file counter affidavit in this case. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties, looking into the gravity of the offence, this court is inclined the grant four weeks' time to the State counsel to file counter affidavit so as to bring on record the material collected during investigation as well as statement of the victim recorded under Section 164 Cr.P.C. 
 Put up this case after four weeks. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Dhiraj Yadav vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 307 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 4 in the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961', 'Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMITAV K. GUPTA 
 --------- 
 For the Appellant : Mr. Satish Kumar, Advocate For the State : Mr. Nehru Mahto, A.P.P. 
 For the Informant : Mr. Kalyan Banerjee, Advocate 
 --------- 
 1. This interlocutory application has been filed underSection 389(1)of the Code of Criminal Procedure for suspension of sentence and grant of ad-interim bail, to the petitioner, during the pendency of the appeal. 
 2. The petitioner/ appellant has been convicted for the offence underSections 307,323,498Aof I.P.C andSection 4of Dowry Prohibition Act, and sentenced to undergo R.I of 5 years and fine of Rs.5,000/- for the offence underSection 307I.P.C, S.I of 3 years for the offence underSection 323I.P.C, R.I of 3 years and fine of Rs.1,000/- for the offence underSection 498AI.P.C and S.I of 2 years and fine of Rs.1,000/- for the offence underSection 4of Dowry Prohibition Act, and in default thereof, to further undergo S.I of three months, vide judgment dated 16.04.2019, passed by the court of learned Additional Sessions Judge - XVI, Dhanbad, in S.T. No.136 of 2015. 
 3. Having heard learned counsel for the petitioner, and objection of learned A.P.P, assisted by the learned counsel for the informant, and on perusal of the materials on record, it appears that the court below has convicted the appellant for the offence underSection 307I.P.C merely on the testimony of the witnesses. In fact, no medical evidence or injury report was adduced to establish the charge under Section 307 I.P.C. 
 Considering that the petitioner has remained in custody for more than two years, accordingly I am inclined to suspend the sentence and enlarge the appellant on bail, during the pendency of the appeal, on his furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Additional Sessions Judge - XVI, Dhanbad, in connection with S.T. No.136 of 2015. 
 4. The appellant shall remain present before the Court, when the appeal is taken up for hearing, failing which his bail shall be cancelled. 
 5. I.A. No.4219 of 2019 stands disposed off. 
 (AMITAV K. GUPTA, J.) Chandan/-

case title: Md. Gulzar Hussain Ansari vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 325 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 326 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 401 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMITAV K. GUPTA 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. Suraj Singh, Advocate For the State : Ms. Vandana Bharti, A.P.P For the Informant : Mr. Pankaj Srivastava, Advocate 
 --------- 
 1. This interlocutory application has been filed underSection 401of the Code of Criminal Procedure for suspension of the sentence and grant of ad-interim bail, to the petitioners, during the pendency of the revision. 
 2. The petitioner was convicted for the offence underSection 326read withSection 34of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to undergo R.I. of 3 years and to pay a fine of Rs.1,000/- in default thereof, to further undergo S.I. for 6 months by the court of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Jamshedpur in G.R. Case No.1820 of 2010. The judgment was affirmed by the court of learned Additional Sessions Judge - XIII, Est Singhbhum, Jamshedpur, in Criminal Appeal Nos.107 of 2019 and conviction underSection 326I.P.C was modified by holding the petitioner guilty for the offence underSection 325of I.P.C and with modification of sentence from 3 years to R.I of 2 years and a fine of Rs.1,000/-, in default thereof, to further undergo R.I of one month. 
 3. Having heard learned counsel for the petitioner and the objection of learned A.P.P, assisted by learned counsel for the informant, and on perusal of materials on record, it appears that the petitioner and the informant are own brothers. As per the injury report, proved by P.W. - 4, the doctor has opined that there was disfigurement of nose and in his cross- examination he has stated that the informant had not disclosed to him as to how the informant sustained injury on-2-the nose. P.W. - 4 has opined that the injury on nose was caused by biting. 
 Considering, the fact, that the petitioner is in custody for more than six months, I am inclined to suspend the sentence and enlarge the petitioner on bail, during the pendency of the revision, on his furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Jamshedpur, in connection with G.R. No.1820 of 2010/ T.R. No.527 of 2019, subject to the condition that the petitioner shall deposit the fine amount of Rs.1,000/- (One thousand) in the court below. 
 4. I.A. No.2236 of 2020 stands allowed. 
 Cr. Revision No.1554 of 2019 
 1. Learned counsel for the informant has submitted that the informant (O.P. No.02) has also preferred Cr. Revision No.267 of 2020, against the aforesaid judgment for enhancement of the sentence, and prays that the instant revision be heard alongwith he said revision. 
 2. Office to list the instant revision along with Cr. Revision No.267 of 2020, under the appropriate heading, in seriatim. 
 (AMITAV K. GUPTA, J.) Chandan

case title: Rajesh Oraon vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 411 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 373 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 379 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conference) 
 ----- 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that though there are defect nos.9(i) and 9(ii) in the bail application as pointed out by the stamp reporter but he has filed an undertaking that he shall remove the defects within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard as it is a regular bail in which petitioner is in custody since 15.02.2020. Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the bail application on merit but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defects within 30 days after the physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defects. Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Prashant Kr. Rahul and learned counsel for the State, Mr. P.K. Appu. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Balumath P.S. Case No.30 of 2020, for the offence registered underSections 379,411IPC, later on Charge sheet has also been filed for the offence underSection 373and411IPC. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has been made a named accused in this case though co-accused, Md. Rustam Ali having similar allegation has been granted bail by co-ordinate Bench of this Court vide order dated 02.09.2020 and he was in custody since 16.02.2020 whereas this petitioner is in custody since 15.02.2020, as such, petitioner may be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that 20 stolen motorcycle has been recovered from the possession of the accused persons including the petitioner. Petitioner has five criminal antecedents of the similar nature, as such, he is not entitled for regular bail. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted on this point that it is an apparent error of record and only two criminal cases are pending against him. 
 After hearing, learned counsel for the parties and perusing the materials brought on record and since co-accused, Md. Rustam Ali having similar allegation has been granted bail by co-ordinate Bench of this Court vide order dated 02.09.2020, as such, this Court is inclined to grant Bail to the petitioner. Accordingly, petitioner (Rajesh Oraon), is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Latehar in connection with Balumath P.S. Case No.30 of 2020 on the following conditions:- 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be deponent/parivikar of the present case namely, Kameshwar Oraon, S/o Bandhan Oraon, R/o- Village- Balu, P.O. & P.S.- Balu, District- Latehar, who has furnished photocopy of his UID Card bearing No.4773 6604 1871 before this Court in the bail application. 
 Office is directed to send photo copy of the UID Card bearing No. 4773 6604 1871 of deponent along with this order to the court below so as to verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Another bailor shall be father/mother/son/sister/brother. 
 (iii) Petitioner is directed to appear before the officer-in-charge, Balumath Police Station, Latehar on 01st Monday of each English Calendar till conclusion of the trial. 
 (iv) Petitioner is also directed to appear before the learned trial court on each and every date till conclusion of the trial. 
 (iii) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioner only after his medical check- up. 
 (vi) The Civil Surgeon, Latehar is directed to medically examine the petitioner at the time of his release and if require, petitioner shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, he shall be released forthwith, if not wanted in any other case. 
 (v) Petitioner shall also comply with all the guidelines issued by the Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as the country is passing through Pandemic of Covid-19. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Rohit Das @ Gourango Das vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. Manoj Tiwari, Advocate For the State : Mr. Jitendra Pandey, Advocate 
 -------- 
 Order No. 02: Dated: 14 September, 2020 th Heard learned counsel for the petitioner and learned counsel appearing for the State. 
 Defect no. 9(i), as pointed out by the office, is ignored. The petitioner apprehends his arrest in connection with Sonari P.S. Case No. 58 of 2019. 
 It has been alleged that the informant and others were fired upon by the accused persons but all had a providential escape. When the locals gathered and started pelting stones the miscreants had fled away. Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner is not named in the FIR and has subsequently been implicated on account of mis-conception due to a namesake of the petitioner having been alleged to be a participant in the offence. It has been stated that the petitioner is Rohit Das @ Gaurang Das son of Dayamay Das whereas Gaurang Das, who has been mentioned in the FIR, is the son of Sri Prafullo Das. Learned counsel, therefore, submits that save and except the implication of the petitioner on account of the confusion arising out of sharing of name with the other co-accused there is no other material which would indicate the complicity of the petitioner. 
 Learned A.P.P. has opposed the prayer for bail made by the petitionr. 
 From the impugned order it appears that the parentage of the namesake of Gourango Das are different. It further appears that that the said Gourango Das has been named in the FIR and charge sheet has been submitted against him while the investigation is still pending against the present petitioner. The aforesaid facts, therefore, to a certain extent substantiates the contention advanced by the learned counsel for the petitioner that the petitioner has been implicated only on account of confusion arising out of a similar sounding name of the petitioner and the named accused in the FIR. 
 On consideration of the aforesaid fact, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. Accordingly, the petitioner, above named, is directed to surrender in the court below within a period of four weeks from today and pray for regular bail, and in that event, he will be enlarged on bail, on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Ten Thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned J.M.F.C., Jamshedpur at East Singhbhum in connection with Sonari P.S. Case No. 58 of 2019, subject to the conditions as laid down undersection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application, accordingly, stands allowed.

case title: Anamika Nandi vs The State Of Jharkhand Through
issues: ['Section 45 in The Prevention of Money-Laundering Act, 2002']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 Heard learned counsel for the petitioner and learned counsel appearing for the Directorate of Enforcement. 
 So far as defect no. 4 is concerned, learned counsel for the petitioner undertakes to remove the same once the situation normalizes. As regards rest defects are concerned, the same are ignored. 
 The petitioner apprehends her arrest in connection with ECIR Case No. 02 of 2020. 
 The allegations reveals that M/s Sanjeevani Buildcon through its directors and others had hatched a conspiracy against the gullible investors and cheated them by inducement to purchase plots of land and received a huge amount of money but did not provide possession of the plots to the purchasers and had ultimately closed the office and had fled away. 
 It appears that initially, the CBI had taken over investigation and after submission of charge sheet a case was registered by the Directorate of Enforcement. 
 It has been stated by learned counsel for the petitioner that the present case is an offshoot of Lower Bazar P.S. Case No. 126 of 2012 in which the trial is still going on. Learned counsel submits that it has not been proved that the petitioner is the beneficiary to the proceeds of crime. Learned counsel further submits that the petitioner has remained in custody for more than five years before being granted bail in connection with Lower Bazar P.S. Case No. 126 of 2012 and in such circumstances, therefore, when custodial interrogation is not necessary, the petitioner deserves to be granted anticipatory bail. 
 Countering the said arguments, learned counsel appearing for the Directorate of Enforcement, has referred tosection 45of the Prevention of Money Laundering Act and has stated that the petitioner has to show, prima facie, that she is not guilty of the offence of money laundering. It has further been submitted that the present case is separate from that of Lower Bazar P.S. Case No. 126 of 2012. Learned counsel further submits that there are overwhelming materials collected during investigation which would indicate that huge amounts were siphoned off from the various accounts which would show that the same were proceeds of crime. 
 On consideration of the arguments advanced by the learned counsel for the respective parties and on going through the investigation report, it appears that the investigation had clearly revealed the modus operandi of the accused persons in cheating the investors in receiving huge amount of money which, prima facie, appears to be the from the proceeds of crime. 
 The case instituted by the Directorate of Enforcement is an altogether different case which is specifically related to the money laundering alleged against the petitioner as she was found to be beneficiary of the proceeds of crime and in such context, therefore, I am not inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner This application, accordingly, stands rejected. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J.) MM

 ------ 
 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Learned counsel for the petitioner personally undertakes to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking of the learned counsel for the petitioner, the defects pointed out by the stamp reporter are ignored for the present. 
 Apprehending his arrest, the petitioner has moved this Court for grant of privilege of anticipatory bail in connection with Sukhdeonagar P.S. Case No.38 of 2020 registered undersections 147,148,149,342,323,325,379,436,504,307of the Indian Penal Code. 
 Heard the learned counsel for the petitioner and learned Addl. P.P. for the State. 
 The Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the allegation against the petitioner is that the petitioner along with co-accused person attempted to murder the informant and Firoj Ansari causing injuries and looted the motorcycle. It is next submitted by the learned counsel that till the date of occurrence the petitioner has no criminal antecedent but after the occurrence three false cases have been foisted against the petitioner. It is, further, submitted that the allegation against the petitioner is false. It is next submitted by learned counsel that the petitioner is ready and willing to pay Rs. 25,000/- as ad interim victim compensation to the informant without prejudice to his defence in this case and undertakes that he will not annoy or disturb the informant in any manner during the pendency of the case. Hence, it is submitted that the petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. 
 Learned Addl. P.P. opposes the prayer for grant of anticipatory bail. 
 Considering the submissions of the counsels and the fact as discussed above, I am of the opinion that it is a fit case where the above named petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. Hence, in the event of his arrest or surrender within a period of four weeks from the date of this order, he shall be released on bail on depositing a demand draft of Rs. 25,000/- as ad interim victim compensation in favour of informant and on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned JMFC, Ranchi, in connection with Sukhdeonagar P.S. Case No.38 of 2020 with the condition that the petitioner will cooperate with the investigation of the case and appear before the Investigating Officer as and when noticed by him and will furnish their mobile numbers and a copy of their Aadhar Cards in the court below with the undertaking that he will not change his mobile numbers during the pendency of the case and also undertakes that he will not annoy or disturb the informant in any manner during the pendency of the case subject to the conditions laid down under section 438 (2) Cr. P.C. 
 In case, the petitioner deposits the ad interim victim compensation amount, the court below is directed to issue notice to the informant and hand over the said demand draft to him, after proper identification. 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Pappu/-

case title: Sewak Barai vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.), (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand), (Korrah), (2)
issues: ['Section 420 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 406 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY 
 ------ 
 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Learned counsel for the petitioner personally undertakes to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking of the learned counsel for the petitioner, the defects pointed out by the stamp reporter are ignored for the present. 
 Apprehending his arrest, the petitioner has moved this Court for grant of privilege of anticipatory bail in connection with Sadar (Korrah) P.S. Case No. 104 of 2019 registered undersections 406/420of the Indian Penal Code. 
 Heard the learned counsel for the petitioner and learned Addl. P.P. for the State. 
 The Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the allegation against the petitioner is that the petitioner has taken loan of Rs.10,00,000/- from Bank of India, Vinoba Bhave University Branch, Hazaribag for purchasing vehicle but encashed the said amount by opening the account in the name of Laxmi Auto and a sum of Rs.9,74,525.85/- is outstanding against the petitioner as on 01.10.2015 in his said loan account with the Bank of India, Vinoba Bhave University Branch, Hazaribag. It is, further, submitted that the allegations against the petitioner are all false and the petitioner is ready and willing to repay the amount of loan taken. It is then submitted that the petitioner intended to purchase a vehicle of 'Travera' make but as no such vehicle was available, so the demand draft which was issued for the said purchase was going to lapse by efflux of time, hence the said loan amount was secured by the petitioner on depositing the same with the Laxmi Automobile company. It is next submitted that since the price of the vehicle has gone up hence the petitioner has no capacity to purchase the said vehicle now and the petitioner did not have any dishonest intention at the time of taking the said loan. It is next submitted that the petitioner is ready and willing to deposit Rs.9,75,000/- with the Bank of India, Vinova Bhave University Branch, Hazaribag. It is next submitted that petitioner undertakes to cooperate with the investigation of the case. Hence, it is submitted that the petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. 
 Learned Addl. P.P. opposes the prayer for grant of anticipatory bail. 
 Considering the submissions of the counsels and the fact as discussed above, I am of the opinion that it is a fit case where the above named petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. Hence, in the event of his arrest or surrender within a period of four months from the date of this order, he shall be released on bail and on showing the proof of deposit of Rs.9,75,000/- with the Bank of India, Vinova Bhave University Branch, Hazaribag and on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned A.C.J.M., Hazaribag in connection with Sadar (Korrah) P.S. Case No. 104 of 2019 with the condition that the petitioner will cooperate with the investigation of the case and appear before the Investigating Officer as and when noticed by him and will furnish his mobile numbers and a copy of his Aadhar Cards in the court below with the undertaking that he will not change his mobile numbers during the pendency of the case and subject to the conditions laid down under section 438 (2) Cr. P.C. 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Pappu/-

case title: Subrat Pathak vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.), (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand), (G.R. No. 217 of 2020), (2)
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY 
 ------ 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. R.S. Mazumdar, Sr. Advocate For the State : Mr. Satish Prasad, Addl. P.P. 
 For the Informant : Mr. Sudhakar Pandey, Adovcate 
 ------ 
 Order No.02 Dated- 14.09.2020 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Learned senior counsel for the petitioner personally undertakes to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking of the learned senior counsel for the petitioner, the defects pointed out by the stamp reporter are ignored for the present. 
 Apprehending his arrest, the petitioner has moved this Court for grant of privilege of anticipatory bail in connection with Telaiya P.S. Case No.32 of 2020 (G.R. No. 217 of 2020) registered undersections 302/34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 Heard the learned senior counsel for the petitioner and learned Addl. P.P. for the State. 
 Mr. R.S. Mazumdar, the Learned senior counsel appearing for the petitioner draws the attention of this court to the confessional statement of the co-accused-Ratnakar Pandey, and submits that the only allegation against the petitioner is that on being informed by the father of the co-accused Ratnakar Pandey that the sister of Ratnakar Pandey is missing from their house, the petitioner accompanied with co-accused-Ratnakar Pandey to the photo studio of the deceased. It is further submitted by the learned senior advocate that in the confessional statement itself, it is specifically mentioned that after visiting the photo shop of the deceased, the petitioner has not committed any covert or overt act and from the photo shop of the deceased, the co-accused-Ratnakar Pandey followed the deceased in the pillion of the motorcycle driven by Rohit Kumar Singh and assaulted the victim with iron rod resulting in his death. It is next submitted that keeping in view the fact that the petitioner lives in the same locality as the co- accused-Ratnakar Pandey, merely accompanying Ratnakar Pandey to the studio of the deceased in search of the sister of Ratnkar Pandey cannot constitute any common intention with the co- accused persons. It is next submitted that as it has specifically been mentioned that Ratnakar Pandey with Rohit Kumar Singh followed the deceased in a motorcycle for a considerable distance, hence, the petitioner cannot be said to have any knowledge about any criminal intention of the co-accused. It is also submitted by the learned senior counsel for the petitioner that except the call details report there is no material in record to implicate the petitioner in this case and admittedly father of the co-accused called the petitioner over phone so the call details report is of no consequence in the facts of this case. It is, further, submitted that the allegation against the petitioner is false and the charge-sheet has already been submitted against the co-accused person. It is next submitted that petitioner undertakes to cooperate with the investigation of the case. Hence, it is submitted that the petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. 
 Learned Addl. P.P. opposes the prayer for grant of anticipatory bail. 
 Considering the submissions of the counsels and the fact as discussed above, I am of the opinion that it is a fit case where the above named petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. Hence, in the event of his arrest or surrender within a period of four weeks from the date of this order, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned J.M.-1st Class at Koderma, in connection with Telaiya P.S. Case No.32 of 2020 (G.R. No. 217 of 2020) with the condition that the petitioner will cooperate with the investigation of the case and appear before the Investigating Officer as and when noticed by him and will furnish his mobile numbers and a copy of the Aadhar Cards in the court below with the undertaking that he will not change his mobile numbers during the pendency of the case and subject to the conditions laid down under section 438 (2) Cr. P.C. 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Pappu/-

case title: Uzir Ansari @ Wazir Ansari vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
Uzir Ansari @ Wazir Ansari ... ... Petitioner Versus The State of Jharkhand ... ... Opposite Party 
 ------- 
 CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through- Video Conferencing 
 ------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Gautam Kumar, Advocate For the State : Mr. Manoj Kr. Mishra, A.P.P. 
 ------- 
 02/14.09.2020 Heard Mr. Gautam Kumar, learned counsel for the petitioner and Mr. Manoj Kr. Mishra, learned A.P.P. for the State. 
 So far as the defects are concerned learned counsel for the petitioner undertakes to remove the same once the situation normalizes. 
 The petitioner has prayed for grant of anticipatory bail, as he is apprehending his arrest in connection with Barharwa P.S. Case No. 492 of 2019, corresponding to G.R. No. 2683 of 2019. 
 The marriage of the informant was solemnized with the petitioner 18 years back. She was kept properly for a period of 5 years. It has been alleged that the petitioner had solemnized another marriage and on a case being filed the matter was compromised and the petitioner agreed to make payment of Rs. 3000/- per month to the informant. It has been alleged that since the last 3 years no maintenance has been paid and the accused persons had tried to burn the informant. 
 The First Information Report appears to be basically revolving around the non-payment of the agreed amount of maintenance. If the allegations are considered with respect to solemnizing a second marriage it seems that the First Information Report has been instituted after an undue delay. If the informant is aggrieved with the non-payment of the agreed amount by the petitioner she has a remedy of-2-approaching the Family Court in a proceeding u/s 125 Cr.P.C. 
 On consideration of the nature of allegations levelled against the petitioner, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. The petitioner accordingly is directed to surrender before the learned court below within a period of four weeks and on such surrender, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Judicial Magistrate 1st Class, Rajmahal in connection with Barharwa P.S. Case No. 492 of 2019, corresponding to G.R. No. 2683 of 2019, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (R. Mukhopadhyay, J.) Alok/-

case title: Anku Kumar vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
So far as the defect nos.3, 4, 5(e), 9(i), as pointed out by the office are concerned, learned counsel for the petitioners undertakes to remove the same once the situation normalizes. As regards the rest defects are concerned, the same are ignored. 
 The petitioner apprehends his arrest in connection with B.S. City P.S. Case No. 122 of 2019. 
 It has been alleged that petitioner had in a drunken state had entered into the Accounts Section and hurled abuses at the informant. It has further been alleged that the home guards present had to forcibly oust the petitioner from the premises. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner had gone to the office to ventilate his grievance regarding stoppage of salary for two days, which resulted in institution of the First Information Report. He has further submitted that the matter has been compromised between the parties. 
 Learned A.P.P has opposed the prayer for anticipatory bail of the petitioner. The petitioner is a home guard and a plausible explanation has been submitted by the petitioner with respect to the incident which had purportedly occurred in the Accounts Section. Moreover, the matter having been compromised between the parties and the petitioner being a government employee, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. 
 Accordingly, the petitioner, named above, is directed to surrender in the court below within a period of four weeks from today and pray for regular bail, and in that event, he will be enlarged on bail, on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- ( Ten thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Bokaro in connection with B.S. City P.S. Case No. 122 of 2019, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J) Rakesh/-

 The petitioner has prayed for grant of anticipatory bail, as he is apprehending his arrest in connection with Bank More (Bhuli) P.S. Case No. 326/2019. 
 While the informant and her daughter were going to their house she was assaulted by the accused persons. Her husband was also assaulted and the accused persons had tried to outrage the modesty of her daughter. 
 It appears that the father of the petitioner had also instituted a First Information Report being Bank More (Bhuli) P.S. Case No. 128/2019 against the informant as well as her husband and her daughter. The informant had also instituted Bank More (Bhuli) P.S. Case No. 129/2019 in which the petitioner was granted anticipatory bail by this Court in A.B.A. No. 6995 of 2019. It appears that the petitioner was also treated for the injuries which he had received and in fact the discharge slip of the petitioner which has been brought on record indicates serious injuries having been suffered by the petitioner. So far as the present case is concerned the allegations against the petitioner and others-2-appear to be of assaulting the informant and which are general and omnibus in nature. The previous enmity between the parties is apparent from what has been stated above.

The petitioner accordingly is directed to surrender before the learned court below within a period of four weeks and on such surrender, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned C.J.M., Dhanbad in connection with Bank More (Bhuli) P.S.  Order No.02 Dated- 14.09.2020 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Learned senior counsel for the petitioner personally undertakes to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking of the learned senior counsel for the petitioner, the defects pointed out by the stamp reporter are ignored for the present. 
 Apprehending his arrest, the petitioner has moved this Court for grant of privilege of anticipatory bail in connection with Borio (J) P.S. Case No.56 of 2020 registered undersections 406/120(B)/34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 Heard the learned senior counsel for the petitioner and learned Addl. P.P. for the State. 
 The Learned senior counsel for the petitioner submits that the allegation against the petitioner is false. It is further submitted that the co-accused of the petitioner/complainant has entered into compromise and the co-accused Panchu Pramanik has agreed to partly pay the amount of Rs.7,00,000/- and the remaining he is ready and willing to pay, in this respect learned senior counsel for the petitioner draws the attention of this court to the copy of the perition dated 26.08.2020 jointly filed before S.D.J.M., Sahebganj in connection with Borio (J) Case No. 56 of 2020. It is next submitted that the said co-accused is liable to pay the amount and the petitioner has no complicity in that and there is no allegation of any dishonest intention on the part of the petitioner at any point of time. Hence, it is submitted that the petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail.

It is submitted by learned counsel for the petitioners that the allegation against the petitioners is false and the petitioners have not taken any money whatsoever and there is absolutely no document in support of the claim of the informant that the petitioners have taken money from him. case title: Sunil Kr. Choudhary @ Pasi @ Sunil ... vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
Sunil Kr. Choudhary @ Pasi @ Sunil Kumar Choudhary @ Sunil Pasi ... ... Petitioner Versus The State of Jharkhand ... ... Opposite Party With B.A. No. 5131 of 2020 
 --------- 
 Ravi Kumar Thakur @ Ravi Thakur ... ... Petitioner Versus The State of Jharkhand ... ... Opposite Party 
 --------- 
 CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through- Video Conferencing 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. Pratiush Lala, Advocate For the State : Mr. Ravi Prakash, Spl. P.P. 
 --------- 
 03/14.09.2020 Heard Mr. Pratiush Lala, learned counsel for the petitioners and Mr. Ravi Prakash, learned Spl. P.P. for the State. 
 Since a common prayer has been made in both these applications the same are being disposed of by this common order. 
 The petitioners are accused in connection with Special (NDPS) Case No. 11/2019, arising out of Nirsa P.S. Case No. 179/2019. 
 It has been alleged that 39.300 Kg. of ganja was recovered from a Tavera vehicle. 
 Mr. Pratiush Lala, learned counsel for the petitioners submits that there is no material available on record which would indicate the presence of the petitioners along with the contraband articles in the Tavera vehicle. It has been stated that once the C.I.D. had taken over investigation the statement of one Santosh Kr. Singh was recorded u/s 164Cr.P.C. and the version which he has given does not co-relate with the case. It has also been stated that even if the statement of Santosh Kr. Singh recorded u/s 164Cr.P.C. is taken to be true even than the petitioners cannot be prosecuted since their names are conspicuously absent in the-2-said statement. It has been stated that the petitioners are in custody since 06.06.2020. 
 Mr. Ravi Prakash, learned Spl. P.P. for the State has stated that initially these petitioners along with the other accused persons had got falsely implicated one Chiranjeet Ghosh as being the person who was involved in the transportation of ganja. Subsequently however in course of investigation the innocence of Chiranjeet Ghosh had come to the fore and therefore FRT was submitted in his favour. Learned Spl. P.P. submits that the C.I.D. had taken over the investigation of the case and in course of investigation it was detected from the call records regarding the presence of the petitioners at the place of occurrence. Learned Spl. P.P. further submits that it is these petitioners who are the master minds behind the transportation of contraband articles and in such circumstances these applications deserves to be rejected. 
 On consideration of the arguments advanced by the learned counsels for the parties and on perusal of the case diary it appears that the primary witness of the C.I.D. is Santosh Kr. Singh whose statement was recorded u/s 164Cr.P.C. and who has not named either of these petitioners in his said statement. The implication of the petitioners appear to be on account of their presence found at the place of occurrence through the call records. The counter affidavit which has been filed by the learned Spl. P.P. based on the investigation carried out by the C.I.D. does not appear to contain any concrete material which would indicate that the petitioners were someway concerned with the Tavera vehicle or the ganja which was being transported in the said vehicle. 
 The petitioners have already remained in custody for more than three months and considering the entire facts as narrated above, they are directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand only) each with two sureties of the like amount each, to the-3-satisfaction of learned Sessions Judge/Special Judge, Dhanbad in connection with Special (NDPS) Case No. 11/2019, arising out of Nirsa P.S. Case No. 179/2019. 
 (R. Mukhopadhyay, J.) Alok/-
