case title: Fauda Munda vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 ----- 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners has submitted that he may be allowed to make necessary correction with regard to name of the Act, as mentioned in Para-1 of the bail application. 
 Prayer is allowed. 
 Let the said correction be made after 30 days after physical court starts. Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of the same. Heard, learned counsel, Mr. Ankit Vishal assisted by learned counsel for the petitioners, Mr. Ajay Kumar Sah and learned counsel for the State, Mrs. Ruby Pandey. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners has submitted that petitioners have prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Namkum P.S. Case No.274 of 2019, corresponding to S.T. No.78 of 2020 for the offence registered underSections 302/34IPC and Sections 3/4 of Prevention of Witch (Daain) Practices Act. Learned counsel for the petitioners has submitted that five persons have been named in the FIR including these two petitioners. He has further submitted that except suspicion, there is nothing against the petitioners. Learned counsel for the petitioners has further submitted that as per the FIR, it is alleged that younger son of petitioner No.1, Fauda Munda was ill, as such, they were apprehending that the deceased was playing black magic and it is alleged that these petitioners came to the house of the informant in-search of the deceased, but did not find her and subsequently no body has seen these petitioners with the deceased nor there was any eye-witness to the occurrence and on recovery of dead-body, an FIR has been lodged against five named accused persons on suspicion. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners has further submitted that the Police has recorded statement of the informant at Para-7 of the case diary, confessional statement of the co-accused, Khudia Munda at Para-29 of the case diary and post- mortem report at Para-42 of the case diary, but there is no material with regard to any recovery pursuant to the confession, as such, confession before the Police is not-2-admissible under the law. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners has further submitted that petitioners are in custody since 28.09.2019, as such, petitioners may be enlarged on bail as the case is under trial vide S.T. No.78 of 2020 and the charge has already been framed. Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that these petitioners were searching the deceased and they have confessed their guilt. From the post-mortem report, it appears that the deceased was brutally killed, as such, these petitioners may not be enlarged on regular bail who might have involvement in commission of the offence. 
 After hearing, learned counsel for the parties and perusing the materials brought on record and looking to the facts and circumstances of the case and since the petitioners have been apprehended on suspicion and they were named in the FIR on suspicion, as such, this Court is inclined to grant Bail to the petitioners. Accordingly, petitioners (Fauda Munda and Rushu Munda), are directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned A.J.C- XV-cum-FTC (CAW), Ranchi in connection with Namkum P.S. Case No.274 of 2019, corresponding to S.T. No.78 of 2020 on the following conditions:- 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be deponent/parivikar of the present case namely, Kitni Kumari, D/o Fauda Munda, R/o- Village- Barudih, P.O.- Tetri, P.S.- Namkum, District- Ranchi (Jharkhand), who has furnished photocopy of her UID Card bearing No.5626 5355 9655 before this Court in the bail application. Office is directed to send photo copy of the UID Card bearing No. 5626 5355 9655 of deponent along with this order to the court below so as to verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Petitioners are also directed to appear before the learned trial court on each and every date till conclusion of the trial. 
 (iii) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioners only after their medical check-up. 
 (iv) The Civil Surgeon, Ranchi is directed to medically examine the petitioners at the time of their release and if requires, petitioners shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, they shall be released forthwith, if not wanted in any other case. 
 (v) Petitioners shall also comply with all the guidelines issued by the Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as the country is passing through Pandemic of Covid-19. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Awadhesh Kumar Singh vs Steel Authority Of India Ltd.
all_text:
For the Petitioner : Mr. Shashank Shekhar, Advocate For the Respondents : Mr. Vijay Kant Dubey, Advocate 
 ----- 
 Order No. 06 Dated: 15.09.2020 The present writ petition is taken up today through Video conferencing. 
 At the request of the learned counsel for the petitioner, the defects as pointed out by the office are ignored. 
 The present writ petition has been filed for issuance of direction upon the respondents to pay the dues of Rs. 8,46,227/- for the period 21.05.2014 to 20.04.2015, Rs. 8,48,584/- for the period 21.05.2015 to 20.04.2016 and Rs. 4,21,934/- for the period 21.04.2016 to 19.11.2016 in relation to the emergency works of maintenance of railway tracks executed by the petitioner in view of the safety of the tracks on the direction of the respondents. 
 2. Heard the learned counsel for the parties and perused the content of the writ petition. 
 3. The learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner had been executing the work of maintenance of railway tracks with the respondents since 2006. The contract period for the same was valid till 20.05.2014. Since a proposal for extending the contract period was under process, the petitioner continued to work2for the abovementioned period on existing terms and conditions of contract by way of oral instruction of the authorities of Raw Materials Division, Bhawnathpur Group of Mines, Bhawnathpur, Steel Authority of India Ltd. and in anticipation of issuance of work order to that effect. The petitioner had again been awarded the work of maintenance of railway tracks from Meral Gram to Bhawnathpur Railway Siding by way of work order dated 20.01.2017 for the period 20.11.2016 to 19.11.2017, however, on completion of the aforesaid works, no payment was made to him. The petitioner made several representations before the respondent no. 5 - the Deputy General Manager, Raw Materials Division, Bhawnathpur Group of Mines, Bhawnathpur, Steel Authority of India Ltd. in the year 2016 and 2017 requesting inter alia to make due payment to him for the said work done, however, the same were not responded. Subsequently, the petitioner filed an application under Right toInformation Act, 2005 before the respondent no. 5 on 25.11.2017, in response to which the petitioner was informed vide letter dated 30.01.2018 that the works of repair/maintenance of railway tracks from Bhawnathpur to Meral Gram for the period 21.05.2014 to 19.11.2017 were awarded to M/s Awadhesh Kumar Singh (the petitioner). It was also informed vide letter dated 30.01.2018 that no payment was made in relation to the said works. 
 4. Mr. Vijay Kant Dubey, the learned counsel for the respondents, submits that admittedly, no work order has been issued in favour of the petitioner for executing the works in question. Only by replying to certain information sought by the petitioner under Right toInformation Act, 2005, it cannot be said that the dues claimed by the petitioner in the writ petition has been admitted by the respondents. However, if the petitioner prefers a fresh representation before the respondent no. 4 - the General Manager, Raw Materials Division, Kuteshwar Limestone Mines, Katni (M.P.), Steel Authority of India Ltd., the petitioner's claim will be considered and appropriate decision will be taken in this regard. 
 5. Having heard the learned counsel for the parties and keeping in view the nature of prayer made in the present writ3petition, without entering into the merit of the claim of the petitioner, he is given liberty to prefer a fresh representation before the respondent no. 4 along with the supporting documents in this regard. On receipt of the said representation, the respondent no. 4 after calling for the relevant records and on making due enquiry, if so required, as well as on providing adequate opportunity of hearing to the petitioner/his representative, shall take an informed decision within a period of four months from the date of filing of the representation. 
 6. The writ petition is accordingly disposed of with aforesaid liberty and direction. 
 (Rajesh Shankar, J.) Manish/AFR

case title: Sunil Kumar Sah vs Bir Singh
issues: ['Section 5 in The Limitation Act, 1963']
all_text:
I.A.No. 1089 of 2020 04/ 15.09.2020 In view of outbreak of COVID-19 pandemic, case has been taken up through Video Conferencing. Concerned lawyers have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through Video Conferencing today at 11:15 A.M. onwards. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 The instant Interlocutory Application has been filed underSection 5of the Limitation Act, 1961. 
 It has been submitted by the learned counsel appearing for petitioner that there is delay of about 12 days in filing the instant CMP. He further submits that sufficient cause has been shown in para Nos. 3 onwards. 
 In view of the submissions of the parties and averment made in para Nos. 3 onwards of the instant interlocutory application, the Court is fully satisfied to condone the delay of 12 days in filing instant CMP and as such, is hereby condoned. 
 Accordingly, I.A. No. 1089 of 2020 stands allowed. 
 C.M.P. No. 362 of 2019 As prayed, defect as pointed out by the office, is hereby ignored for the present. 
 The instant Civil Miscellaneous Petition has been filed for restoration of M.A. No. 51 of 2016 to its original file, which has been dismissed for default on 04.04.2019 on account of non-compliance of order dated 28.03.2019 passed by this Court. 
 Mr. Manoj Tandon, learned counsel for the petitioner submits that petitioner has a good case on merit and inadvertently, the order of this Court could not be complied with. It is further submitted by the learned counsel for the petitioner that the aforesaid order shall be complied within three weeks' from today. 
 In view of the submission of the learned counsel for the petitioner and averment made in para Nos. 3 onwards of the instant CMP, M.A. No. 51 of 2016 is restored to its original file, with the condition that the order dated 28.03.2019 passed in M.A. No.51 of 2016 shall be complied within four weeks from today. 
 Accordingly, the instant C.M.P. stands allowed with the condition as above. 
 (Dr. S.N. Pathak, J.) punit/

case title: Prabhat Singh vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 164 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mrs. Vani Kumari, Advocate. 
 Mr. Ashish Kumar, Advocate. 
 For the State : Mr. Anup Pawan Topno, A.P.P. 
 --------- 
 02/Dated: 15/09/2020 Heard, learned counsel Mrs. Vani Kumari assisted by learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Ashish Kumar. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that defect nos. 9 (i) to (iii), as per Stamp Reporting dated 19.06.2020, have not been removed, which he undertakes to remove within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard, as it is a regular bail application of the petitioner, who is in custody since 18.02.2020. 
 Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the instant bail application on merits, but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defect(s) within 30 days after the physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defect(s). 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Chandil P.S. Case No. 42/2020, corresponding to POCSO Case No. 19/2020 for the offence registered underSections 366AI.P.C. and Sections 4/8 of POCSO Act. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has love affair with the victim, who is grand-daughter of the informant and both eloped on 09.02.2020, but the F.I.R. has been lodged on 16.02.2020 and under duress the statement of the victim has been recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C. though the victim is a-2-major girl, as such, petitioner, who is in custody since 18.02.2020, may be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. Anup Pawan Topno, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that a minor girl, aged about 14 years, has been forcibly kidnapped by this petitioner, which is apparent from the statement of the victim recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C. Since there is a serious allegation against the petitioner, he does not deserve to be enlarged on bail, as such, this application may be rejected. 
 After hearing learned counsel for the parties and on the basis of material brought on record and looking into age of the victim as well as her statement recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C., this Court is not inclined to grant bail to the petitioner. 
 Accordingly, the instant bail application is hereby rejected. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Lalita Devi vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 437 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 25 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 307 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 149 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Ashraf Ansari, Advocate. For the State : Mr. Bishambar Shastri, A.P.P. 
 --------- 
 03/Dated: 15/09/2020 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Ashraf Ansari. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that defect nos. 9 (i) to (iii), as per Stamp Reporting dated 19.06.2020, have not been removed, which he undertakes to remove within 30 days after the physical court starts and the bail application may be heard, as it is a regular bail application of the petitioner, who is in custody since 14.08.2019. 
 Considering the same, this Court is inclined to hear the instant bail application on merits, but with condition that petitioner shall remove the defect(s) within 30 days after the physical court starts. 
 Joint Registrar (Judicial) is directed to ensure the compliance of this order after the physical court starts so as to remove the defect(s). 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner Lalita Devi has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Kisko P.S. Case No. 43/2018 corresponding to G.R. No. 224/2019 for the offence registered underSections 147,148,149,307I.P.C.,Sections 25(1-b)a, 26, 27, 35 of theArms Act, Section 3 / 4 of Explosive Substance Act, Sections 10 / 13 of U.A.P.A. Act and Section 17 of C.L.A. Act. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that F.I.R. has been lodged against eight named accused persons and the name of petitioner transpired in the confessional statement though nothing has been recovered from possession of this petitioner. It is alleged that petitioner is the wife of MCC Zonal Commander, Rabindra-2-Ganjhu and has criminal antecedent related to Jobang P.S. Case No.33/2018, as such, petitioner has been made accused in this case and she is in custody since 14.08.2019. The co-accused, Kudus Ansari has been enlarged on bail by Coordinate Bench of this court vide order dated 21.10.2019 passed in B.A. No.9256/2019 and another co-accused, Sanicharwa Kisan has been enlarged on bail vide order dated 22.10.2019 passed in B.A. No.9433/2019, as such, petitioner may also be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. Bishambar Shastri, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that this petitioner is the wife of MCC Zonal Commander, Rabindra Ganjhu and she has involvement in demanding the levy as transpired from paragraph-55 of the case diary, as such, petitioner may not be enlarged on bail. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties and looking into the fact and circumstances of the case as the petitioner is a lady and comes under the proviso ofSection 437Cr.P.C. and other male co-accused, Kudus Ansari and Sanicharwa Kisan have been enlarged on bail, this petitioner is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each in connection with Kisko P.S. Case No. 43/2018 corresponding to G.R. No. 224/2019 to the satisfaction of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Lohardaga on the following conditions: 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be the deponent / pairvikar of the present case namely, Kanchan Bogta, son of Aghnu Bhogta, resident of Village - Mainichapar, P.O. - Nawagarh, P.S. - Sikidiri, District - Ranchi, who has furnished photocopy of his UID Card bearing number 9575 0178 9773 before this Court in the bail application. 
 Office is directed to send the photocopy of UID Card bearing no. 9575 0178 9773 of deponent alongwith this order to the court below so as to verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Another bailor shall be close relative of the petitioner i.e. father / mother / son / brother. 
 (iii) As her husband is alleged to be the Zonal Commander of MCC, petitioner shall appear before the trial court on each and every date till conclusion of the trial. 
 (iv) Petitioner shall also appear before the Officer-in-Charge, Kisko P.S. on 1st Monday of each Calendar Month till conclusion of the trial. 
 (v) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioner only after her medical check-up. 
 (vi) The Civil Surgeon, Lohardaga is directed to medically examine the petitioner at the time of her release and if she is infected with corona virus, she shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, she shall be released forthwith, if not wanted in any other case. 
 (vii) The petitioner shall follow all the guidelines issued by the Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as presently Country is passing through pandemic of Covid-19. 
 Accordingly, the instant bail application is allowed. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Biju Munda vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 161 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 201 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Anil Kumar Ganjhu, Advocate. For the State : Mr. Abhay Kumar Tiwari, A.P.P. 
 --------- 
 05/Dated: 15/09/2020 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Anil Kumar Ganjhu. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner Biju Munda has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Karra P.S. Case No. 80/2016 corresponding to G.R. No. 410/2016 (S.T. No. 144/2019) for the offence registered underSections 302,201/34I.P.C. and Section 17 of C.L.A. Act. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner is not named in the F.I.R. nor there is any eye witness to the occurrence, rather an F.I.R. has been lodged against unknown as the husband of the informant has been killed. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that in the counter affidavit at paragraphs-10, the State has referred the statement of Madan Nayak and Manoj Nayak, who have stated underSection 161Cr.P.C. that this petitioner has given threatening to Seva Nayak, father of the deceased by saying that he will be sent to the same place where his son has gone, as such, there is no legal material with regard to the complicity of the petitioner in the alleged offence and as such, petitioner, who is in custody since 28.03.2019, may be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. Abhay Kumar Tiwari, has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that this petitioner has three criminal antecedents of similar nature and this is fourth case, if he is enlarged on bail, there is every likelihood that he will tamper-2-the evidence, abscond from the trial and he will come up with another offence, as he has criminal antecedents, as such, this court may not grant bail to the petitioner. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties, looking into the materials collected during the investigation, since there is no eye- witness to the occurrence, as such, considering the period of custody since 28.03.2019, the petitioner is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each in connection with Karra P.S. Case No. 80/2016 corresponding to G.R. No. 410/2016 (S.T. No. 144/2019) to the satisfaction of learned Distrct & Additional Sessions Judge, 1st, Khunti on the following conditions: 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be the deponent / Pairvikar of the present case namely, Bahalen Devi, wife of Chudata Munda, resident of Village - Sangor, P.O. - Sangor, P.S. - Karra, District - Khunti, who has furnished photocopy of her UID Card bearing number 2704 0577 7359 before this Court in the bail application. 
 Office is directed to send the photocopy of UID Card bearing no. 2704 0577 7359 of deponent alongwith this order to the court below so as to verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Another bailor shall be close relative of the petitioner i.e. father / mother / son / wife / brother. 
 (iii) Petitioner shall not influence the witnesses and shall appear before the trial court on each and every date till conclusion of the trial. 
 If implication of the petitioner is further made in any case, State Authority is at liberty to file application for cancellation of bail. 
 (iv) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioner only after his medical check-up. 
 (v) The Civil Surgeon, Khunti is directed to medically examine the petitioner at the time of his release and if he is infected with corona virus, he shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, he shall be released forthwith, if not wanted in any other case. 
 (vi) The petitioner shall follow all the guidelines issued by the Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as presently Country is passing through pandemic of Covid-19. 
 Accordingly, the instant bail application is allowed. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Raju Saw @ Raj Kumar Gupta vs State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 482 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 83 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 82 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 341 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
which has been held through video conferencing today at 11.15 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 This case was listed/ supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board for passing an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the office. 
 Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their Clerks in the Court, this court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner prays to ignore the defect and take up the matter on merits. 
 Defects stand ignored. 
 In this application, the petitioner has challenged the order dated 03.08.2005, by which cognizance of the offence punishable underSections 147,148,323&341of the Indian Penal Code has been taken and thereafter, summon has been issued to him. 
 After 15 years of order taking cognizance, the same is being challenged. From the order sheet, which has been annexed, I find that the petitioner was well aware of the proceeding as earlier also he approached this Court by filing Cr. M.P. No. 1902 of 2012, challenging the order by which coercive steps was taken against him underSections 82&83Cr. P.C. He got relief from this Court also in the said case. This clearly shows that the petitioner was well aware of the proceedings. In this 15 years, he did not even chose to challenge the order taking cognizance and now after 15 years he woke up from slumber and challenged the order taking cognizance by filing this application. This is a very serious laches on the part of the petitioner. 
 This court feels that extraordinary jurisdiction and discretionary jurisdiction of this Court cannot be used in favour of the petitioner, who approached this Court after 15 years knowing fully about the proceedings. Since there is serious laches on the part of the petitioner, I am not inclined to exercise my jurisdiction underSection 482of the Code of Criminal Procedure, whereby order taking cognizance dated 03.08.2005, has been challenged by the petitioner after 15 years. Accordingly, this application stands dismissed. 
 The Trial Court is directed to proceed and conclude the trial at the earliest. 
 (Ananda Sen, J) Mukund/-cp.3

case title: Prem Kumar @ Prem Raut vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): (R. Mukhopadhyay, J.), (Rupees Ten Thousand only), (Galfarbari O.P.), (2)
all_text:
1. Prem Kumar @ Prem Raut 
 2. Avinash Singh @ Avinash 
 3. Gaurav Dubey @ Gaurav Kumar Dubey 
 4. Dinesh Raut @ Padai Raut @ Dinesh Kumar ... ... Petitioners Versus The State of Jharkhand ... ... Opposite Party 
 ------- 
 CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through- Video Conferencing 
 ------- 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. R.S. Mazumdar, Sr. Advocate For the State : Mr. Suraj Verma, A.P.P. 
 ------- 
 02/15.09.2020 Heard Mr. R.S. Mazumdar, learned senior counsel for the petitioners and Mr. Suraj Verma, learned A.P.P. for the State. 
 Learned senior counsel for the petitioners submits that so far as the petitioner nos. 2 and 3 are concerned they have already been arrested and this application accordingly has become infructuous as against them. 
 This application stands dismissed as infructuous as against petitioner nos. 2 and 3. 
 So far as the petitioner nos. 1 and 4 are concerned they are apprehending their arrest in connection with Chirkunda (Galfarbari O.P.) P.S. Case No. 80 of 2020. 
 The informant was molested in her shop by the accused persons and on raising a protest she and her son were alleged to have been assaulted and a gold chain worth Rs. 70-80 thousand was snatched. 
 So far as the petitioner no. 1 is concerned he seems to have a criminal antecedent and considering the same, I am not inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner no. 1, which is hereby rejected. 
 However, so far as the petitioner no. 4, is concerned, the allegations being general and omnibus in nature and there is nothing to show that he is involved in any other case, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the-2-petitioner no. 4. The petitioner no. 4 is accordingly directed to surrender before the learned court below within a period of four weeks and on such surrender, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Dhanbad in connection with Chirkunda (Galfarbari O.P.) P.S. Case No. 80 of 2020, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands disposed off. 
 (R. Mukhopadhyay, J.) Alok/-

case title: Shobhit Sharma vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.), (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand), (2)
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 307 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 353 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 325 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY 
 ------ 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. A.K. Das, Advocate For the State : Mr. S.K. Srivastava, Addl. P.P. 
 ------ 
 Order No.02 Dated- 15.09.2020 Apprehending his arrest, the petitioner has moved this Court for grant of privilege of anticipatory bail in connection with Netarhat P.S. Case No.06 of 2019 registered undersections 341/323/325/353/307/34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Learned counsel for the petitioner personally undertakes to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking of the learned counsel for the petitioner, the defects pointed out by the stamp reporter are ignored for the present. 
 The Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the allegation against the petitioner is that the co-accused persons used the car of the petitioner and were consuming liquor and when the officer in-charge challenged them, they assaulted the officer in- charge of the police station causing injuries to him. It is, further, submitted that the allegation against the petitioner are all false. It is also submitted that petitioner is not named in the F.I.R. nor the apprehended co-accused persons have taken the name of the petitioner. It is then submitted that the petitioner is ready and willing to pay Rs. 20,000/- as ad interim victim compensation to the informant without prejudice to his defence in this case and undertakes to cooperate with the investigation of the case. Hence, it is submitted that the petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. 
 Learned Addl. P.P. opposes the prayer for grant of anticipatory bail. 
 Considering the submissions of the counsels and the fact as discussed above, I am of the opinion that it is a fit case where the above named petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. Hence, in the event of his arrest or surrender within a period of four weeks from the date of this order, he shall be released on bail on depositing a demand draft of Rs. 20,000/- as ad interim victim compensation in favour of informant and on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Additional Sessions Judge -III, Latehar, in connection with Netarhat P.S. Case No.06 of 2019 with the condition that the petitioner will cooperate with the investigation of the case and appear before the Investigating Officer as and when noticed by him and will furnish his mobile number and a copy of his Aadhar Card in the court below with the undertaking that he will not change his mobile number during the pendency of the case subject to the conditions laid down under section 438 (2) Cr. P.C. 
 In case, the petitioner deposits the ad interim victim compensation amount, the court below is directed to issue notice to the informant and hand over the said demand draft to him, after proper identification. 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Sonu/Gunjan-

case title: Parmeshwar Yadav vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
1.Parmeshwar Yadav 
 2.Shambhu Yadav 
 3.Bhola Yadav @ Bhola Mahto 
 4.Rajendra Yadav 
 5.Ganesh Yadav 
 6.Ashok Yadav 
 7.Rajesh Yadav ... ... Petitioners Versus The State of Jharkhand ... ... Opposite Party 
 ------- 
 CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through- Video Conferencing 
 ------- 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. Prakash Chandra, Advocate Mr. H.S. Pandey, Advocate For the State : Mr. Bishambhar Shastri, A.P.P. 
 ------- 
 02/15.09.2020 Heard Mr. Prakash Chandra, learned counsel appearing for the petitioners and Mr. Bishambhar Shastri, learned A.P.P. for the State. 
 The petitioners have prayed for grant of anticipatory bail, as they are apprehending their arrest in connection with Devipur P.S. Case No. 96/2020. 
 Mr. Prakash Chandra, learned counsel for the petitioners, at the outset, submits that he is withdrawing this application so far as the petitioner no. 2 is concerned since he has already been arrested. 
 In view of the said submission this application stands dismissed as withdrawn as against petitioner no. 2. 
 So far as the rest petitioners are concerned the allegation reveals that while the informant and his son were digging a plinth the accused persons who were variously armed had assaulted them. 
 Specific allegation of assault apart from the petitioner no. 2 whose case has already been withdrawn by the learned counsel for the petitioners also rests upon petitioner nos. 1 and 3 as they had assaulted the informant with a sword and bhala. 
 In such circumstances, therefore, I am not inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner nos. 1 and 3. 
 However, so far as the petitioner nos. 4 to 7 are concerned the allegations are general and omnibus in nature. 
 In such view of the matter, therefore, petitioner nos. 4 to 7 are directed to surrender before the learned court below within a period of four weeks and on such surrender, they shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand only) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned C.J.M., Deoghar in connection with Devipur P.S. Case No. 96/2020, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands disposed off. 
 (R. Mukhopadhyay, J.) Alok/-

case title: Rajan Kumar vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 438 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
For the Opposite Party : Mr. Satish Prasad, A.P.P. 
 --- 
 2/15.09.2020 Heard the parties. 
 The petitioner is apprehending his arrest in connection with Argora P.S. Case No. 300 of 2016 corresponding to G. R. No. 5204 of 2016. 
 The informant is in the business of development of land by constructing multi-storied building. It has been alleged that the accused persons had approached the informant for developing 9 Kathas of land of which they were the joint owners. A development agreement was entered into and the accused persons had received Rs. 12,55,000/- from the informant who also spent Rs. 8 lacs in primary development of the said land. It has been alleged that the informant later on came to know that the accused persons had entered into an agreement for sale with one Sushil Kumar Gupta and had also taken Rs. 1,65,90,000/- from him. 
 It has been stated by the learned senior counsel for the petitioner while referring to the development agreement that neither the petitioner was the signatory to the said agreement nor in the Schedule D which is with respect to the payment received by the accused persons, the petitioner's signature is evident. Learned senior counsel further submits that the main accused in the present case are Amitabh Sahay and Ashim Kumar who were dealing with the informant and in fact they had received certain amount from the informant which would appear from the Schedule D of the agreement and on instruction, Mr. A. K. Kashyap, submits that the amount has already been returned back to the informant. He has further stated that on being noticed underSection 41Aof Cr.P.C., both Amitabh Sahay and Ashim Kumar have accepted-2-the responsibility of the entire dealing with respect to the transfer of land in favour of the informant. 
 Learned A.P.P. for the State opposed the prayer for anticipatory bail. 
 It appears from the development agreement itself that although there are 5 coloums, but the signature of the petitioner is conspicuously absent in the same. In fact the development agreement seems to have been signed by Amitabh Sahay and Ashim Kumar and in the Schedule D of the agreement which is the amount which has been received on account of the said sale deeds, once again Amitabh Sahay and Ashim Kumar who have received the amount had accorded their acknowledgement regarding receipt of the said amount. The signature of the petitioner also does not find place in the Schedule D of the agreement. 
 Learned A.P.P. has not controverted the contents of the development agreement brought on record by the petitioner. 
 Thus, there appears to be no documentary evidence that would indicate that the petitioner was a party to the said agreement and being in receipt of the certain amount consequent to entering into said agreement. 
 Regard being had to the aforesaid facts, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. 
 Accordingly, the petitioner above named is directed to surrender in the court below within four weeks and pray for bail, and in that event, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Ten Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each, to the satisfaction of learned Judicial Magistrate, Ranchi in connection with Argora P.S. Case No. 300 of 2016 corresponding to G. R. No. 5204 of 2016, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Codeof Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J) R. Shekhar Cp 3

case title: Raja Singh @ Kamlesh Kumar Singh vs State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 364 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
which has been held through video conferencing today at 11.15 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 This case was listed/ supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board for passing an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the office. 
 Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their Clerks in the Court, this court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner prays to ignore the defect and take up the matter on merits. 
 Defects stand ignored. 
 Heard the parties. 
 The petitioner, in this application, has challenged the order dated 10.12.2019, by which summon has been issued to him, as the cognizance was already taken underSections 364,302/34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 I have gone through the impugned order. From the impugned order I find that the police submitted final form in favour of this petitioner finding no material against him and he was not charge sheeted. But the court below differed with the finding recorded in the final form and, thereafter, issued summon to this petitioner. What are the materials to summon this petitioner, has not been mentioned in the impugned order by which summon has been issued. Some paragraphs of the case diary have been referred, but what are the prima-facie materials to summon the petitioner has not been mentioned. The court has to apply its mind carefully while issuing summons when differing with the police report. The impugned order doesnot reflect any reason for differing. 
 Considering the aforesaid fact and in view of the order passed by this Court in the case of "Amresh Kumar Dhiraj & Ors.- versus- State of Jharkhand & Anr, reported in 2020 (1) JLJR 199 (Jhr.)", I am inclined to allow this application. Accordingly, this application is allowed. The impugned summoning order dated 10.12.2019, passed by the Sub-Divisional Judicial Magistrate, Rajmahal in G.R. No. 21 of 2010, whereby the petitioner has been summoned, is, hereby, set aside. The matter is remitted to the Court below to pass a fresh speaking order stating as to what are the materials to summon the petitioner in this case. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition stands allowed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J) Mukund/-cp.3

case title: Kavita Devi vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 107 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
1. Kavita Devi. 
 2. Jirauti Devi @ Jira Kunwar. 
 3. Dipu Chandravanshi @ Dipu Ram. 
 4. Pintu Chandravanshi @ Pipu Kumar Ram. ......Petitioners Versus The State of Jharkhand. .....Opposite Party 
 -------- 
 Coram: THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 The petitioners apprehend their arrest in connection with Manjhion P.S. Case No. 46 of 2020. 
 It has been alleged that on 27.4.2020, the accused persons started abusing the informant under the influence of liquor. On protest, they had assaulted the informant and her husband, which resulted in their suffering from several injuries. Sudhir Kumar and Banshi Ram had tried to intervene and they were assaulted with a tangi. 
 It has been submitted by the learned counsel for the petitioners that infact there was a free fight between both the sides and one Umesh Ram who appears to be the father of petitioner nos. 3 and 4 had also instituted a case against the informant party being Manjhion P.S. Case No. 45 of 2020. It has further been submitted that in the said case, one of the injured-Baban Ram, who happens to be the husband of petitioner 2 had succumbed to his injury. It has also been submitted that so far as petitioners are concerned, the allegations are general and omnibus in nature and specific allegation has been levelled against Umesh Ram and Umesh Chandravanshi. 
 Learned A.P.P. has opposed the prayer for anticipatory bail of the petitioners. 
 It appears that there has been a case and counter case between the parties on account of a free fight between them. It further appears that there is a previous enmity between both the sides relating to a land dispute and for which a proceeding undersection 107Cr.P.C. was also pending. As stated above, the husband of petitioner no. 2 had already succumbed to his injury on account of the assault committed upon him from the side of the informant party. 
 Regard being had to the aforesaid facts, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioners. 
 Accordingly, the petitioners, named above, are directed to surrender in the court below within a period of four weeks from today and pray for regular bail, and in that event, they will be enlarged on bail, on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- ( Ten thousand only) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st class, Garhwa in connection with Manjhion P.S. Case No. 46 of 2020, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J) Rakesh/-

case title: Rajesh Ray vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 161 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Onkar Nath Tiwary. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner seeks permission of this court to make necessary correction in paragraph-5 of the petition, where this petitioner has been wrongly cited as mother-in-law, though this petitioner Rajesh Ray is husband of the deceased. 
 Prayer is allowed. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner is permitted to make necessary correction in paragraph-5 of the petition. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner Rajesh Ray has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Hansdiha P.S. Case No. 43/2019 for the offence registered under Section 304(B)/34 I.P.C. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that as per the investigation, there is no allegation against this petitioner nor any person has stated underSection 161Cr.P.C. that they have either seen this petitioner torturing the wife for demand of dowry, rather his wife has consumed poison mistakenly and due to which, she became ill and taken to the hospital, but on the way to hospital, she died. This information was given to the informant, but even then, an F.I.R. was lodged. The deceased has no external or internal injury in the post-mortem report, as such, petitioner, who is in custody since 10.05.2019, may be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. S. P. Jha, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that all the four ingredients for constituting an offence underSection 304B-2-IPCis available on record. The presumption is against the petitioner as perSection 113Bof the Indian Evidence Act, as such, petitioner has to discharge his onus. 
 Learned counsel for the State has further submitted that in this case, case diary, postmortem report and FSL report are necessary for proper adjudication of the bail application, as such, State may be granted four weeks' time to file detail counter affidavit on the basis of aforesaid documents. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties, State counsel is granted four weeks' time to file detail counter affidavit on the basis of post-mortem report, FSL report and the material collected during investigation. 
 Put up this case after four weeks. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Ranchi District Bar Association vs The Jharkhand Urja Vikas Nigam ...
all_text:
For the Petitioner : Mr. D.K. Pathak, Advocate Mr. Saket Upadhyay, Advocate Mrs. Sweta Rani, Advocate For the Respondents : Mr. Manoj Kumar, Sr. SC, JUVNL 
 ----- 
 Order No. 03 Dated: 15.09.2020 The present writ petition is taken up today through Video conferencing. 
 The present writ petition has been filed for issuance of direction upon the respondents to issue revised energy bill after deleting the components of DPS in view of the fact that the respondents have raised wrongful energy bill against the petitioner and have charged DPS thereon and after much persuasion, the respondents have rectified the bill, however, DPS has not been removed even after correction of the energy bill. Further prayer has been made for issuance of direction upon the respondents to fix the payment of the corrected energy bill on suitable number of instalments considering the fact that huge amount has been accumulated due to raising of wrong energy bill and laches on the part of the respondents in revision of the same in accordance with law. 
 At the outset, Mr. Manoj Kumar, the learned Sr. SC, Jharkhand Urja Vikas Nigam Limited, submits that the present writ2petition is not maintainable in view of alternative remedy available to the petitioner to approach the Vidyut Upbhokta Shikayat Nivaran Forum, Ranchi created by the respondent-Jharkhand Vidyut Vitran Nigam Limited (JUVNL) underSection 42(5)of the Electricity Act, 2003. 
 Having heard the learned counsel for the parties and keeping in view that the petitioner has an efficacious/alternative remedy of filing complaint before the Vidyut Upbhokta Shikayat Nivaran Forum, Ranchi created by the Jharkhand Vidyut Vitran Nigam Limited (JUVNL) underSection 42(5)of the Electricity Act, 2003 for redressal of its grievance, I am not inclined to entertain the writ petition. The same is accordingly dismissed as not maintainable at this stage. 
 The petitioner is, however, at liberty to approach the said forum for redressal of its grievance. If the petitioner prefers a complaint before the Vidyut Upbhokta Shikayat Nivaran Forum, Ranchi within fifteen days from today, the same shall be entertained by the said forum on its merit and be disposed of as early as possible, preferably within a period of three months from the date of filing of the complaint. 
 (Rajesh Shankar, J.) Manish

case title: M/S United Club Ltd. vs The Employees State Insurance ...
all_text:
CORAM HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RAJESH SHANKAR 
 ----- 
 29.06.2019 (Annexure-7 to the writ petition) passed by the Presiding Officer, Labour Court-cum-Employees State Insurance Court, Jamshedpur in E.S.I. Case No. 02 of 2007 wherein it has been held that the petitioner is covered under the provisions of theEmployees State Insurance Act, 1948 (hereinafter referred to as 'the Act, 1948') and has upheld the order dated 10.10.2007 passed by the respondent-Employees State Insurance Corporation underSection 45Aof the Act, 1948. 
 Mr. Ashutosh Anand, learned counsel for the respondents, raises a preliminary objection regarding the maintainability of the present writ petition in view of the provision of appeal underSection 82(2)of the Act, 1948. 
 Having heard learned counsel for the parties and keeping in view that the petitioner has got alternative/efficacious/statutory remedy of preferring an appeal underSection 82(2)of the Act, 1948 against the impugned judgment dated 29.06.2019 passed by the Presiding Officer, Labour Court-cum-Employees State Insurance Court, Jamshedpur, I am not inclined to entertain the present writ petition and the same is accordingly dismissed as not maintainable. 
 The petitioner is however at liberty to prefer an appeal underSection 82(2)of the Act, 1948 against the impugned judgment dated 29.06.2019 passed by the Presiding Officer, Labour Court-cum-Employees State Insurance Court, Jamshedpur in E.S.I. Case No. 02 of 2007. 
 Consequently, I.A. No. 11406/2019 also stands dismissed.

case title: Akhilesh Kumar Singh vs The State Of Jharkhand And Others
judges name(s): (Dr. Ravi Ranjan, C.J.), (Sujit Narayan Prasad, J.)
issues: ['Section 72 in The Bihar Reorganisation Act, 2000']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE THE CHIEF JUSTICE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE SUJIT NARAYAN PRASAD 
 ------ 
 For the Appellant: M/s. Ritu Kumar, Advocates For the State (487/18): Mr. Sachin Kumar, Addl. A.G.-II For the State (852/19) Mr. Arun Kumar Dubey, A.C. to GP-III For the State of Bihar: Mr. S.P. Roy, G.A.-Bihar 
 ------ 
 Oral Order 10/Dated: 15.09.2020 With consent of the parties, hearing of this matter has been done through video conferencing. They have no complaint about any audio and visual quality. 
 I.A. No.3267 of 2019 (in L.P.A. No. 487 of 2018) Learned counsel appearing for the appellant does not press this application for amendment in the memo of appeal in view of the another appeal having already been preferred by the appellant against the impugned order passed in the connected writ petition. 
 Hence, this Interlocutory Application being I.A. No.3267 of 2019 is dismissed as not pressed. 
 L.P.A. No. 487 of 2018 and L.P.A. No. 852 of 2019 Heard the learned counsel appearing for the appellant as also the respondents-State and the State of Bihar. 
 At the time of hearing of these appeals, learned counsel for the appellant has raised an issue that the order of punishment dated 07.08.2004 was without jurisdiction, inasmuch as the concerned-2-Officer (the writ petitioner) was already allocated the cadre of State of Jharkhand underSection 72of the Bihar Reorganisation Act, 2000. 
 Though this issue has not been raised before the learned Writ Court and does not find place even in the pleading, however, since the issue touches the issue of jurisdiction, which is purely a question of law based upon the admitted facts, this Court permits the writ petitioner to bring on record the order of the competent authority passed underSection 72of the Bihar Reorganisation Act, 2000. 
 Learned counsel for the State has stated that many documents brought on record in one of the appeals are missing in the other. 
 Hence, let the missing annexure be filed by the learned counsel for the appellant in the concerned appeal after serving a copy thereof to the learned counsel appearing for the State of Jharkhand and the State of Bihar. 
 As prayed, put up this case on 12th of October, 2020. 
 (Dr. Ravi Ranjan, C.J.) (Sujit Narayan Prasad, J.) Manoj/Raman

case title: Ritwik Mukherjee vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 420 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 379 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 461 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
1. Ritwik Mukherjee 
 2. Jayanti Mondal 
 3. Subrata Adhikary ... Petitioners 
 -versus- 
 for the State through Video Conferencing. The lawyers have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through Video Conferencing today at 11.15 a.m. They have no complain in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 2. This case was listed/supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board for seeking an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the Office. 
 3. Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their Clerks in the Court, this Court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 4. Counsel for the petitioners prays to ignore the defects and take up this matter on merits. The defects stand ignored for the present. 
 5. Petitioners have challenged the First Information Report being Chakulia Police Station Case No.41 of 2019, registered for offences underSections 461,379,420,120Band34of the Indian Penal Code, and has prayed to quash the same. 
 6. Counsel for the petitioners submits that the First Information Report has been lodged with a malafide intention. Referring to Annexure 2, which is, admittedly, an agreement, he submits that since there was long standing transactions between the parties, a cheque was given to the informant in discharge of liability. He submits that amount was transferred-: 2 :-through bank account by debiting bank account of the informant and crediting bank account of wife of petitioner No.1. 
 7. Quashing of First Information Report means quashing the investigating and throttling the criminal prosecution at an initial stage. It is well settled principle of law that when prima facie cognizable offence is made out, which needs investigation, First Information Report cannot be quashed. After going through the First Information Report, I find that there is allegation that the petitioners came to the shop of the informant for a business deal. A cancelled cheque was taken from the informant, but, the cheque book was kept there on the table. Some cheques were signed by the informant in the cheque book and were kept blank. It is allegation of the informant that these petitioners have taken some blank cheque and it was utilized by them deceitfully. The aforesaid allegation, definitely, makes out an offence, which needs an investigation. Whether there was any business transaction between the petitioners and the informant has to be investigated. The genuineness of the agreement, which the petitioners are relying upon also needs to be enquired and investigated into and only after thorough investigation, one can conclude whether the allegations in the First Information Report is correct or false. 
 8. Since the allegations in the First Information Report make out an offence and needs to be investigated, I am not inclined to entertain this criminal miscellaneous petition and accede to the prayer made by the petitioners. Accordingly, this criminal miscellaneous petition is, hereby, dismissed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J.) Kumar/Cp-03

case title: Ramdeo Mahto @ Ramdev Mahto vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 164 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 511 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 376 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
appearing for the State through Video Conferencing. The lawyers have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through Video Conferencing today at 11.00 a.m. They have no complain in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 2. This case was listed/supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board for seeking an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the Office. 
 3. Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their Clerks in the Court, this Court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 4. Counsel for the petitioner submits that the defects have already been removed. Office to check. 
 5. Petitioner has challenged the First Information Report being Mohammadganj Police Station Case No. 32 of 2019 (G.R. No. 1215 of 2019) registered for an offence underSections 376,511of the Indian Penal Code and has also challenged the order dated 04.10.2019 passed by the Sub Divisional Judicial Magistrate, Palamau at Daltonganj, by which cognizance of offence underSection 376,511of the Indian Penal Code has been taken and the petitioner has been summoned. 
 6. Counsel for the petitioner submits that there are discrepancies in the written report and the statement of the victim recorded underSection 164of the Code of Criminal Procedure. He submits that though in the first information report, the victim has stated that there was an attempt to commit rape, yet in her statement recorded underSection 164of the Code of Criminal Procedure, victim has stated that the petitioner has only assaulted the victim-: 2 :-and there is no whisper of attempt to commit rape. On this ground, petitioner has challenged the First Information Report and the order taking cognizance. 
 7. When I go through the First Information Report, I find that there is an allegation that the petitioner has tried to commit rape after entering into the house of the informant. There is also an allegation of assault. Though in the statement recorded underSection 164of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the victim has not narrated about the attempt to commit rape, yet she has stated about the assault inflicted by the petitioner. From the First Information Report, a primafacie offence, which is cognizable, is made out. The Court below has, thus, rightly taken cognizance, and has issued summons. Veracity of the statement of the victim recorded underSection 164of the Code of Criminal Procedure cannot be looked into at this stage. Since an offence is made out, which is cognizable, the Court below has correctly taken cognizance of the offence. 
 8. On the facts of this case, the First Information Report or the order taking cognizance cannot be quashed. Accordingly, this criminal miscellaneous petition is, hereby, dismissed. Petitioner is at liberty to take all the points at the time of framing of charge, if the charge has already not been framed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J.) Kumar/Cp-03

case title: Danish Hussain vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 317 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 83 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 82 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
the State. The lawyers have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through Video Conferencing today at 11.00 a.m. They have no complain in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 2. This case was listed/supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board for seeking an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the Office. 
 3. Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their Clerks in the Court, this Court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 4. Counsel for the petitioner prays to ignore the defects and to take up this case on merits. Accordingly, the defects stand ignored for the present. 
 5. Petitioner has challenged the order dated 07.12.2018 passed by the learned Judicial Magistrate 1st Class, Bermo at Tenughat in C.P. Case No.902 of 2017, whereby non-bailable warrant of arrest has been issued after rejecting the petition underSection 317of the Code of Criminal Procedure of the petitioner. 
 6. Counsel for the petitioner submits that after rejecting the petition underSection 317of the Code of Criminal Procedure, at least an opportunity should have been given to the petitioner to appear before the Court. He submits that subsequent orders dated 06.02.2019 and 26.03.2019 issuing processes underSection 82of the Code of Criminal Procedure and attachment order in terms ofSection 83of the Code of Criminal Procedure are also bad as the same are only oneline orders without recording any subjective satisfaction. He submits that all these orders are absolutely bad. He submits that the petitioner should not have been declared permanent absconder and-: 2 :-the order dated 13.05.2019 declaring the petitioner a permanent absconder is also equally bad. He lastly submits that the petitioner will appear before the Court below. 
 7. I have heard the counsel for the parties and have gone through the records. Order dated 23.10.2018 suggests that the case was fixed for evidence. No witnesses were present on that date. The next date was fixed for 04.12.2018, when also no witnesses were present. Court below, thereafter on 07.12.2018, when a petition underSection 317of the Code of Criminal Procedure was moved on behalf of petitioner, rejected the same and issued warrant of arrest. The ground for rejecting the petition underSection 317of the Code of the Code of Criminal Procedure is that on earlier occasion, the petitioner was directed to remain physically present, but he was not present. Admittedly, the petitioner was on bail. Admittedly, the case was at the stage of evidence. On 07.12.2018, there is nothing recorded in the ordersheet to suggest that witnesses were present. On earlier occasion also witnesses were not present. This Court fails to understand as to when witnesses were not present, what purpose would have been served to direct the petitioner to appear in person when he is already represented through lawyer. This approach of the Court below is erroneous and is not acceptable. When an accused is allowed to be represented underSection 317of the Code of Criminal Procedure and there is no effective proceeding, which is being conducted on a particular date, then directing the petitioner to appear in person will only be a harassment to him. The orders dated 06.02.2019 and 26.03.2019 issuing processes underSection 82of the Code of Criminal Procedure and attachment order in terms ofSection 83of the Code of Criminal Procedure are absolutely cryptic and have been passed without recording any satisfaction. Thus, I am inclined to set aside all the three orders, i.e., orders dated 07.12.2018, 06.02.2019 and 26.03.2019 passed in C.P. Case No.902 of 2017. Consequentially, the order dated 13.05.2019 whereby petitioner has been declared a permanent absconder is also, hereby, set aside. The petitioner will remain on same bail bond. 
 8. This criminal miscellaneous petition, accordingly, stands allowed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J.) Kumar/Cp-03

case title: Mohan Prasad Burnwal @ Mohand Lal ... vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 420 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 4 in the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961']
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANANDA SEN THROUGH VIDEO CONFERENCING 
 ---- 
 the State. The lawyers have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through Video Conferencing today at 11.00 a.m. They have no complain in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 2. This case was listed/supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board for seeking an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the Office. 
 3. Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their Clerks in the Court, this Court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 4. Counsel for the petitioners prays to ignore the ignore the defects and take up this matter on merits. Accordingly, the defects stand ignored for the present. 
 5. Petitioners have challenged the order dated 21.08.2018 passed by the learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Hazaribagh in Complaint Case No.2123 of 2017, by which cognizance has been taken for the offence underSection 420of the Indian Penal Code andSection 4of the Dowry Prohibition Act. 
 7. Counsel for the petitioners submits that by no stretch of imagination, on the facts narrated in the complaint, offence underSection 420of the Indian Penal Code is made out. He submits that the Court below has wrongly taken cognizance underSection 420of the Indian Penal Code. 
 8. After hearing the counsel for the parties, I have gone through the complaint petition. From perusal of the complaint petition, I find that a-: 2 :-cognizable offence is made out, thus, the Court below took cognizance of the offence. So far as the contention of the petitioners that offence underSection 420of the Indian Penal Code is not attracted, this Court feels that the said issue can be raised at the time of framing of charge. Whether the charge can be framed underSection 420of the Indian Penal Code or not is to be decided by the Court at the time of framing of charge. Merely, because cognizance has been taken for the offence underSection 420of the Indian Penal Code, it cannot be said at this stage that the Court will try the petitioners for the charge underSections 420of the Indian Penal Code, rather, the petitioners will be tried only for the charge which will be framed against them under particular penal section(s). 
 9. Thus, at this stage, I am not inclined to entertain this criminal miscellaneous petition. This criminal miscellaneous petition is, hereby, dismissed. Petitioners are at liberty to raise all the points at an appropriate stage. 
 (Ananda Sen, J.) Kumar/Cp-03

case title: Uttam Kumar vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 328 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 498 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 506 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
the State assisted by the counsel appearing for the opposite party No.2. The lawyers have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through Video Conferencing today at 11.00 a.m. They have no complain in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 2. This case was listed/supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board for seeking an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the Office. 
 3. Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their Clerks in the Court, this Court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 4. Learned counsel appearing for the petitioner prays to ignore the defects and to take up this matter on merits. Accordingly, the defects are ignored. 
 5. Petitioner, in this criminal miscellaneous petition, is challenging the First Information Report being Deoghar Sadar Mahila Police Station Case No. 20 of 2019, registered for offences underSections 498A/323/504/506of the Indian Penal Code. 
 6. Counsel for the petitioner submits that the informant is in the habit of lodging false cases against this petitioner. He submits that the petitioner wants to keep his wife with proper dignity, but, she does not want to stay with this petitioner. 
 7. I have heard the counsel for the parties and have gone through the records including the First Information Report. I find that the petitioner, being the husband, tortured and assaulted the informant, who is the wife. Further a demand of Rs.5,00,000/- (Rupees Five Lakh) as dowry was made. On earlier occasion, Mahila Police Station Case No.76 of 2016 was registered-: 2 :-for offences underSections 498/34,323,328/34of the Indian Penal Code andSections 3/4of the Dowry Prohibition Act, but, as the petitioner and the informant compromised, the said case was withdrawn. It has also been mentioned that after withdrawal of the said case, wife was taken to matrimonial house, but, again after torture and assault, the present first information report has been lodged. The aforesaid allegations definitely make out an offence. 
 8. Since an offence, prima facie, is made out, which needs investigation, I am not inclined to entertain this criminal miscellaneous petition. Accordingly, this criminal miscellaneous petition is, hereby, dismissed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J.) Kumar/Cp-03

case title: Lotan Khan Choudhary vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
Lotan Khan Choudhary ... ... Petitioner Versus The State of Jharkhand ... ... Opposite Party 
 ------- 
 CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through- Video Conferencing 
 ------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. A.K. Kashyap, Sr. Advocate For the State : Mr. Anup Pawan Topno, A.P.P. 
 ------- 
 02/15.09.2020 Heard Mr. A.K. Kashyap, learned senior counsel for the petitioner and Mr. Anup Pawan Topno, learned A.P.P. for the State. 
 The petitioner has prayed for grant of anticipatory bail, as he is apprehending his arrest in connection with Bariatu P.S. Case No. 231/2019. 
 It has been alleged that the petitioner had tried to take illegal possession of the land purchased by the son of the informant. He had demanded a sum of Rs. 12,00,000/- as extortion money and on 29.09.2019 the accused persons had entered into the campus and on the next day the boundary wall was demolished. 
 It has been stated by the learned senior counsel for the petitioner that the petitioner is a social worker and since he had raised the issue with respect to the illegal occupation of an Adavasi land by the informant he has falsely been implicated in the present case at the behest of the informant as well as by the builder. Learned senior counsel further submits that with respect to the said land a suit is already pending in which the informant as well as the builder is a party. So far as the antecedents of the petitioner is concerned learned senior counsel submits that in most of the cases the petitioner has been acquitted or final report has been submitted and the petitioner at present has one criminal antecedent being an accused in Bariatu P.S. Case No. 168/2019 which is also with respect to a trivial offence. 
 Mr. Anup Pawan Topno, learned A.P.P. for the State has opposed the prayer for anticipatory bail made by the petitioner. 
 It appears that the dispute seems to be with respect to a land which was purportedly purchased by the informant and which is a non-transferable land to a general person. It also appears that a title suit being Title Suit No. 391/2019 is pending in which the informant, the claimant of the land as well as the builder are parties. 
 In view of the attritional relationship which is existing between the informant, the builder as well as the petitioner apart from Gopal Tirkey who claims the said land the false implication of the petitioner cannot be ruled out. 
 In such view of the matter, therefore, the petitioner is directed to surrender before the learned court below within a period of four weeks and on such surrender, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Judicial Magistrate 1st Class, Ranchi in connection with Bariatu P.S. Case No. 231/2019, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (R. Mukhopadhyay, J.) Alok/-

case title: Alok Dubey @ Alok Vardhan vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 239 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 511 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 504 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 385 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
has been held through video conferencing today at 11:00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect of the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 2. This case was listed/supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board for seeking an order in respect of the defects, pointed out by the office. 
 3. Considering the pandemic situation where the Court has minimized the footfall of the lawyers and their clerks in the Court, this Court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defects can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before the Court directly. 
 4. Defect(s) as pointed out by the office, stand ignored for the present. 
 5. With the consent of the parties, the matter is taken up for hearing on merits. 
 6. The petitioner has challenged the order dated 18.3.2019 passed by the learned Judicial Magistrate, Deoghar in G.R. No. 1338 of 2015, whereby the discharge application has been dismissed. He has also challenged the revisional order dated 1.8.2019 whereby, Criminal Revision No. 102/2019 has also been dismissed. 
 7. The petitioner is an accused for the offence underSections 279,291,323,341,354,379,458,385,504,511and34IPC. The police filed chargesheet against the petitioner. The petitioner thereafter, filed an application underSection 239Cr.P.C praying therein to discharge him from the offence, as alleged. The said application was taken up by the court below on 18.3.2019 and final order was passed dismissing the discharge petition. 
 8. While I go through the order dated 18.3.2019, I find that the same is cryptic and non-speaking as no reason has been assigned as to why the discharge petition is being dismissed. Merely dismissing the petition of the petitioner on the ground that the chargesheet has been submitted and cognizance has been taken is not an ground to dismiss the discharge application. Through the court has mentioned about some paragraphs i.e. Paragraphs Nos. 2, 5, 6 and 25 of the case diary but has not mentioned what those paragraph is all about and what are the materials there to frame charge. What are the materials which makes out the case for framing charge against the accused, has not been mentioned. The revisional court has also not mentioned as to what are the materials against the petitioner. Thus, both the impugned orders are liable to be set aside. 
 9. In that view, impugned orders i.e. order dated 18.3.2019 passed in G.R. No. 1338 of 2015 and the revisional order dated 1.8.2019 passed in Criminal Revision No. 102/2019 are set aside. The matter is remitted to the court below to pass a fresh order in accordance with law. 
 10. Accordingly, this petition is allowed.

 Order No.02 Dated- 15.09.2020 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Learned counsel for the petitioners personally undertakes to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over.

 Apprehending their arrest, the petitioners have moved this Court for grant of privilege of anticipatory bail in connection with Meral P.S. Case No.60 of 2020 registered undersections 323/379/504/506/307/34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 The Learned counsel for the petitioners submits that the allegation against the petitioner is that petitioners in furtherance of common intention with the co-accused persons snatched purse, gold chain, mobile handset and attempted to murder Raj Singh and Vikash Singh. It is further submitted that the allegation against the petitioners are all false and there was previous enmity between the parties and a case was lodged by the informant against the co- accused persons earlier also. It is then submitted that the petitioners are ready and willing to cooperate with the investigation of the case. It is lastly submitted that the co-accused person whose case stands on the similar footing has already been given the privilege of anticipatory bail by a coordinate bench of this Court vide order dated 17.08.2020 in A.B.A. No.3323 of 2020. Hence, it is submitted that the petitioners be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. 
 Learned Addl. P.P. opposes the prayer for grant of anticipatory bail.
