case title: Mithun Kumar vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 506 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 504 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 376 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 341 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conference) 
 ----- 
 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Hemant Kr. Shikarwar, learned counsel for the State, Mrs. Ruby Pandey and learned counsel for the O.P. No.2, Mr. Achyut Swaroop Mishra. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Giddi P.S. Case No.75 of 2019, for the offence registered underSections 323,341,376,504,506IPC and 4 of POCSO Act. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that as per the FIR, it is alleged by the informant that on the pretext of marriage, they had sexual relationship for the last two years, but the petitioner has refused to marry her, as such, she has filed the instant case. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has categorically stated that informant is a major lady and has stated in para-14 of the case diary that petitioner is agree to marry with her, if he is released on bail he shall file a marriage certificate before the court below with regard to registration of the marriage with the informant. 
 Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail. Learned counsel for the informant has submitted that victim is a major lady and she is also willing and ready to marry with the petitioner, as such, petitioner may be enlarged on bail so as to file a registration of marriage by the Registrar, Birth, Death and Marriage, within a period of three months. After hearing, learned counsel for the parties and looking upon the stand taken by the informant/victim that she is a major lady, this Court is inclined to grant Provisional Bail for three months to the petitioner so that he can comply the undertaking as stated in Para-14 of the bail application that he is-2-ready to marry with the informant/victim. Accordingly, petitioner (Mithun Kumar), is directed to be released on Provisional Bail for three months on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 20,000/- (Rupees Twenty Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Additional Sessions Jude-I cum Spl. Judge POCSO Act, Hazaribag in connection with Giddi P.S. Case No.75 of 2019 on the following conditions:- 
 (i) One of the bailors shall be deponent/parivikar of the present case namely, Rameshwar Ram Mahto, S/o Anup Mahto, R/o Behari, Oriya, P.O. & P.S.- Hazaribag, District- Hazaribag, who has furnished photocopy of his UID Card bearing No.2489 5399 5275 before this Court in the bail application. 
 Office is directed to send photo copy of the UID Card bearing No. 2489 5399 5275 of deponent along with this order to the court below so as to verify the authenticity of the bailor. 
 (ii) Both the parties shall file an affidavit along with marriage certificate issued by Registrar, Birth, Death and Marriage within three months. 
 Registrar, Birth, Death and Marriage shall expedite the process after ascertaining physical appearance of both the parties before him. 
 (iii) Another bailor shall be father/mother/son/sister/brother. 
 (iv) The Jail Authority shall release the petitioner only after his medical check- up. 
 (v) The Civil Surgeon, Hazaribagh is directed to medically examine the petitioner at the time of his release and if require, petitioner shall be taken for quarantine, but if no such requirement is there, he shall be released forthwith, if not wanted in any other case. 
 (vi) Petitioner shall also comply with all the guidelines issued by the Government to meet the challenges of Covid-19, as the country is passing through Pandemic of Covid-19. 
 Put up this case on 14.12.2020. 
 By the next date, learned counsel for the petitioner may file certificate of marriage before this Court. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Yogendra Singh vs The State Of Jharkhand

all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 ----- 
 Heard, learned Sr. counsel, Mr. Anil Kumar Sinha assisted by learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Raunak Sahay and learned counsel for the State, Mr. Vikash Kr. Sinha. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Govindpur P.S. Case No.256 of 2019, for the offence registered underSections 419,420,467,468,471,34IPC, read withSection 132(1)(b)(c)(e)and (f) of the Jharkhand Goods & Service Tax Act, 2017. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that it is alleged that proprietor of M/s Maa Bhawani Enterprises has taken input credit facilities of Rs.5,36,66,982.68/- on the basis of forged document. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that admittedly the proprietorship of M/s Maa Bhawani Enterprises is in the name of Jai Ram Mahato and it is surprising that while Jai Ram Mahato was in custody, his statement was recorded underSection 161Cr.P.C. where he has alleged that this petitioner, Yogendra Singh was doing entire business for the M/s Maa Bhawani Enterprises and on the basis of that petitioner, Yogendra Singh has been made accused and he has been taken into custody on 28.02.2020. Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that the name of the petitioner got transpired on the basis of confessional statement of the co- accused and petitioner has no criminal antecedent, as such, he may be enlarged on regular bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that case diary as well as material collected during investigation is required to be looked into. 
 Learned counsel for the State has further submitted that case may be heard along with bail application bearing B.A. No.4348 of 2020 preferred by co- accused, Jai Ram Mahto though the same is still defective. Considering the rival submissions of the parties, learned State counsel is directed to file counter-affidavit within four weeks. List this case after four weeks along with B.A. No.4348 of 2020 and analogous cases arising out of Govindpur P.S. Case No.256 of 2019. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Nazarul Ansari vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 164 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 319 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 201 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conference) 
 ----- 
 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Dhirendra Kr. Prasad and learned counsel for the State, Mr. Shekhar Sinha. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with S.T. Case No.99 of 2019, arising out of Shikaripara P.S. Case No.53 of 2017, corresponding to G.R. Case No.481 of 2017, for the offence registered underSections 302,34&201IPC. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that brother of the deceased- Rameshwar Ray is the informant of this case and he is not an eye witness of the case rather on the basis of investigation, it transpired that deceased- Shrawan Ray had affair with Priti Singh, whose marriage was solemnized with the petitioner, Nazarul Ansari six months ago. It is alleged that when Nazarul Ansari came to know about the said affair, he has called Shrawan Ray. It is alleged that Nazarul Ansari along with his two friends had killed Shrawan Ray. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that on the basis of some flimsy material, petitioner was made an accused, who surrendered before the court on 01.03.2019. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that some of the prosecution witnesses have said that Priti Singh has called the deceased and as such, she is also an accused. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that on the basis of statement of the co-accused, petitioner has been made accused and is in custody though the Priti Singh has not been summoned underSection 319Cr.P.C., but evidence on record suggests that Priti Singh is also accomplice to the offence, as such, petitioner may be enlarged on regular bail. Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that Priti Singh has been examined underSection 164Cr.P.C. and-2-her statement as mentioned at para 10 of the bail application recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C. is sufficient to establish the involvement of the petitioner in commission of the offence. 
 Learned counsel for the State has further submitted that if any material comes during the trial, the learned trial court may suo moto proceed underSection 319Cr.P.C. and the parties may file an application before the court but at this stage till Priti Singh has not been examined as prosecution witness, as such, petitioner may not be enlarged on bail. 
 After hearing, learned counsel for the parties and perusing the materials brought on record and looking upon the merit of the case and the involvement of the petitioner which has been disclosed by his wife, Priti Singh, this Court is not inclined to grant bail to the petitioner. Accordingly, the prayer of bail of the petitioner is hereby rejected. 
 However, petitioner may renew the prayer for bail after it comes that Priti Singh has not supported the case of the prosecution. Further learned trial court is directed to expedite the trial as the petitioner is in custody since 01.03.2019. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

all_text:
1. Santosh Bharati @ Santosh Bharti @ Sanju Giri 
 2. Arbind Shukla @ Arvind Shukla ... Petitioners Versus The State of Jharkhand ... Opposite Party 
 ------ 
 CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY 
 ------ 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. Ajit Kr. Dubey, Advocate For the State : Mr. P.K. Chatterjee, Addl. P.P. 
 ------ 
 Order No.02 Dated- 15.09.2020 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Learned counsel for the petitioners personally undertakes to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking of the learned counsel for the petitioners, the defects pointed out by the stamp reporter are ignored for the present. 
 Apprehending their arrest, the petitioners have moved this Court for grant of privilege of anticipatory bail in connection with Lesliganj P.S. Case No.22 of 2020 registered undersections 414/34of the Indian Penal Code,section 21(4)of the Mines and Minerals (Development andRegulation) Act, under section 54 of the Jharkhand Minor Mineral Concession Rule, 2004 and section 9(i)/13 of the Jharkhand Minerals (Prevention of Illegal Mining, Transportation and Storage) Rule, 2017. 
 Heard the learned counsel for the petitioners and learned Addl. P.P. for the State. 
 The Learned counsel for the petitioners submits that the allegation against the petitioners is that the petitioner no.1 is the owner of the Tractor bearing registration no. JH03G-1255 and the petitioner no.2 is the owner of the tractor bearing registration no. JH03P-4565 which were involved in transportation of illegally excavated sand. It is further submitted that the allegation against the petitioners are all false and the petitioners being the owners of the said tractors have no knowledge about their vehicles being involved in any illegal activity. It is next submitted that the petitioner no.1 has no criminal antecedent. It is then submitted that the petitioners are ready and willing to furnish sufficient security including cash security and undertake to cooperate with the investigation of the case. Hence, it is submitted that the petitioners be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. 
 Learned Addl. P.P. opposes the prayer for grant of anticipatory bail. 
 Considering the submissions of the counsels and the fact as discussed above, I am of the opinion that it is a fit case where the above named petitioners be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. Hence, in the event of their arrest or surrender within a period of four weeks from the date of this order, they shall be released on bail on the petitioner no.1 depositing cash security of Rs.5,000/- and the petitioner no.2 depositing cash security of Rs.15,000/- and on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned S.D.J.M., Palamau, in connection with Lesliganj P.S. Case No.22 of 2020 with the condition that the petitioners will cooperate with the investigation of the case and appear before the Investigating Officer as and when noticed by him and will furnish their mobile numbers and a copy of their Aadhar Cards in the court below with the undertaking that they will not change their mobile numbers during the pendency of the case subject to the conditions laid down under section 438 (2) Cr. case title: Nimesh Kachhap vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 27 in Arms Act', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 307 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 306 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Mahesh Kr. Sinha (2) and learned counsel for the State, Mr. Vibhuti Shankar Sahay. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Namkum P.S. Case No.203 of 2019, for the offence registered underSections 306/307/302IPC andSection 27of the Arms Act. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that as per the FIR, petitioner is not named in the FIR rather the same has been lodged against three unknown persons in Namkum Police Station, Ranchi. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the informant, Rupa Devi is not an eye-witness to the occurrence nor Puran Mahato is an eye-witness of the fardbeyan. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that on the basis of confessional statement of one Sanjay Nayak, the petitioner has been remanded in this case on 04.10.2019, as the petitioner was in judicial custody in different case. Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that in Para-20 of the case diary, Puran Mahato has claimed to be eye-witness to the occurrence and he has given vivid description of the occurrence. As per the statement of Puran Mahato, he has identified Sanjay Nayak in the TIP, but nothing has been alleged against this petitioner, Nimesh Kachhap. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that on the basis of confessional statement of Sanjay Nayak, pistol and bike used in commission of the offence have been recovered, as mentioned in Para-40 of the case diary, but this petitioner has been named in this case on the basis of confessional statement of Sanjay Nayak during police custody, which is not admissible under the law, as such,-2-petitioner, who is in custody since 04.10.2019, as such, he may be enlarged on regular bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that a detail counter-affidavit is required to be filed in this case, as this petitioner has also confessed his guilt in his extra-Judicial confession, as mentioned in Para-77 of the case diary, as such, four weeks' time may be granted. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties and considering the gravity of the offence, learned State counsel is directed to file a detail counter-affidavit within four weeks including the criminal antecedent of the petitioner and other materials collected by the investigating officer in the present case. List this case after four weeks. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Uma Shankar Sao @ Uma Shankar ... vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.), (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand), (2)
issues: ['Section 304 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
Uma Shankar Sao @ Uma Shankar Prasad ... Petitioner Versus The State of Jharkhand ... Opposite Party 
 ------ 
 CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY 
 ------ 
 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Learned counsel for the petitioner personally undertakes to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking of the learned counsel for the petitioner, the defects pointed out by the stamp reporter are ignored for the present. 
 Apprehending his arrest, the petitioner has moved this Court for grant of privilege of anticipatory bail in connection with Hazaribagh Sadar P.S. Case No.109 of 2020 registered undersections 304of the Indian Penal Code. 
 The Learned Senior Advocate appearing for the petitioner submits that the allegation against the petitioner is that the petitioner being the owner of Premier Ice Factory was instrumental in leaking of poisonous gas from his said factory due to which 50- 60 persons became ill and the mother of the informant whose house is at a distance of 200 metres from the said Ice factory became seriously ill and died in course of her treatment because of the said poisonous gas. It is further submitted that the allegation against the petitioner are all false and the petitioner and his family members reside in the said premises and neither the petitioner nor his family members has suffered any illness because of leakage of gas and the petitioner has been granted licenses including the licence issued by the Factory Inspection Department which were valid during the alleged occurrence. It is next submitted that though the informant claims that his house is situated at a distance of 200 metres but a three men committee constituted under the chairmanship of Deputy Chief Inspector of the Factory; has found that the house of the informant is situated at a distance of 650 metres and it has also been found that 27 persons have been admitted to Hospital and after proper checkup they were released on the same day. It is also submitted that the pressure vessel has been found to be defective which led to leakage of Ammonia gas. It is next submitted that because of power cut for about 18-20 hours, the pressure could not be maintained and due to mechanical fault, Ammonia gas leaked in the night when no operation of any machine was being done. It is further submitted that leakage of Ammonia gas was an accident which could not have been controlled by the petitioner. It is next submitted that there is no material in the record to suggest that the deceased died because of inhaling Ammonia gas. It is next submitted that the petitioner has been running the said ice factory for several years and there is no allegation that the petitioner has any intention of causing the death or having knowledge that it is likely to cause death of any person nor there is any specific negligence attributed to the petitioner hence at best the offence punishable underSection 304Aof I.P.C. could be made out which is bailable in nature. It is next submitted that the petitioner has no criminal antecedent as has been mentioned in paragraph no. 23 of the anticipatory bail application. It is then submitted that the petitioner is ready and willing to cooperate with the investigation of the case. Hence, it is submitted that the petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. 
 Learned Addl. P.P. opposes the prayer for grant of anticipatory bail. 
 Considering the submissions of the counsels and the fact as discussed above, I am of the opinion that it is a fit case where the above named petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. Hence, in the event of his arrest or surrender within a period of four weeks from the date of this order, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned C.J.M., Hazaribagh, in connection with Hazaribagh Sadar P.S. Case No.109 of 2020 with the condition that the petitioner will cooperate with the investigation of the case and appear before the Investigating Officer as and when noticed by him and will furnish his mobile number and a copy of his Aadhar Card in the court below with the undertaking that he will not change his mobile number during the pendency of the case subject to the conditions laid down under section 438 (2) Cr. P.C. 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Sonu/Gunjan-

case title: Avinash Singh @ Avinash Kumar ... vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 306 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 ----- 
 Heard, learned counsel, Mr. Sanjay Kumar assisted by the learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Rajiv Lochan and learned counsel for the State, Mr. Rajneesh Vardhan assisted by learned counsel for the informant, Mr. R.C.P. Sah. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Adityapur P.S. Case No.15 of 2020, for the offence registered underSection 306/34IPC as the informant (wife of the deceased) has relied upon a suicide note in which the deceased has admitted that petitioner, Avinash Singh was carrying stolen articles on his car, which was known to the police, as such, petitioner- Avinash Singh was pressurizing the deceased to admit the guilt otherwise he will kill him. Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that suicide note has been cited and it has been written by the deceased, but the investigating officer has not connected the suicide note with the alleged offence rather on the basis of the fabricated document, petitioner has been made accused in this case and petitioner is in custody since 10.02.2020, as such, he may be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State assisted by learned counsel for the informant have opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that suicide note is written in the hand-writing of the deceased, which will be apparent from the other letters and documents written by the deceased, as such, petitioner may not be enlarged on bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State has further submitted that the case diary has been called for, which has not been received by him, as such, some time may be granted to file a detail counter-affidavit. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties, learned State counsel is directed to file a detail counter-affidavit within four weeks with regard to the materials collected against the petitioner including the authenticity of suicide notes. 
 List this case after four weeks. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Sikha Jha & Ors vs The State Of Jharkhand & Ors
issues: ['Section 83 in The Registration Act, 1908', 'Section 82 in The Registration Act, 1908', 'Section 144 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
For the Petitioners : Mr. R.S. Mazumdar, Sr. Advocate Mr. Ankit Kumar, Advocate For the Respondent-State : Mr. Ashish Kr Thakur, AC to AAG-III 
 ----- 
 02/15.09.2020 The present writ petition is taken up today through Video conferencing. 
 The assisting counsel to Mr. R.S. Mazumdar, the learned Senior Counsel for the petitioners undertakes to remove the defects as pointed out by the office within two weeks. 
 The present writ petition has been filed for issuance of direction upon the respondent authorities to show cause as to how and under what law the Sub-Divisional Officer, Deoghar in connivance with the private respondent nos. 6 to 9 demolished the boundary of the petitioners' land situated at Jamabandi No. 134, Plot No. 1/C (revised town plan), Mouza-Nilkanthpur, Holding No. 0240001276000A2 under Ward No. 24, District-Deoghar and to restrain the State respondents as well as the private respondents to get possession of the said land. 
 I.A. No. 4618 of 2020 The present interlocutory application has been filed on behalf of the petitioners seeking addition of the prayer in paragraph no. 1 as well as in the prayer portion of the writ petition, which is as follows: 
 "(f) During the pendency of the instant writ petition, for stay of further proceedings in Misc. Complaint Case No. 05/2020-21." 
 The learned Senior Counsel for the petitioners submits that initially, a proceeding underSection 144Cr.P.C. was initiated against Mohan Prasad Yadav and Others (the vendors of the land which were purchased by the petitioners) by the respondent no. 3 - the Sub- Divisional Officer, Deoghar at the instance of the respondent no. 6 - Ram Sharan Singh, registered as Criminal Miscellaneous Case No. 908/2019. The respondent no. 3, however, dropped the said proceeding vide order dated 03.02.2020 (Annexure-1 to the writ petition) observing inter alia that the matter appeared to be dispute of title between the parties which was beyond his jurisdiction. Despite dropping of the said proceeding, the respondent no. 3 issued the order as contained in memo no. 172 dated 12.03.2020 (Annexure-3 to the writ petition) deputing police force at the instance of the private respondents for the purpose of repair of the boundary wall and measurement of the disputed property. The said action of the respondent no. 3 is completely without jurisdiction. 
 The learned Senior Counsel for the petitioners further submits that during the pendency of the instant writ petition, at the behest of the respondent no. 3, a proceeding being Misc. Complaint Case No. 05/2020-21 has been initiated before the respondent no. 2 - the Deputy Commissioner, Deoghar. A notice dated 01.07.2020 has been served upon the petitioner no. 1 informing that the concerned respondent authority has started a proceeding underSection 82and83of the Registration Act, 1908 for cancellation of sale deed of the petitioner no. 1 and has been directed to appear before the respondent no. 2 on 17.07.2020. 
 Having heard the learned Senior Counsel for the petitioners and AC to AAG-III appearing for the State of Jharkhand and for the reasons stated in I.A. No. 4618 of 2020, the petitioner is allowed to add the aforesaid prayer in the writ petition. 
 Let necessary amendment in paragraph-1 and in the prayer portion of the writ petition be made within two weeks. 
 I.A. No. 4618 of 2020 stands disposed of. 
 W.P.(C) No. 1873 of 2020 AC to AAG-III prays for and is allowed three weeks' time to seek instruction and file counter affidavit on behalf of the respondent nos. 1 to 5. 
 Issue notice to the respondent nos. 6 to 9 under registered cover with A/D for which requisites etc. must be filed within one week. 
 Put up this case under appropriate heading after six weeks. 
 In the meantime, the parties shall maintain the status-quo with regard to the land bearing Jamabandi No. 134, Plot No. 1/C (revised town plan), Mouza-Nilkanthpur, Holding No. 0240001276000A2 under Ward No. 24, District-Deoghar. 
 It is made clear that the proceeding being Misc. Complaint Case No. 05/2020-21 pending in the court of District Sub-Registrar- cum-Deputy Commissioner, Deoghar shall continue. However, no final order shall be passed in the said case, till further order of this Court. 
 (Rajesh Shankar, J.) Manish

It is further submitted that the allegation against the petitioner are all false and there is an inordinate delay of ten years in lodging the FIR.  The learned Addl. P.P. opposes the prayer for anticipatory bail. 
 List this case on 05.11.2020. 
 Considering the submissions of the counsels and the fact as discussed above, I am inclined to pass an interim order of anticipatory bail provisionally till 05.11.2020. In case of the petitioner being arrested by the police on or before 05.11.2020, he shall be released on bail provisionally on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five thousand) with two sureties of like amount each to the satisfaction of the officer concerned in connection with Complain Case No.1341 of 2019 subject to the conditions laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

case title: Birsa Bhengra vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 27 in Arms Act', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 307 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 ----- 
 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Ritesh Kumar and learned counsel for the State, Mr. Sardhu Mahto. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Torpa P.S. Case No.27 of 2016, S.T. No.334 of 2019, corresponding to G.R. No.175 of 2016 for the offence registered underSections 302/307/34IPC, underSection 27of Arms Act and under Section 17 of C.L.A. Act. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner is not named in the FIR nor there is any eye-witness to the occurrence nor he has been put on TIP and because of criminal antecedent, he has been remanded in this case from Murhu P.S. Case No.81 of 2017 and petitioner is in custody in this case since 23.04.2019. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that on the basis of belated statement of Punam Tiru recorded in para 46 on 01.01.2017, petitioner has been implicated in this case but even Punam Tiru has not alleged that this petitioner has entered into the premises nor alleged that he has taken the deceased- Domnic Barla, whose dead body was subsequently found rather a large number of people has gathered and the presence of the petitioner cannot be made basis for rejection of the bail until and unless there is specific averment that this petitioner has any role. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that on the basis of belated statement which was recorded after six months, petitioner has been languishing in custody, as such, petitioner may be enlarged on regular bail. Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that this petitioner has 17 criminal antecedent, as such, considering the statement of Punam Tiru as recorded in para 46 of the case diary, prayer for-2-bail may be refused. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties, learned State counsel is directed to file a detail counter-affidavit within four weeks with regard to the involvement of the petitioner and the statement made by the Punam Tiru and State counsel shall also give details about 17 criminal antecedent of the petitioner. 
 List this case after four weeks. 
 In the meantime, learned counsel for the petitioner is also directed to file an affidavit with regard to the pending criminal cases and the stage of the trial and whether he has been granted bail in those cases. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Lalit Sah vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.), (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand), (G.R. No. 64 of 2020), (2)
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 420 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 406 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
1. Lalit Sah 
 2. Prabhakar Kumar @ Prabhakar Singh ... Petitioners Versus The State of Jharkhand ... Opposite Party 
 ------ 
 CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY 
 ------ 
 For the Petitioners : Mr. N.P. Choudhary, Advocate For the State : Mr. Tarun Kumar, Addl. P.P. 
 ------ 
 Order No.02 Dated- 15.09.2020 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Learned counsel for the petitioners personally undertakes to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking of the learned counsel for the petitioners, the defects pointed out by the stamp reporter are ignored for the present. 
 Apprehending their arrest, the petitioners have moved this Court for grant of privilege of anticipatory bail in connection with Mihijam P.S. Case No.136 of 2018 (G.R. No. 64 of 2020) registered undersections 406/420/34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 The Learned counsel for the petitioners submits that the allegation against the petitioners is that the petitioners accompanied the co-accused -Jitendra Singh and approached the informant to take C&F of Shree Sunshine Brand and the informant paid Rs.12,50,000/- to the co-accused -Jitendra Singh but the petitioners and the co-accused cheated the informant and committed criminal breach of trust. It is further submitted that there is no allegation of entrustment of money to the petitioners and police after due investigation submitted final form against the petitioners and did not send them up for trial but the learned Magistrate has taken cognizance for the offences punishable undersection 406/420/34of the Indian Penal Code against the petitioners also. It is next submitted that the allegation against the petitioners are false and there is no allegation of any dishonest intention of the petitioners at the time of alleged entrustment of money to the co-accused. Hence, it is submitted that the petitioners be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. 
 Learned Addl. P.P. opposes the prayer for grant of anticipatory bail. 
 Considering the submissions of the counsels and the fact as discussed above, I am of the opinion that it is a fit case where the above named petitioners be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. Hence, in the event of their arrest or surrender within a period of four weeks from the date of this order, they shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five Thousand) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned S.D.J.M., Jamtara, in connection with Mihijam P.S. Case No.136 of 2018 (G.R. No. 64 of 2020) with the condition that the petitioners will cooperate with the investigation of the case and appear before the Investigating Officer as and when noticed by him and will furnish their mobile numbers and a copy of their Aadhar Cards in the court below with the undertaking that they will not change their mobile numbers during the pendency of the case subject to the conditions laid down under section 438 (2) Cr. P.C. 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Sonu/Gunjan-

case title: Pankaj Bansal vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 306 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 ----- 
 Heard, learned Sr. counsel, Mr. R.S. Mazumdar assisted by learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Rohan Mazumdar and learned counsel for the State, Mrs. Priya Shrestha assisted by learned counsel for the informant, Mr. Arun Kumar. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Chas P.S. Case No.389 of 2019, corresponding to G.R. Case No.357 of 2020 for the offence initially registered underSection 304B/34IPC as marriage took place in January, 2019 and they have been blessed with one male child. Subsequently wife was under depression and committed suicide, as such, police after investigation submitted chargesheet underSections 304B,306/34IPC. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that witnesses examined during investigation underSection 161Cr.P.C. have categorically stated that at the time of the occurrence, this petitioner was not present there and he came subsequently and the investigating officer has mentioned the place of occurrence where he has found a duppata hanging from a ceiling fan and chair and table were properly placed under the ceiling fan, as such, he may be enlarged on regular bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State assisted by learned counsel for the informant have opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that it is surprising that a lady committed suicide by means of duppata, which was not torn nor ripped nor cut. The chair and table which have been used by the deceased for committing suicide has been placed properly and have not been disturbed even after jumping from the chair which was on the table, as such, it is a case underSection 304BIPC where chargesheet has been submitted underSections 304B-2-and 306IPC. 
 Learned counsel for the State assisted by learned counsel for the informant has further submitted that in view of the judgment passed by the Hon'ble Apex Court, in such cases chargesheet ought to have been framed underSections 302,304Band306IPC, as such, State counsel may be directed to file a detail counter-affidavit. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties, this Court directs the Superintendent of Police, Bokaro (In-person) to file a detail counter-affidavit in this case with respect to the place of occurrence and material collected during investigation. 
 The affidavit must be filed by the Superintendent of Police, Bokaro (In- person), so as to know the standard of investigation made in such heinous crime by the investigating officers. 
 List this case after four weeks. 
 Let a copy of this order be communicated through FAX to the Superintendent of Police, Bokaro at once. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Brijesh Kumar Pandey vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 164 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 161 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 ----- 
 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Amit Kumar and learned counsel for the State, Mrs. Priya Shrestha assisted by learned counsel for the informant, Mr. Ram Subhag Singh. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with M.G.M. P.S. Case No.105 of 2019, for the offence registered underSection 302IPC and 27Arms Actby the informant as Bijay Kumar Singh, who was the Manager has been shot dead by criminals. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that on the basis of suspicion, the name of the petitioner has been mentioned along with Budh Ram Baskety @ Budhu Ram Baskey @ Ludhu Ram Baskey and said Budh Ram Baskety has already been enlarged on bail vide order dated 01.06.2020 passed by co-ordinate Bench of this Court in B.A. No.2599 of 2020. Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that falsity of the case would be apparent from the fact that even it is alleged that there is land dispute with the petitioner, as such, deceased has been killed by the petitioner though there is no document to support that petitioner has any land dispute with the deceased and there is no an eye witness to the occurrence. Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that petitioner is in custody since 28.11.2019, as such, he may be enlarged on regular bail. Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that case diary has not been received by her, as such, four weeks time may be granted to file a detail counter-affidavit. Learned counsel for the informant has also opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that at para 17 of the case diary, the CCTV footage has been-2-mentioned whereby a white Bullet motorcycle was used by the accused persons for assassinating the deceased (Bijay Kumar Singh). Since the petitioner was named in the FIR and on the basis of that police apprehended him and he confessed his guilt and on the basis of confessional statement of the petitioner white Bullet motorcycle was recovered, which belongs to one Md. Shabdar. It is further submitted that Md. Shabdar has been examined underSection 161Cr.P.C. as well as underSection 164Cr.P.C. where he has categorically stated that petitioner has taken his Bullet motorcycle of Md. Shabdar on the pretext that his vehicle was not in order, as such, to use the same the said bullet motorcycle was taken. 
 Learned counsel for the informant has further submitted that in the case diary at paras 6, 8, 9, 10 and 18 witnesses have also supported the case of the prosecution and the mobile phone of the petitioner was found near the place of occurrence. He has further submitted that petitioner is giving threatening to the informant, as such, petitioner may not be enlarged on bail. Considering the rival submissions of the parties, learned State counsel is directed to file a detail counter-affidavit on the above issue along with copy of the statement of Md. Shabdar recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C, as well as tower location within four weeks. 
 List this case after four weeks. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Pintu Kumar vs State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 27 in The Indian Evidence Act, 1872', 'Section 394 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
Order No.04, Dated 15.09.2020. 
 Heard learned counsel appearing for the petitioner and learned Public Prosecutor for the State. 
 The petitioner, who is accused for offence underSection 394of the Indian Penal Code, prays for regular bail in connection with Bashisthanagar P.S. Case No.04 of 2020. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that as per the FIR, informant went to the house of the petitioner to bring the instalment amount. Subsequently the informant was going on his motorcycle which was chased by two unknown persons on a tempo and they have taken one cell phone of VIVO company from the informant and his Motorcycle bearing Registration Number JH 13D 8155 was also snatched by the unknown criminals. Since the informant has gone to the house of the petitioner, it is suspected by the informant that the petitioner has role in this case. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that the looted motorcycle, three cheques of the informant and mobile phone have been recovered from one co-accused, Badal Kumar @ Badal Kumar Gupta who has already been enlarged on bail passed by Co-ordinate Bench vide order dated 18.08.2020 in B.A. No.4877 of 2020. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has further submitted that the petitioner is in custody since 14.01.2020, as such, the petitioner may also be enlarged on regular bail. 
 Learned counsel for the State has opposed the prayer for regular bail and submitted that on the basis of confessional statement of this petitioner, Pintu Kumar, those looted articles have been recovered from the house of co-accused, Badal Kumar @-2-Badal Kumar Gupta and case of the petitioner comes undersection 27of the Evidence Act, as such, petitioner may not be enlarged on regular bail, as involement of co-accused, Badal Kumar @ Badal Kumar Gupta has not been found rather recovery has been made from the house of the co-accused, Badal Kumar @ Badal Kumar Gupta. 
 Learned counsel for the State has further submitted that co- accused, Badal Kumar @ Badal Kumar Gupta has not been put in TIP so as to establish that he is one of the persons out of two unknown persons who snatched all the articles from the informant. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties and looking into the facts and merits of the case that on confession of the petitioner (Pintu Kumar) recovery of looted articles have been made, as such, I am not inclined to enlarge the petitioner on bail. 
 Accordingly, the prayer for bail of the petitioner is hereby rejected. 
 ( Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sandeep/R.S.

case title: Lileshwar Singh vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MRS. JUSTICE ANUBHA RAWAT CHOUDHARY 
 --- 
 Through Video Conferencing 07/15.09.2020 
 1. Heard Mr. Jitendra Shankar Singh, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the petitioner(s) along with Mr. Randhir Kumar, Advocate in both the cases. 
 2. Heard Mr. Shailesh Kumar Sinha, leaned counsel appearing on behalf of opposite party-State in Cr. Revision No. 966 of 2014 as well as Ms. Priya Shrestha, APP in Cr. Revision No. 210 of 2015. 
 3. The learned counsel for the petitioner while advancing his argument has submitted that the petitioner has been convicted under Sections 25(1-b) (a)/35/26/35 of theArms Actfor three years each. He submits that merely because the arms was recovered from the house of the petitioner was not sufficient to convict, as the petitioner was residing with his family members and recovery cannot be imputed only to the petitioner. He has submitted that altogether 11 witnesses have been examined in this case. P.Ws. 9 and 11 are the seizure witnesses and rest of them are members of the raiding team. Although P.Ws. 9 and 11 have identified their signatures, but they have stated that they have signed on blank pages and they2were threatened by the informant to make signature. In spite of this evidence of seizure witnesses, they were not declared hostile. He has further submitted that so far as ballistic report is concerned, the same is Ext.-4, but the expert has not been examined and it has been proved by the investigating officer who was P.W.-10. The learned counsel further submits that P.W.-10 has also exhibited Ext.-5 i.e. sanction for prosecution and neither the sanctioning authority has been examined nor the application of mind while granting sanction has been proved. The learned counsel has submitted that only the signature on the sanction, but the content of the sanction has not been proved. He has relied upon the judgment passed by the Hon'ble Supreme Court reported in (2006) 10 SCC 595 as well as the judgment reported in AIR 1954 637 (SC). 
 4. As the court's time is over, the matter is adjourned and is directed to be posted on 30.09.2020 for further hearing. 
 (Anubha Rawat Choudhary, J.) Mukul

case title: Arvind Kumar Yadav vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 4 in the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961', 'Section 3 in the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 504 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Lakhan Chandra Roy, Advocate. For the State : Mr. Nawin Kumar Singh, A.P.P. For the O.P. No. 2 : Mr. Arvind Kumar Choudhary, Advocate. 
 --------- 
 04/Dated: 15/09/2020 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Lakhan Chandra Roy. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner has prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Rikhiya P.S. Case No. 168/2018 for the offence registered underSections 323,504,498A,34I.P.C. andSections 3/4of the Dowry Prohibition Act. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that prior to lodging of the case, both the parties have settled their dispute after payment of Rs.1,45,000/- and to that effect, an agreement was executed by the both the parties, the incident was videographed and the payment was made by Prabhu Sharma, as such the provisional bail granted to this petitioner, who remained in custody from 08.02.2020 till provisional bail granted on 18.05.2020, may be confirmed. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. Nawin Kumar Singh, Additional Public Prosecutor assisted by learned counsel for the opposite party no.2, Mr. Arvind Kumar Choudhary has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that the signature of the informant at page nos.14 and 23 of the petition differ and she has not admitted that such agreement was executed between the parties and payment to the tune of Rs.1,45,000/- was paid by Prabhu Sharma under the videography, as such, provisional bail granted to the petitioner on 18.05.2020 may be cancelled. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties, looking into fact and circumstances and the evidence made in the complaint petition and that the petitioner has already remained in custody for more than 3 months 10 days, provisional bail granted to the petitioner by Coordinate Bench of this court vide order dated 18.05.2020 is hereby confirmed. 
 However, learned trial court is directed to refer the matter before the D.L.S.A., Deoghar so as to have amicable settlement between the parties as trial has commenced. 
 Mediation shall be done after the physical court starts. Both the parties are expected to cooperate in the mediation process. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Durga Hajam vs State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANANDA SEN. 
 THROUGH : VIDEO CONFERENCING 
 ------ 
 FOR THE PETITIONER(S) : Mr. Bijay Kr. Sinha, Advocate FOR THE STATE : Mr. Shiv Kumar Sharma, APP 
 ------ 
 03/15.09.2020 The lawyer have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through video conference today at 11.00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 This case was listed/supposed to be listed before the Lawazima Board of the Registrar General for seeking an order in respect of the defect(s), pointed out by the office. 
 Considering the pandemic situation where the court has minimize the footfall of the lawyers and their clerk in the court, this court felt proper to get all the cases listed before this Court so that the defect(s) can be looked into at this stage only. Thus, this case is listed today before this Court directly. 
 Defect(s) as pointed out by the office, if any, is ignored for the present. Counsel for the petitioner submits that in utter violation of law as laid down by the Hon'ble Supreme Court in the case of Priyanka Srivastava & Anr. Vs State Of Uttar Pradesh & Others reported in the case of (2015) 6 SCC 287 the FIR was registered. He submits that court below, without there being any affidavit with the complaint, has referred the complaint underSection 156(3)Cr.P.C for registering the FIR. He submits that this illegality goes to the root of registering the FIR. 
 Issue notice to opposite party no.2 for which requisites etc. under registered post with A/D as well as through ordinary process must be filed within two weeks. 
 In the meantime, further proceeding so far as these petitioners are concerned in connection Lohardaga SC/ST P.S. Case No. 2 of 2020, pending in the court of Additional Sessions Judge-I, Lohardaga shall remain stayed. Further, no coercive steps shall be taken against the petitioners in these cases. 
 (ANANDA SEN , J) anjali/ C.P 3

 For the Petitioner : Mr. R.S. Mazumdar, Sr. Advocate. 
 Heard, learned senior counsel Mr. R.S. Mazumdar assisted by learned counsel for the petitioner, Mr. Rohan Mazumdar. 
 Learned senior counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner Rajeev Pandey has been wrongly implicated in this case i.e. Chatra Sadar (Mahila) P.S. Case No. 09/2020 for the offence registered underSection 376I.P.C. and Sections 4 & 6 of the POCSO Act as the alleged date of occurrence is December, 2019, whereas F.I.R. has been lodged on 13.02.2020. 
 Learned senior counsel for the petitioner has submitted that it is a case where the victim was impressed with the look and service of this petitioner and try to solemnize marriage. The entire case is a false case as the victim is having date of birth as 17.03.2002. 
 Learned senior counsel for the petitioner has submitted that in view of Annexure-2 Series of the Supplementary Affidavit dated 15.09.2020 i.e. the application filed by the victim, her mother and father, the entire prosecution case is demolished. 
 Office is directed to bring the said Supplementary Affidavit on record. 
 Learned senior counsel for the petitioner has submitted that petitioner is in custody since 13.02.2020 and he is teacher and his entire carrier is ruined because of false case. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. Suraj Verma, Additional Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer for bail and has submitted that State wants to file a detail counter affidavit looking into the date-2-of birth of the victim as well as the Annexure-2 Series filed in the Supplementary Affidavit dated 15.09.2020. 
 Learned counsel for the informant, Mr. Atanu Banerjee submits that as per the instruction, he admits that Annexure-2 Series has been filed by informant and her parents. 
 Considering the rival submissions of the parties, State counsel is granted four weeks' time to file detail counter affidavit. 
 Put up this case after four weeks. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Kartick Mandal vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through Video Conferencing 
 --- 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Rahul Ranjan, Advocate For the State : Mrs. Niki Sinha, A.P.P. 
 --- 
 Order No. 03 Dated 15th September, 2020 Heard the learned counsel for the respective sides. So far as the defects No. 3, 4 and 9(1) are concerned, learned counsel for the petitioner undertakes to remove the same once the situation normalizes. As regards the rest defects, as pointed out by the office, are concerned, the same are ignored. 
 The petitioner apprehends his arrest in connection with Narayanpur P.S. Case No. 24 of 2020. 
 It has been alleged that the minor daughter of the informant was enticed away by Ajay Kumar Mandal and the petitioner and others were suspected to have facilitated the enticement. 
 In the 164Cr.P.C. statement of the victim, it has been state that she was having a friendship with Ajay Kumar Mandal and on account of the said friendship both have eloped. 
 Mrs. Niki Sinha, learned APP has stated that the petitioner has got one criminal antecedent being involved in a case of cybercrime. 
 However, so far as the present case is concerned, the 164Cr.P.C. statement of the victim does not utter a single word about the involvement of the petitioner. It therefore appears that the petitioner has been implicated merely on suspicion. 
 On consideration of the aforesaid facts, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. The petitioner accordingly is directed to surrender before the learned trial court within four weeks from today and on such surrender, he shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Ten Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Additional Chief Judicial Magistrate, Jamtara in connection with Narayanpur P.S. Case No. 24 of 2020, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed.

case title: Shambhu Ram vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 201 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
The matter was taken up through Video Conferencing. Learned counsels for the parties had no objection with it and submitted that the audio and video qualities are good. 
 -------- 
 I.A. No. 1193 of 2020 4/ 15.09.2020 Heard learned counsel for the appellant and learned counsel for the State on the interlocutory application filed by the appellant, renewing the prayer for bail during the pendency of this appeal. 
 The appellant has been convicted and sentenced for the offences underSections 302,201/34of the Indian Penal Code. 
 The appellant is the father of the deceased and it is alleged that he had committed the murder of his own daughter along with family members and cremated the dead body. When the police reached the place of occurrence, no one was present in the house and the planks of the chouki, on which the deceased was allegedly murdered, were also missing. The police reached the place, where the dead body was burnt and the parts of the plank of the chouki were also recovered. The burnt bones were also seized by the police, which were sent for FSL examination and were found to be human bones. The saree, by which the deceased was allegedly strangulated, was also recovered. 
 In the backdrop of these facts, prayer for bail of this appellant was earlier rejected by this Court on merits. 
 Learned counsel for the appellant has renewed the prayer for bail. In the facts of this case, we are not inclined to grant bail to the appellant, Shambhu Ram. Accordingly, his prayer for bail is rejected. 
 The aforesaid interlocutory application stands dismissed. 
 (H. C. Mishra, J.) (Rajesh Kumar, J.) R.Kr.

case title: Shakil Ahmad @ Shakil Ansari vs State Of Jharkhand

all_text:
Coram: Hon'ble Mr. Justice Ananda Sen Through:-Video Conferencing ...... 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Suraj Singh, Advocate For the State : Mrs. Vandana Bharti, A.P.P. 
 ...... 
 5/15.09.2020 The lawyers have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through video conferencing today at 11.15 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner prays to ignore the defect and take up the matter on merits. 
 Defects stand ignored. 
 Heard the parties. 
 The petitioner, in this application, has challenged the order dated 22.11.2019, by which processes underSection 82Cr.P.C. has been issued against him. 
 After going through the impugned order, I find that the same is non-speaking and cryptic. No satisfaction of the court has been recorded in the impugned order. No reason has been assigned while passing the impugned order issuing process underSection 82Cr.P.C. In absence of any reason and satisfaction, the order impugned is rendered bad in law. 
 Thus, the impugned order dated 22.11.2019, passed by the Additional Sessions Judge-VI-cum-Special Judge SC/ST Act, Dhanbad, in SC/ST Case No. 27/2019, issuing process underSection 82Cr.P.C. against the petitioner, is hereby set aside. The matter is remitted to the court below to pass a fresh speaking order, recording the satisfaction, in accordance with law and in terms of the judgment, passed by this Court in the case of "Md. Rustum Alam @ Rustam & Others- versus- State of Jharkhand, in Cr. M.P. No. 2722 of 2019." 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition stands allowed. 
 (Ananda Sen, J) Mukund/-cp.1

case title: Neeraj Kumar Shahu @ Neeraj Kumar ... vs The State Of Jharkhand
judges name(s): (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.), (Rupees Twenty Five thousand), (2)
issues: ['Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 406 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
Neeraj Kumar Shahu @ Neeraj Kumar Sahu ... Petitioner Versus 
 1. The State of Jharkhand

 CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANIL KUMAR CHOUDHARY 
 ------ 
 For the Petitioner : Mr. Binit Chandra, Advocate For the State : Mr. Ashok Kumar, Addl. P.P. 
 ------ 
 Order No.02 Dated- 15.09.2020 Heard the parties through video conferencing. Learned counsel for the petitioner personally undertakes to remove the defects as pointed out by the stamp reporter within two weeks after the lockdown period is over. 
 In view of the personal undertaking of the learned counsel for the petitioner, the defects pointed out by the stamp reporter are ignored for the present. 
 Apprehending his arrest, the petitioner has moved this Court for grant of privilege of anticipatory bail in connection with Complaint Case No.3225 of 2017 registered undersections 498A/406/34of the Indian Penal Code and under Section 3/4 of D.P. Act. 
 Let notice be issued to the opposite party no.2 under registered cover with A/D as well as under ordinary process for which requisites etc. must be filed within two weeks by the petitioner, failing which, this application shall stand dismissed without further reference to the Bench. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner is the husband of the complainant and the allegation against the petitioner are all false and are general and omnibus in nature. Hence, it is submitted that the petitioner be given the privilege of anticipatory bail. 
 The learned Addl. P.P. opposes the prayer for anticipatory bail. 
 List this case on 05.11.2020. 
 Considering the submissions of the counsels and the fact as discussed above, I am inclined to pass an interim order of anticipatory bail provisionally till 05.11.2020. In case of the petitioner being arrested by the police on or before 05.11.2020, he shall be released on bail provisionally on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty Five thousand) with two sureties of like amount each to the satisfaction of the officer concerned in connection with Complaint Case No.3225 of 2017 subject to the conditions laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 (Anil Kumar Choudhary, J.) Sonu/Gunjan-

case title: Santosh Vishwakarma vs State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 204 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 190 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973', 'Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 506 in The Indian Penal Code', 'Section 504 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANANDA SEN. 
 THROUGH : VIDEO CONFERENCING 
 ------ 
 FOR THE PETITIONER(S) : Mr. Nilesh Kumar, Advocate FOR THE STATE : Shree Prakash Jha, APP 
 ------ 
 02/15.09.2020 Heard learned counsel for the parties through video conferencing. The lawyers have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through video conference today at 11.00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 In this application, petitioner has prayed to quash the composite order dated 24.03.2020 by which cognizance of the offence punishable underSection 376,504,506/34IPC has been taken and summon has been issued. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the cognizance order is absolutely bad and is a non-speaking order and it does not reflect any subjective satisfaction as to what are the materials to take cognizance against this petitioner. He submits that the requirements ofSections 190&204Cr.P.C has not been dealt with in the impugned order. He is relying upon the judgment of this Court in the case of Amresh Kumar Dhiraj and Ors. Vs. State of Jharkhand &Anr., reported in 2020 (1) JLJR 199. 
 After going through the record, I find that the order is absolutely cryptic and non-speaking and is not in conformity with the judgment passed by this Court in the case of Amresh Kumar Dhiraj and Ors. Vs. State of Jharkhand &Anr., reported in 2020 (1) JLJR 199(Jhr). What are the materials against the petitioner to proceed, has also not been mentioned. Thus, the impugned order dated 24.03.2020 passed by the court below is, hereby, set aside. The matter is remitted to the court below to pass a fresh order in accordance with the provision of law. 
 This criminal miscellaneous petition stands allowed. 
 (ANANDA SEN , J) anjali/ C.P 3

case title: Guljar Ansari vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 376 in The Indian Penal Code']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 Order No. 02: Dated: 15th September, 2020 Heard learned counsel for the petitioner and learned counsel appearing for the State assisted by learned counsel for the opposite party no. 2. 
 So far as the defect nos. 9(i) to (iv) are concerned, the same are ignored. 
 The petitioner is an accused in connection with Nagri P.S. Case No.226 of 2019 (S.T. No. 201 of 2020).The prayer for bail of the petitioner was earlier rejected by this Court in B.A. No. 3003 of 2020. 
 The only ground for renewal of prayer for bail made by the petitioner is the submission advanced by the learned counsel for the petitioner and echoed by the learned counsel for the opposite party no. 2 that the matter has been compromised between the petitioner and the opposite party no. 2 for which reference has been made to a compromise petition filed before the court of learned Additional Judicial Commissioner-I, Ranchi. 
 This is a case undersection 376of IPC and the allegation against the petitioner reveals that the informant was repeatedly subjected to rape by the petitioner. The fact that the case is non-compoundable and therefore, the compromise which has been purportedly effected would have no bearing for consideration for grant of bail to the petitioner. 
 Accordingly, there being no fresh ground to reconsider the prayer for bail of the petitioner, the prayer for bail is rejected once again. 
 However, the trial court is directed to expedite the trial once the normal court work resumes. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J.) MM

case title: Bajal Tudu vs The State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 164 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE KAILASH PRASAD DEO (Through : Video Conferencing) 
 --------- 
 Heard, learned counsel for the petitioners, Mr. Kanti Kumar Ojha. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners has submitted that the petitioners have prayed for grant of regular bail in connection with Amrapara P.S. Case No. 01/2020 for the offence registered under Section 364-A I.P.C. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners has submitted that on previous date, the Coordinate Bench of this Court has called for the statement of the victim recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C. and the same has been received, which reflects that name of the petitioners are not mentioned by the victim. 
 Learned counsel for the petitioners has further submitted that petitioners are in custody since 28.01.2020 and have no criminal antecedent. 
 Learned counsel for the State, Mr. S. P. Jha, Additional Public Prosecutor has submitted that he has not received the statement of the victim recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C., as such, four weeks' time may be granted to file detail counter affidavit. 
 After hearing learned counsel for the parties, this Court directs the learned counsel for the State to file detail counter affidavit including the statement of the victim recorded underSection 164Cr.P.C. and also to ascertain as to whether these petitioners were put on test identification parade or not? 
 Put up this case after four weeks. 
 It is made clear that no further adjournment shall be granted to the State, if the counter affidavit is not filed within a period of four weeks. 
 (Kailash Prasad Deo, J.) Sunil-Jay/

case title: Sona Mani Mishra And Another vs Shri Paramand Tripathi And Others
judges name(s): (Dr. Ravi Ranjan, C.J.), (Sujit Narayan Prasad, J.)
issues: ['Article 227 in The Constitution Of India 1949']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE THE CHIEF JUSTICE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE SUJIT NARAYAN PRASAD 
 ------ 
 None appears on behalf of the appellants. Perused the office note. 
 Although several defects have been pointed out by the Office, but it does not appear that the Stamp Reporter has pointed out any defect regarding maintainability of this appeal in view of the writ petition having been filed underArticle 227of the Constitution of India. 
 We have found that in many cases, in which such issue of maintainability was involved, such defect is not being pointed out by the Office. 
 Hence, let a proper note be put up by the Stamp Reporter in this regard. 
 Let this matter be put up on 22nd of September, 2020. It is expected that the writ petitioners would be well represented on the next date of hearing. 
 The learned counsel appearing for the writ petitioners-appellants would also be ready on the point of maintainability of this appeal on the next date of hearing. 
 Since the learned counsel for the appellants is not present today, let a copy of this order be communicated to him either on email or by any other mode by the Office. 
 
 (Dr. Ravi Ranjan, C.J.) (Sujit Narayan Prasad, J.) Manoj/Raman

case title: Ajeet Mehta vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through Video Conferencing 
 --- 
 Heard the learned counsel appearing for the respective parties. The defects, as pointed out by the office, are ignored. The petitioner is an accused in connection with Pandu P.S. Case No.04 of 2020, corresponding to G.R. Case No.609 of 2020. 
 The petitioner was suspected to have enticed away the daughter of the informant. In the 164Cr.P.C. statement of the victim, she has stated that she was knowing the petitioner for five months and both had fallen in love and had decided to go to Delhi. On the way they were caught at Jabalpur Railway Station and were brought back. She has further stated that the petitioner had no hand in her enticement. 
 The medical report reveals that the age of the victim which has been assessed is between 15-16 years. In the 164Cr.P.C. statement of the victim, there does not appear to be any allegation of sexual advances made against the petitioner. The petitioner is in custody since 08.02.2020. 
 Regard being had to the above, the petitioner, named above, is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st Class, Palamau in connection with Pandu P.S. Case No.04 of 2020, corresponding to G.R. Case No.609 of 2020. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J.) Raja/-

 02/15.09.2020 Heard Mr. Deepak Kumar, learned counsel for the petitioners and Mr. Satish Prasad, learned A.P.P. for the State. 
 The petitioners have prayed for grant of anticipatory bail, as they are apprehending their arrest in connection with Domchanch P.S. Case No. 05/2020. 
 It has been alleged that Jobraj Singh had caused bodily harm to the informant with arrow and pasuli. The wife of the informant also sustained injuries with similar weapons. 
 The petitioners seem to have been implicated on the allegation of threatening the informant earlier. The First Information Report also reveals about an existing land dispute. The injuries sustained by the informant and his wife can therefore be attributed to Jobraj Singh. 
 In view of the aforesaid, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioners. The petitioners accordingly are directed to surrender before the learned court below within a period of four weeks and on such surrender, they shall be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand only) each with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned S.D.J.M., Koderma in connection with Domchanch P.S. case title: Chunnu Bhuiyan @ Chunu Bhuiyan vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
Chunnu Bhuiyan @ Chunu Bhuiyan. ......Petitioner Versus The State of Jharkhand. .....Opposite Parties 
 -------- 
 Coram: THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY 
 -------- 
 The petitioner apprehends his arrest in connection with Nawdiha Bazar P.S. Case No. 35 of 2019. 
 It has been alleged that the petitioner had entered into the house of the informant at night and started molesting her. Petitioner is also alleged to have taken Rs.30,000/- cash and ornaments of the informant. 
 The FIR seems to have been instituted after seven days from the alleged date of occurrence. The wife of the informant had also lodged a case of molestation against the son of the informant. Thus there appears to be a case and counter case between both the sides and institution of the FIR without any reasonable or plausible explanation for such delay creates a doubt over the prosecution case itself. 
 On consideration of the aforesaid facts, I am inclined to extend the privilege of anticipatory bail to the petitioner. 
 Accordingly, the petitioner, named above, is directed to surrender in the court below within a period of four weeks from today and pray for regular bail, and in that event, he will be enlarged on bail, on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- ( Ten thousand only) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st class, Palamau at Daltonganj in connection with Nawdiha Bazar P.S. Case No. 35 of 2019, subject to the conditions as laid down underSection 438(2)of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
 This application stands allowed. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J) Rakesh/-

case title: Rajesh Kumar Pandey @ Rajesh Ku. ... vs The State Of Jharkhand
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE RONGON MUKHOPADHYAY Through Video Conferencing 
 --- 
 Heard the learned counsel appearing for the respective parties. The defect no.9 (i) & (ii), as pointed out by the office, are ignored. The petitioner is an accused in connection with S.T. No. 52 of 2020 arising out of Mandu (Kuju) P.S. Case No.269 of 2016, pending in the court of learned Additional Sessions Judge-I, Ramgarh. 
 The prayer for bail of the petitioner was earlier rejected by this Court in B.A. No.6579 of 2019. 
 It appears that an order was passed 18.03.2020 by the learned Additional Chief Judicial Magistrate, Ramgarh by which, cognizance has been taken for the offence underSections 498-Aand306of the Indian penal Code. The First Information Report was instituted underSections 498-Aand306of the Indian penal Code and subsequently,Section 304-Bwas added at the time when the bail application of the petitioner was earlier rejected on 20.11.2019. The petitioner appears to be in custody since 28.03.2019. 
 On considering the period of custody undergone by the petitioner and the chain circumstance as enumerated above, the petitioner, named above, is directed to be released on bail on furnishing bail bond of Rs.10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand) with two sureties of the like amount each to the satisfaction of Additional Sessions Judge-I, Ramgarh in connection with S.T. No. 52 of 2020 arising out of Mandu (Kuju) P.S. Case No.269 of 2016. 
 (Rongon Mukhopadhyay, J.) Raja/-

case title: Sonam Purty @ Sonam Purti vs State Of Jharkhand
issues: ['Section 82 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973']
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANANDA SEN. 
 THROUGH : VIDEO CONFERENCING 
 ------ 
 FOR THE PETITIONER(S) : Md. Zaid Ahmed, Advocate FOR THE STATE : Mr. Someshwar Roy, APP 
 ------ 
 02/15.09.2020 Heard learned counsel for the parties through video conferencing. The lawyer have no objection with regard to the proceeding, which has been held through video conference today at 11.00 A.M. They have no complaint in respect to the audio and video clarity and quality. 
 In this application, petitioner has challenged the order dated 30.5.2020 whereby process underSection 82Cr.P.C has been issued. 
 After going through the impugned order, I find that order is cryptic and non-speaking one. The court below has not recorded the subjective satisfaction which is necessary to be recorded while issuing the process underSection 82Cr.P.C. The court below has only mentioned that on 7.2.2020 non-bailable warrant of arrest has been issued and the penal sections are non-bailable in nature. These are not sustainable grounds for issuing process underSection 82Cr.P.C. This Court has passed detailed order in the case of Md. Rustum Alam @ Rustam & Ors. Vrs. State of Jharkhand in Cr.M.P No. 2722 of 2019 covering the issues. The order dated 30.5.2020 is not in conformity with the order passed by this Court in the case of Md. Rustum Alam @ Rustam (Supra). Hence the order dated 30.5.2020 is hereby, set aside. The matter is remanded back to the court below for passing order afresh in accordance with law. 
 Accordingly, this application stands allowed. 
 (ANANDA SEN , J) anjali/ C.P 3

case title: Balwant Singh vs State Of Jharkhand & Anr
all_text:
CORAM : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE ANANDA SEN. 
 THROUGH : VIDEO CONFERENCING 
 ------ 
 FOR THE PETITIONER(S) : Mr. Madhu Sudan Mittal, Sr. Advocate FOR THE STATE : Mr. P.D. Agarwal, Spl. P.P 
 ----- 
 03/15.09.2020 Mr. M.S. Mittal, learned Senior Counsel appearing on behalf of petitioner assisted by Salona Mittal submits that the alleged offence is against the Company but surprisingly the Company has not made an accused. He submits that the FIR has been lodged as if the petitioners who are Directors of the Company has committed the offence in their personal capacity. He submits that there is no whispered as to what overt act has been committed by the petitioner to attract offence underSections 135and138of the Indian Electricity Act. He submits that cognizance has been taken against the provisionSection 149of the Indian Electricity Act. 
 Standing Counsel Ms. Asmita Srivastava appearing on behalf of JUVNL who is present in this proceeding submits that she is entitled to receive copies and accept notices on behalf of JUVNL which was earlier Jharkhand State Electricity Board. 
 Salona Mittal is directed to serve two copies of this petition to Asmita Srivastava through email. Counsel appearing on behalf of JUVNL is directed to file counter-affidavit, if any, within eight weeks. 
 In the meantime, further proceeding so far as this petitioner is concerned in connection with Ghatshila- Chakulia P.S. Case No. 66 of 2020, corresponding to G.R. No. 557 of 2010, pending in the court of Special Judge (Electricity), Jamshedpur shall remain stayed. 
 (ANANDA SEN , J) anjali/ C.P 3

case title: Electrosteel Steels Limited vs Jharkhand State Pollution ...
issues: ['Section 19 in The Environment (Protection) Act, 1986', 'Section 15 in The Environment (Protection) Act, 1986', 'Section 5 in The Environment (Protection) Act, 1986']
cited cases: ['alembic pharmaceutical v. rohit prajapati and others']
all_text:
CORAM: HON'BLE MRS. JUSTICE ANUBHA RAWAT CHOUDHARY 
 --- 
 1. Heard learned counsels appearing for the parties on the point of extension of interim relief. 
 2. Heard Mr. Abhay Mishra, Advocate for the proposed intervenor opposing the prayer. 
 3. The learned Senior counsel for the petitioner refers to the interim orders for which prayer has been made for extension. 
 In WP(C) No.1873 of 2018 this court passed an interim order on 16th July 2018 in the following terms: - 
 "Considering the submissions made by the counsel for the parties, this Court grants interim order to the extent that till the next date the petitioner be allowed to operate under the supervisory regulatory control of the respondent-Board, who may carry out periodical checks as to the adherence by the petitioner to the aforesaidPollution Control Acts. 
 In WP(C) No.4850 of 2018, this court passed an interim order on 27th September 2018 in the following terms: - 
 "18. As this court prima-facie finds that the impugned order in this case has been passed in total violations of principles of natural justice therefore in such circumstances this writ petition is being entertained. 
 21. This court further prima-facie finds that the impugned order has serious repercussions on the unit of the petitioner which is a running unit and has caused prejudice to the petitioner on account of violations of principles of natural justice. This court further finds that the balance of convenience is in favour of the petitioner. Accordingly, operation, implementation and execution of the impugned order dated 20.09.2018 (Annexure-19) is hereby stayed till the next date. 
 23. However, this order will not be an impediment for the petitioner if the petitioner chooses to apply for statutory clearance as indicated in the impugned order without prejudice to the contention of the petitioner in this writ petition." 
 4. The above interim orders have been extended from time to time by this Hon'ble Court and on number of the occasions with the consent of the parties. The matter regarding extension of interim relief pursuant to the present interlocutory applications was heard on earlier occasions and the prayer was opposed by the Jharkhand State Pollution Control Board and the learned ASGI representing Union of India also expressed reservations on such prayer ,but today, the learned Advocate General appearing for the State of Jharkhand as well as Jharkhand State Pollution Control Board upon instructions has consented for extension of interim relief, although no such affidavit has been filed. The Union of India has filed an affidavit clearly expressing no objection to extension of interim relief.
